33cl bottle. The appearance is a dark-ish blonde with a red hue. There are a lot of bubbles and the head is very big. The nose is slightly elusive but there is a gentle pale malt profile. The taste is of more gentle malt, then zingy-lemon which continues through to the finish and is joined by green herbacsous tang. The palate has a big structure, a creamy texture and a refreshing long finish. Overall, a tastey beer.

Pour is a golden orange color with a decent sized white head, which which slowly recedes and leaves good lacing. Nose is mostly of bread with some fruity notes. Taste is much more dominated by notes of coriander and honey, however done well and does not taste like your drinking pepper.

Bottle.  Clear golden orange in color with a massive pillow of foam sitting atop.  Took two pours to get this into my glass.  Bready aroma, nice yeasty spiciness, and maybe a little bit of honey.  Taste is yeasty spiciness, some honey sweetness, some bread, and a dry finish.  Nice warming feeling as it goes down.  Medium bodied.  All around a really enjoyable beer.
Cloudy pale yellow with a very thin head, could not identify the aroma so I will say it was complex and fruity, fruity malty caramel taste, very good beer.
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2011 Pours a beautiful yellow. Aroma of yeast and slight frutiness, banana. Great tripel, but not quite the best.

On tap in a bar in Highwood, IL. Poured into a Chimay glass. Golden pour with frothy white head. Aroma of sweet breast malt and yeast, green apples and pears. Taste is sweet and minorly tart. Crisp yet creamy mouthfeel. Excellent.

Not my favorite Chimay (Im partial to the grand reserve/blue) but still very nice. Nose is full of yeast and fruitiness/sweetness. Taste is full of spice, grapefruit, strong hops, and sweet malt. Color is excellent orange-amber. Nice and good for sipping.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2011 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: my favourite Chimay, strong citric hops, spicy yeast, nice malt, minor sweetness, bitter hop ending that is a little bit in your face, hint of banana in the smell as well

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2011 
Original rating, 2011-03-14: 6-5-7-5-14=3.7
Im not sure if this is the most visually appealing beer ever made, or if it
was my newly bought trappist chalice that made this brew look so gorgeous: a white, creamy, fully lasting head floats on top of the beautiful medium amber,almost clear body. Spices, perfume, citrus, pine and yeast in the aroma. The taste is light bitter, but somehow it magically transforms into a long, sweet aftertaste with honey flavours. Also a hint of banana in the flavour. Medium body, lively carbonation.
[33 cl bottle, from Vinmonopolet]

Re-rating, 2011-10-21, 8-5-8-4-15=4.0
To celebrate our new house I open a Chimay Triple, knowing that Im in for a treat. It turns out that I like this beer even better now than when I first rated it. Not surprisingly it looks rather similar to what it did last time, even it I would describe the body as slightly hazy. The lacing is excellent. How I could give this a 6 for the aroma is beyond my belief, its fantastic! Spices, yeast, citrus, herbs, honey, light fruits, banana, peach, pineapple and vanilla! Both sweet and dry with spicy herbs. Wow, thats what I call complex! Up from 6 to 8. Moderate bitter initial taste, along with a light bitterness and a vague touch of acidity. The acidic touch is also present in the finish, but a medium to light bitterness dominates. Very long aftertaste with a peppery dryness. The flavours are as plentiful as the aromas: spices, herbs, resin, honey, and light fruit. The alcohol is clearly present and Im glad it isnt hidden: it gives the brew a vinous exclusiveness that makes me want a Chimay Triple for next new years eve instead of a champagne. I think I prefer the beer at the warmer end of the recommended temperature scale, i.e. at least 8ºC, since this brings forward the sweet honey flavours. Taste up from 7 to 8. Medium to full body, oily to sirupy texture and medium to lively carbonation. A good mouthfeel, but I dont think it deserves a 5: Palate down to 4. Overall up from 14 to 15. A magnificent beer!
[33 cl bottle, from Vinmonopolet Oslo City, Oslo]
hazy golden body and white head. yeast aroma with some raisin, appel and pear, hints of honey. malty and creamy. Some spice and hints of banana. Dry and some alcohol. Good beer to drink.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Wegmans Leesburg.  It pours a slightly cloudy amber color with a nice foamy, off-white head.  The nose is spicy with notes of Belgian yeast, a slight fruitiness, clove, and a bit of banana.  The flavor has dry fruit notes of apple and banana with a nice zing of yeast and spice.  Medium bodied with abundant carbonation leading to a nice dry finish.  This is a very nice brew.  You would do yourself a disservice if you dont try it.

Pours hazy amber brown with a huge frothy head. Aroma is light, bananas, malty sweetness and fruity notes.  Flavor of spices, yeast, hint of bananas, some noticable hop bitterness over the malty sweetness. Bitter finish. Palate is full bodied, high carbonation and rough but really enjoyable mouthfeel

Pours a hazy amber with a billowy pure white head. Aromas of Belgian yeast, apples, raisins. My first impression of the beer was that it is perfectly smooth, balanced, and complex. A strong yeasty flavors adds bread, biscuit, and a buttery mouthfeel. The malt is sweet, but rather short lived as a firm hop bitterness is also present, adding spice characteristics. Black pepper, honey, clove, and apple on the finish.

Draft into a Westmalle chalice at "The Porch" in Key West, Florida.   This was a very nice buttery smooth Belgian ale at the best bar in Key West.  There were bread, butter, alcohol, and light hops in the first sip.  As it warms up, the hops die back a little bit and the yeast and alcohol become more pronounced.  This was a great beer and a great bar.  Now I want to go back!
Has an out of place aroma, almost like some sort of baking spice.  Other than that its a rather standard tripel, although not as complex as others in the style.
Excellent tripel. Golden colour, refreshing nose, complex aroma. Recommendable.

0,33l bottle. Hazy golden body covered by a three fingers thick, frothy, off-white head. Honey, dried flowers aroma. Medium sweet, alcoholic and quite bitter with a dry bitter finish with notes of clove. Medium to full body. Carbonation prickles the tongue.

pale yellow, some fine sediment, lots of steady bubbles and a frothy white head
nose is a dry barnyard yeastiness but it is rather subdued. theres not much on the nose and i expected more from a tripel
full body and moderately fizzy
up front the beer is sweet, neutrally malty and creamy. the finish is very drying, leaving your mouth dry and with an odd bitterness. 
for an 8% tripel there is surprisingly little aroma or taste of alcohol. sadly, i kind of like that in a tripel.
i cant say i really enjoy this.

0.33l bottle. This is a nice semi-cloudy orange brew with a two-finger sized fluffy and white head, leaving big lacing. Strong peppery aromas, some yeast and notes of banana. Tastes are orange and grapy with hint of sweet honey. You can really sense the warming alcohol tingling down your throat leaving a longlasting clovey and spicy aftertaste. Nice and complex brew.

bottled 12/09.  Pours hazy orange apricot gradient, with fizzy, sustaining white head.  Aroma of honey glazed raisin, pear, spiced white grape.  This is a particularly, creamy, smooth, and soft feeling triple, full bodied, with abv non existent and a very subtle bitterness on the finish.  Flavor is complex, at first with sweet spiced fruit tones, leading to something of a hop profile with light bitterness, and then an evolving finish which seems to jump back and forth in between these aspects.

The gold standard for triples, Chimay White is a beauty to behold and a wonder to partake. Pouring a cloudy amber, this brew lays a head of untouched snow leaves full thick viscous lacing coating the glass. With the first sip a complex mix of yeast, peppery notes, malt sweetness arrive. Not a second before ample hop bitterness ramps up to quickly temper the sweetness. Notes of apple and cherry mix well in the aroma, while the fade is even with just a bit of bitterness left behind to cleanse the palate. Sprightly carbonation plays an important part in the mouthfeel.

poured hazy orange with huge head (so much it overflowed). not much aroma. bananas, plums, yeast and wheat flavours. light alcohol warming in the middle, with a tart finish. i drank half the bottle before i realized how much i liked this beer. great body and complexity, will buy more if i can find it.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2013 Bottle. Hazy amber colour with a  white head. Aroma has some spices, caramel. Flavour is yeasty, some spices, alcohol.

--Original rating 2011-02-21--
8-4-8-4-18
Dark golden colour with a thick head. Spicy aroma. Rich spicy flavour. A very good beer.

33 cl: Cloudy with little, shortlived head.
Nose with lemon/limoncello, sour cherry - wheat like!?!.
Slightly bitter and not very harmonic. Bottle trouble?
Taste is sour, with cherry and a slightly metallic taste.
Must be rated again as this was very dissapointing.
poured into my Chimay glass. tastes similar to the red and blue. the white  has a stronger  aroma. flavor is also stronger. overall an okay  beer.
Hazy golden color with a white head that thins quickly.  Aroma of dried fruits, flowers, and honey.  Rich mouthfeel with a pleasant finishing bitterness.  Great beer.
UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Super belgian beer with a beautiful head. Aroma is complex. Nice balance of bitterness and the great yeast from the monks.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2011 330ml bottle. Poured into a Chimay glass according to the instructions of Chimay, with the last bits of the beer left in the bottle. Color is cloudy amber with a large, cloudy, creamy head. Very beautiful in the trappist glass. Aroma is fruity (raw bananas and peaches) and yeasty. Taste is raw bananas, spiciness, dry fruitiness and a little bit of sweet maltiness. Aftertaste is yeasty with some dry bitterness and a bit of alcohol. Palate is full, but a bit too carbonated, perhaps due to poor pouring technique? Drank with some aged emmental. Worked very well together once both started to warm up.

bought at LCBO ottawa. 330 ml for 2.90$
pours thick yellow with beautiful white head that stays
carbonation is a bit intense. Tastes very good. 
not my favourite Tripel, however a great value for the price
Yellow haze. Herbs and honey are the initial hint and a bitter finish. I think its medium bodied.

quite a sweet fruity smell, almost sickly sweet, a definite orange to the aroma, a cloudy golden appearance and fast dissapating fizzy head sits upon this beer, the taste closely follows the aroma, a bit highyl carbonated for my liking, and a bit expensive too, this beer doesnt match up to its big name.

aroma citrus, herbs, 
looks hazy, amber, not much head
could taste a little sweeter, slightly bitter finish.

From a 330ml bottle on 12/2/2011. Pours cloudy and golden. Has a relatively subtle aroma of honey and fruits (peaches) and yeast. The taste in sweet and fruity up front, with some big spicy and peppery notes following, along with a good dash of warming alcohol. Tastes every bit of its 8%. Nice stuff.
Chimays Tripel just isnt one of my favorite Tripels. It happens to be the spiciest in my opinion.
Hazy yellow-brownish with a huge white head. Mainly fruity flavours, andnot so spicy or hoppy. Rather bitter and dry. Light mouthfeel for so much alcohol. Not my favourite take on the tripel style.

Served on tap.  A slightly hazy golden beer with the usual triple head shortened by the rather chilled pour.  Nose is firstly of candied sugar and spices then comes the rich yeast backbone, all fruity and soft.  There is a light buttery character that works well with the yeast and this develops in the mouth.  Here the spices are joined by an almost herbal flavour; then the malt comes back with a honey edge, merging into that candied sugar.  The mouth feel is medium with a soft carbonation.  It finishes towards the malts and yeast, edging towards an almost bitter mid-palate.  Finally theres a return to the spices.  Very nice.

Aroma of spice, floral and grassy hops, yeast and hints of banana. Pour very hazy yellow/orange color with huge pillow of head and outstanding lace that clings better then Spiderman. Taste very bitter, grassy hops, orange peel, spice, banana,  fruity, and yeasty. MF medium body nice prickly carb. Warm dry finish. ABV very well hidden. Very good beer.

Opaque gold amber with frothy head. Fruity on the nose with some hops and yeasty note. Taste fruity, malty, biscuity, bready, yeasty spiciness, raisins, bitter just enough. Enjoyable but not very interesting

33 cL bottle at home poured into a Westmalle glass.  Has a vibrant head and amber brown colour.  Looks like a proper beer as an ex-native of Belgium thinks.  Aroma wise its good and full-on, but there are no outstanding notes.  One expects trappist battery acid from the scent.   Its remediated however by a quick tate.  Palate is good it tastes almost like a beer-ified meat stock with some caramel influences.  

Can honestly say this tastes like a beer of its own, i.e. there are few like it.  Having read the blurb above I can now identify the raisins.

Great trappist beer.  Served on tap.  Golden color with white head.  Nose not much different than the Red.  Tastes of malt, raisins, and other fruits.  Very clean finish.  Great but a notch or two below the red and a few more below the blue.
Beautiful trappist beer. Excellent hop aroma, full body with a fizzy mouth feel. Hard to top.
Deep amber/orange with light white head.  Dry, but adequate caramel and nut malt flavours. Really smooth on the palate without the alcohol sting of some tripels.
Had a tap beer. Big white head. Very tastefull. Tastes of yeast and hop. Dry hoppy aftertaste. Nice blond tripel!

28-01-11 Petite bouteille Expi.fin2011, donc environ 3 ans vieillies: Brun pâle, dorée, presque orange, avec une belle mousse blanche asser épaisse et persistante, mais énormément de particules de différentes grosseurs en suspension. Aromes de caramel et de houblon, asser semblable a la westmalle triple. Légèrement sucrée, avec une moyenne amertume et une petite note sure. Tout de même asser bien balancée. Corps moyen avec une texture plutôt croustillante et légèrement épaisse. Asser forte carbonisation. Finale asséchante. Légèrement décue vue le vieillissement en bonne condition de cette bière. Peut-être plus positive dégustée fraiche et jeune?
Had a large wine-corked bottle, poured pompously into my Chimay-approved glass. Tasted incredible and improved my virility after I gave the entire beer to my girlfriend and took advantage of her.

Bottle.

Hazy golden with a large, white and fluffy head. The aroma reminded of a Wheat Beer, spices, banana, yeast, fruit and some perfume. The same in the pleasant and resfreshing taste. Not bad!

Ljus vätska och stort skum.
Doften är lite åt weissbier-hållet med inslag av skumbanan och självklart den belgiske kryddan.
Smaken är mycket trevlig. Vätskan är krämig och fyllig, stora kryddor och kanske en aning het.
Eftersmaken är mycket frisk och fin.

Jag har köpt några flaskor extra och planerar öppna en när de förste solstrålarna börjar värma på balkongen  kanske rent av tillsammans med en mild cigarr.

30cl bottle. cloudy, big head, yellow colour with a slight reddish note. on the nose it is extremely fruity, floral but has some nice bread notes as well as some spicy esters. on the palate it is highly carbonated again, leafy hops, big bready notes and a finish that keeps on giving. excellent brew.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2011 Bottle. Hazy deep orange with a big nice bubbly porous off-white head that leaves thick lacings. Aroma is citrusy yeasty with notes of bitter orange, apples, banana, spice, raisins and lovely flowery fruity hops. Caramel, almond paste and cookie sweetnes. Taste is sweet, slight yeasty and refreshingly hoppy. Orangepeel, dried apples, some banana, fruit candy, marsipan and a good hoppiness. Big and tasteful but refreshing and easy drinking. My favourite chimay. Gorgeous.

Starts with musty barrel aroma and then develops notes of pear and cherries.  Murky light brown with a substantial light tan head.  Flavor has nice tartness and apple, pear, cherry flavors accompanied by a nice hop bitterness.  Finishes very dry with prickly carbonation.  Wonderful beer.
Great. One of my fav tripels. Taste is amazing, and could drink one after the other.

Cloudy pour on the darker side of gold, with a huge, fluffy white head. Lemons everywhere. Oodles of citrus, orange zest, coriander, and spice in the nose. Very light but tangible bitterness in the aroma. Flavor is definitely both fruity and spicy. Lacks the cloying sweetness of many tripels. A touch of booze and bitterness on the finish. Almost an oaky sort of dryness. Mouthfeel is light and delicate for the amount of alcohol. Delicious stuff.

330ml bottle sample purchased at the LCBO. Pours an orange brown, nice off white head, some minor lacing. Aroma is spicy and of some fruit. Taste is of apple, pear, slight raisin, bread and an alcohol aftertaste is a nice little burn. Good stuff.

Ótima Triple. Balanceada e com uma sincronia perfeita. Cor laranja escuro, fosco, espuma branca densa e de boa formação. Bonita. Cheiro floral, adocicado. Uma cerveja forte, complexa. Bem frutada. Densa e refrescante (Compatível?) Acida. Muito Boa.

Its a good looking beer, made to look even better in its tulip glass.  Its a light, hazy, golden orange with a very very steadily sinking just barely offwhite head.  The aroma is a little sour, some pears/green apples a touch of citrus.  The flavor is sour almost a little tart but not in a bad way, in a good way. A very good way
Hazy yellow color with a medium white head. Kind of sweet, kind of spicy. A little alcohol burn in the end. Very good beer!

Bottle; Pour is cloudy golden with a frothy white head initially, dissipates fairly quickly into this Chimay glass. Nice lacing, however. Aromas are dark fruits and sweet breads. This is Belgian. Flavors are surprisingly hoppy, however. Combined with that yeasty note, raisins, pears, belgian sugars  - and you have a fresh, slightly bitter, but sweet brew that seems to work very well.

Slightly hazed golden orange pour, thick white head that forms islands on the beer as it falls.  Soft caramel aroma with hints of spice and bright golden raisin and tropical fruit notes.  Tastes of light caramel with a little spice, apple and pear, more golden raisin and some moderately bitter herbal hops.  A strong beer with a good sense of balance.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2012 Bel colore dorato con buon cappello di schiuma. Aroma principalmente dolce, con lieviti e anche leggero luppolo. In bocca è la classica tripel belga ma con un pò più di classe. Gran bere...

April 2009 bottle.  I was surprised to notice I had not yet rated the white, so I pulled one out of the cellar.  Pours hazy yellow with pillowy white head.  Aroma is belgian yeast, pears and bready.  Taste is sweet with some light bitters.  The finish is very smooth with some warming.
On tap at Mompau in Newark.  Aroma of banana and raisin spice. Taste is sweet but not overwhelming. Alcohol is covered well making this very drinkable.  Just a great beer.
Pours a nice hazy, golden color. Good floral, hoppy aroma.  Somewhat spicy flavor with hint of bread.

Pours a beautiful golden color.  Has one of the most pleasing aromas I have encountered   - spicy with a hint of hops.   Medium, slightly malty body with fruits and spice  texture..   Finishes very pleasantly with a hint of hop bitterness and alcohol.

Light orange color. Hazy. Thick wispy head.  Light color.  Very distinct bread and yeast smell. Some light fruit.  Very malty and breads flavor. Plenty of sweetness. Fruit taste reminds me of apple and banana. Little bit of alcohol is coming through - warmth. Not too much hops. This is more about the malt.  Light to medium body.

Good beer but less than I was expecting, The aroma is even a bit malty, the appearance is a cloudy orange gold with "stuff" floating around.  The taste is a bit bland but nice.  Overall not a bad beer but I was thinking it would be more.
Excellent Belgian beer.  Aroma reveals both banana and spice.  Taste is sweet but not overly like some of the trappist ales.  The alcohol content is masked very well and this is very drinkable.

Found some old ratings on paper that I never posted. pour is a nice head with little lacing over a darker orange body. Aroma is wheat, apricot, sweet fruits and strong alc. Flavor is full of fruits and hops.

The aroma has the characteristics of hay, citrus, and a bit of barnyard fragrances. The beer itself is golden, bit cloudy, with a massive, yellowish long-lasting head. Main tastes are light sweetness and light fruit flavours.  With light body and fizzy carbonation it isnt a very strong beer, I can recommend it for anyone maybe while having a nice Christmas dinner. :)

Very good, bready, cereal, alcohols are present upon first try.  Its very nice, a little bite and spice, good clean flavor, Decent head, and aroma is good, the palate is saturated with flavor and alcohol quickly and then dries to a clean taste again. Overall I really like this strong belgian blonde trippel, white.

33cL bottle: Appearance is medium brown with a large slow fading off white head. Aroma is breaddy and yeast like, with the addition of some spices. Flavor is also slightly breaddy, has some spices and distinct Belgium yeast. Overall an excellent beer out of Belgium as always.
Yeasty, slightly hoppy aroma. Thick, pale head with cloudy, dark copper appearance. Complex taste, fruity, with a hoppy aftertaste and dry finish. Delicious tripel.
A wonderful triple. Great balance of malt and hops. Minimal acidity. A really nice beer

Fantastic ale the flavor literally sweeps you off your feet. For being 8% the alcohol is masked quite well. It has a slight bitter taste to it that leaves a pleasant twang on your palate. The ale its self has a pleasing aroma and has a beautiful amber/gold appearance. I recommend this ale to anyone

Hazy amber with a medium tan head.  Aroma is full of yeast with bready malt, dough, fruit and alcohol.  Effervescent mouth feel, almost champagne like, with plenty of yeast and fruit, light sugar and some alcohol, though it hides it pretty well.  Mild bitterness on the finish.  Not bad.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2011 Tasted on tap at Old Chicagos in Aurora, Colorado. Big white fluffy head that disappears pretty quickly. Hazy light orange body. Aroma is citrusy, wheat-like, and yeasty. Flavor is simiar to most Abbey Tripels- Belgian ale flavor, yeast, citrus fruits, wheat, and light alcohol in the flavor. Finish is fairly sweet. Tasty and enjoyable beer but Ive had a lot better Abbey Tripels. Overrated.
Exceptional ale.  Near-perfect balance between the yeast/grain and the savory bitterness that permeates the finish.  The easiest drinking of the Chimay trio, my personal preference.
Crisp, sparkling, and almost champagne-like. Fairly high in alcohol but doesnt taste like it. Slight bitterness, but not overpowering. Light amber in color.
Surprisingly light and flavorful.  Pours hazy orange with noticeable carbonation.  A pleasant blend of sweet citrus, spices, and bitterness.  Subtle wheat aftertaste.
Bottle. Pours hazy golden with a huge white head. Aroma has notes of fruity hops, some thing sour and yeast. Taste is malt, yeast a hint of sweetness and alcohol.
Vary light and fruity. Very subtle aroma, finishes with refreshing citrus linger.
Pours with almost slightly cloudy with very light head. Nice distinct sweet aroma.  Very nice taste with slight hint of citrus. Smooth and delicate bite, but noticeable. Great beer.

Hazy bright orange. White foamy head.

Aroma is peer, citrus, freash coriander, mild bread flavours and grass. Pleasant.

Taste is spicy and peppery, hay, fruits, rich, black pepper, orange and grapefruit peel.

Slight boozy aftertaste. Aftertaste with bitterness that finish fast.
Aroma of pears/fruit.  Unexpected bitter taste with mild fruits but mostly a malty Hoppy presence.   The odd Chimay out.

Bottle. Hazy golden color, nice creamy head (slightly off white) that lasts long. Aroma is yeasty, some sourness,  fruit and alcohol. Alcohol is also present in the taste, apart from a well balanced bitter-sweetness. Its pleasantly carbonated with a medium body. The finish is a dry alcohol+bitter-sweetness. Okay, but nothing special for me.

Lightly Chilled 33 Cl bottle of Chimay Triple. Served in a Tulip Glass. On Pour has orange to amber color with white frothy head that dissapates quickly. The Aroma is that of a peppery mix of banana, apricot, and Cardamom. Taste is similar and adds a floral nose. Very palatable and finishes with a hint of pepper on the end. Overall great beer.

Tried on bottle from Systembolaget. Aroma is rich and malty. Flavour is a bit roasted with a rich bitterness in the aftertaste, it is hoppy, but not in an American way. Overall this is a very easy beer to like and not as complex as many trappist beers are. I actually preferred this over Chimay Blue. Colour is brownish and quite hazy. The head is tan, very thick and leaves some lacing on the glass.

Transcription of an old BA review from 01-04-2010, with scores adjusted to RB scale. Will re-rate...someday.

The label says best before 2012. Into Chimay calice.
Effervescent ,mostly clear honeyish golden-orange fluid topped with rich white head that retreats until a firm thick lacy coating is left. The scent is a composite of peppery phenolics, aromas of peach /apricot, refined sugar and quite evident spicy alcohol. Somewhat yeasty with peppery phenolics and flavors of peach /apricott incorporated into the malty body balanced by some hops and subdued spicy alcohol. High carbonation is leading into dry finish with prominent bitter aftertaste that seemingly lasts forever. Although the beer seems hoppier in character than most trappist ales, hoppiness is quite shy until the aftertaste phase when reveals itself as an everlasting bitterness. This beer is a shirk which escapes my attempts to evaluate it: aromas and flavors are somehow hard to take hold of. The apparent absence of citrusy esters so typical of a triple and the pronounced dryness remind me more of a golden strong ale than a triple. Sharp-edged,prickly on the palate and rather dry the Chimay White is my least favorite of the three brothers.

Pours out a hazy golden colour with a creamy white head, great retention and ok lacing. Aroma is pretty sweet. Im getting floral hops, candy apple, raisins, and fresh pear. The flavors become accentuated in the mouth, with a taste profile similar to the nose, just a bit more yeasty. A certain nuttiness is also present in the middle, alongside...banana?  Interesting beer, though I cannot say it is a favorite. Its a beer I would give to someone who has never had a Belgian before; a nice starter course for newbs.

On tap at Masons Pub, Huntsville, AL. Pours a pale gold color with a fluffy white head. The aroma is strong and pleasant, with notes of oranges, wheat, and caramel. The flavor is very bitter for a Belgian beer. There is a strong malt backbone and a slight tart taste. The palate is light and silky, and very carbonated. Overall, an interesting tripel, with a lot of elements similar to a witbier. Enjoyable and smooth.

Small bottle (best before date 2011). Cloudy orange body with a decent head. Aroma has ripe fruits and hops. Taste has some pear and honey and they balance the yeast and carbonation well. Dry sweetness followed by a good bitter finish. In my opinion, the best Chimay.

750 ml bottle poured into tumbler, compared side by side with Westmalle Tripel and the rest of the Trappist beers Ive drank tonight. These two beers are #5 and #6 in tonights Trappist tasting. Pours a hazy gold with a large head that dissipates very slowly, leaving a couple centimeters of head and some foamy lace. Retention is awesome. Aroma is woody, cheesy, ripe fruit, citrus powder drink, a bit phenolic, funky; complex. Taste is lightly sweet with no bitterness; could use more flavor--I was expecting more after the aroma. More highly carbonated than the Westmalle, but still just a medium level of it. Medium-high body. Overall, pretty equal to the Westmalle in quality, but definitely different. This was always my least favorite Chimay. Id like to re-rank the red and the blue now.

Une fois versé, le liquide dévoile une robe orangée et voilée par les sédiments.  Un anneau de mousse se dépose pour quelques gorgées.  Le nez est fabuleux, vraiment fabuleux avec des fleurs de houblons aromatiques, des esters fruités (dominés par le citron), de la levure belge et des arômes de poivre doux qui gravitent autour dun maltage fin mais judicieux.  Au goût, le liquide est très convainquant avec son malt en sourdine, sa levure accentuée, son côté floral affirmée, sa fraîcheur fruitée aux notes surettes et son alcool habilement parfumé.  En bouche, le liquide a un corps moyen avec une effervescence appropriée et une texture qui permet une certaine sensation crémeuse.  En finale, les notes amères des houblons saffirment et sont asséchantes.  En résumé, très facile à boire, trop facile à boire

Sampled at Belgian Beer weekend 2010.  I tasted  12+ tripples over three days and this (to me) is the prototype triple. Perfect balance.  Aroma has sour fruit, vinegar  and citrus.  Fluffy mouthfeel. Yeasts are mostly sour atop a base of malts that leaves the impression of a thicker body. I really love the bittered finish.

Pours hazy copper with mountains of lingering head.  Aromas of raisin, berries, orange, bread.  Alcohol is there but not overpowering.  Grassy/floral hops in there too?  The intense bubbliness makes it feel very creamy and chewy.
Another fantastic trappist beer from Chimay.Not so super-malted tasting as the blue one but more fruity.The palate was astonishing and you can feel it in your gums,the thick body.Amazed.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2012 Pours hazy orange-amber with a puffy white head. Aroma of yeast, fruit, some hops and malts. Taste is a touch bitter, but mostly yeast and pale malts. Mildly carbonated and refreshing, finishes with a slight bitterness.

pours a hazy pale orange with a nice white head.  Aroma is yeast and citrus.  Taste is of pale malt, citrus and yeast with a slight hop kick.  Bitter finish.  overall fairly light and subtle but lovely nonetheless.
Bottle. Hazy golden with a white head. Yeasty aroma with some fruit. Taste has malty sweetness and some spices.
Cloudy golden with full white head. Light to medium nose of orange and spice. Full palate is creamy and rich with orange and spice as well as banana and nutmeg. Has a little bite on the finish.

Lourdes into a mug. Appearance is a hazy copper with a thick, fluffy white head. Aroma is of malts and flowers. Taste is very much like a hefeweissen in the coriander and citrus characteristics. Body is a smooth one with a tangy citrus and yeast aftertaste. This is very good.
Bottle; aroma of honey and spice. Taste similar with notes of honey and spice, almost creamy. A good beer but the liked the Chimay Blue and Red much better.
Bottle. Large thick foamy white head over a hazy red-gold body. Aroma-taste: sweet, citrus, coriander, cloves, roses with a somewhat dry finish. Light to medium bodied.

Draft served in trappist glass. Yeasty aroma. Cloudy golden orange. Fluffy white head with plenty of lacing.t aste was sweet then sour then with a biter finish. I loved the texture of this beer: moderate thickness with some slickness. carbonation brings out the bitterness in the finish like trappist ales do.
Has a very typical belgian yeast flavour. Good aroma, Overall tastty beer. Recommended
Small bottle as in the picture. Small fruity aroma, goes down very smooth.
Bottle. Rich bronze color with a white and frothy head. Well balanced with fruit and yeast flavors. Tad bit of caramel and honey. A solid brew.

Smooth is the first thing that comes to mind as I took my first sip. The aromas of yeast lemons and spices  drift up from the tulip. Nice head which disappeared rather quickly but leaves behind some lace. Tastes of yeast and spices gives way to citrus hops and malts. Sweet candied sugars mask the high alcohol well resulting in a soft but warm mouth feel and finish.. I will definitely enjoy another under different circumstances.
Pours hazy leave with medium size dense off white head. Aroma of malt with yeasty undertone. Quite bitter taste with warm alcohol finish.
UPDATED: FEB 17, 2015 Lovely stuff.  Rather dry and crisp beer. Quite tart and a bit citrusy. Serving: Bottle
330ml bottle.  Pours a hazy orange with a small head.  Aroma is nutty yeast, banana and bubblegum.  Taste is nutty and yeasty with some bubblegum.  Nutty, dry finish.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2010 0.33L bottle. Pours cloudy gold, a bit on the richer side. Thick white head laces the sides of the glass. Very nice. Mild spice mixed with high-fruit notes dominate the aroma. Slight bitter citrus on the back of the tongue. Easy to drink.

Appearance:  cloudy peanut butter brown with a rich, foamy head.  Aroma:  roasted butterscotch toffee, raspberries (?), raisins and white wine. Taste:  mellow, slightly bitter hops balancing a medium sweet maltiness.  Finish: long, smooth and dry, with slight bitterness and sweetness in equal measure.  Notes:  Not bad.  Need to try again with more time to savor it.

Pours yellow/orange with white head, aroma is some nice clove, banana, bit of other spice and some biscuit.  Taste is spicy up front, leading to a nice mix between the banana and biscuit, with a sweet and slightly bitter finish.  Alcohol only on the exhale, a very nice tripel.
Yet another great brew from Chimay, this one seems to do well with guests that have not ventured far into beerland.

Bottle from Barleywine.dk @ 16.9.2010.
Pours golden to light copper. Massive long lasting head.
Yeast aroma dominant. Maybe a hint of banana.
Medium body, high carbonation. Lightly warming with hints of pepper.

Overall a nice beer, even if i like the Chimay Red better.

On draft at Firewaters in AC.  Pours a deep golden yellowish orange colour with a frothy white head. Pleasant citrus aroma.  Tastes of caramel malts citrus hops, cloves, pepper and hints of bubblegum, and banana.

330 ml bottle from LCBO (aged a few years).  Pours a cloudy deep orange/gold with good-sized, lasting white head and lots of floaties.  Aroma of yeast, fruit (esp banana) and light spices.  Taste is initially sweet and fruity, with some spice and yeast and a definite sourness and bitterness in finish while still retaining a nice fruity character.  Alcohol is very subtle after aging.  Quite good.

330 ml bottle @ home. Rated @ 21.3.2009.
Orange colour with a foamy white head. Orange, banana, spices and caramel malts on the nose. Sweet caramel flavour with a hint of banana. Medium bodied with a sour and dry finish. Very solid. Better than Red but worse than Blue.

Despite a slow, deliberate pour, a very thick, foamy head develops on top of the dense orange colored ale. The aroma is quite inviting, with notes of banana, yeast, and spice. The flavor is largely a continuation of the aroma, with a dry fruity sweetness and spicy overtones. This flavor is somewhat hidden by the high amount of effervescence, but this feature also hides the flavor of 8% alcohol. Overall, though, this is a very good, very drinkable tripel.
Yellow and hazy - good head.  Light aroma of yeast and fruit, but the flavor has a bit of fruit to it too along with just a bit of tartness.  The finish is clean.  My favorite Chimay.

bottle aug 24. more of a yeast smell than im use to but still ok. light golden color with off white head. the taste is most compelling part. hints of yeast and fruit especially banana but not to much like a hefeweizen. overall very good.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2010 Aroma: caramel, resin, floral.
Appearance: golden, orange, hazy, sparkling, frothy, white foam.
Taste: medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour.
Palate: medium body, creamy, lively, astringent.
Overall: Crafted to perfection, this is the gold standard for the abbey tripel style. Of the three styles of Chimay, this one is my favorite. The sweetness and bitterness are balanced, so that neither one is overpowering. Belgian ales dont smell or taste like beer in the conventional sense. Rather, it is as elegant as drinking wine, with an 8% alcohol content to match.

Drunk it twice: once from a 33 cl bottle and once from tap, also 33 cl. Hazy golden coloured beer with small white head, that lasts a bit on top of the beer. Aroma is light sweet, fruity (citrus) and grainy. Taste is light sweet and malty at first, then hops come to the foreground, together with the fruitiness and some light spices on the background give the beer an even better and deeper taste. Light bittersweet finish. Great beer with nice complexity in a great pallet!

On draught @ The Thirsty Dog Tavern in Buckhead.  Poured a clear golden color with a small white head.  Aroma was heavy on the belgian yeast characteristics.  Lots of banana, light clove and bubble gum.  Flavors were very yeasty, somewhat spicy and had a tinge of sweetness in the finish.  Other than that it was quite dry.  Alcohol was unnoticeable, very drinkable.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2010 Pours a clear offwhite head with a hazy copper/amber body. Tastes of banana, pineapple, raisins, honey, hops and yeast. I really enjoy this beer. Very good! One of my absolute favorites.

A-pours a murky dark amber color with tons of an off white fluffy head that leaves a decent lace.

S-a fair amount of belgian yeast hits the nostrils, notes of banana, a strong malt aroma, dark fruits, plums and raisins.

T-the belgian yeast is much lighter allowing for more flavors to come through, light banana, a fair amount of peppery spice to it, dark dried plums and faint touch of raisin towards the back.  the finish adds dry grass and spicey herbal notes with a light bitterness.

M-the feel is lively and active, high carbonation, prickly on the tongue and back of the throat, light body, crisp semi dry finish.

D-the flavor is quite good, the nose fell a little short as it was dominated by yeast and malt sweetness.  a complexity not seen in many tripels and the balance that makes a beer great.  this is a darn good beer!
Pours a hazy pale peach color, nose is fruity, nice belgian esters, body is full, loads of toffee, peach, stone fruits, and a good booze kick.

Pours hazy golden with huge tanned head. Aroma is of citrus and caramel, yeast, bananas, grapes and sweet raisins. Flavour is very much the same. Balanced lean on palate. Finishes with sweet, but still dry, malty and yeasty aftertaste.

Golden, apricot color with thin head. Sweet, floral nose with spicy notes. Malty intro with a moderately carbonated palate followed by a somewhat bitter, citrusy finish with a touch of alcohol warmth.

2009 Bottle in the hotel - Pours a hazy golden with a massive sandy head...aroma is citrus and toffee, sweet burnt sugar and raisin...flavour is similar, very light bitterness, dry caramel malt, spicy dough and yeasty on the finish...
750 ml bottle a orange yellow colored beer with a white head aroma oranges caramel malts yeast and citrus taste malts fruits caramel oranges spices and some hop

"My God....its full of stars!!"  

Yeah, Im stealing a quote from Stanley Kubricks movie 2001--but man, this ale is out-of-this-world good.  Inter-galactic good.  This was poured from a small bottle, and was purchased as a sampler pack from World Market, on clearance.  A bottle each of the Red, Blue, and White with a Chimay goblet for $9.99.  It was my first Chimay White ever, and it rocked my world, and several neighboring star systems.  Wonderful aroma, beautiful appearance, and the taste...oh the taste.  Now I (kinda) know what a crack addict feels like.  I want more of the smooth, silky Trappist Triple, and I want it NOW.
My favorite Chimay. Pours a nice golden hazy dark yellow/tan with frothy head. Sweet and spicy smells mingle. Taste is smooth, fresh, deep; good stuff
Very strange tasting, a bit citrus like.  Mouthfeel is not smooth, left an uneven coating on my tongue.  Finish is awful, bitter and strange.
Wasnt bad.. Wasnt great.  Thought it was overrated.  Like a hybrid between a tripel and an IPA.

Light amber with some haze.  Head collapses to "islands" of foam quickly.  There is faint malt, but definitely a pronounced hop spiciness - the flavor is more of the same - complex hop/yeast spiciness with just a trace of malt - very dry.

12 oz bottle, pours a cloudy honey w/ a foamy quickly-dissipating head, aroma is cereal malt w/ some spicy hop and caramel, flavor is light malt up front w/ spicy hop & carbonated bit at finish, not what I expected: anticipated more rummy/caramel/burnt sugar for the style, a little overcarbonated as well, slightly disappointed

Poured from a 11.2 oz. bottle into a Chimay goblet.

Appearance: Pours a hazy dark golden color with orange highlights. Has a 2 finger fluffy white foamy head which dissipates fairly quickly. No lacing.

Smell: Malt and yeast dominate with floral and hoppy notes and very light hints of fruit.

Taste: Malt flavor up front with a hints of baked bread in the middle. Finishes with a bit of bitter lemon zest.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a high amount of carbonation up front. Dry finish.

Drinkability: Fairly high drinkability for a beer with an ABV of 8%.

Overall: Id recommend giving this a shot if youve never tried it before. Its not something Id seek out, but wouldnt object to trying again in the future.
Bottle. Hazy golden body with a big fluffy white head. The aroma is spices, coriander, fruit and caramel. The flavour is sweet malty, some spices, fruit and caramel. Some banana as well.

Bottle. Thick fluffy white head, hazy amber body. Excellent head retention. Sweet caramel aroma, wheat, honey, spruce, floral. Sweet, with slight bitter notes. Medium bodied, silky mouthfeel, slight bitter finish.

Pours a cloudy burnt-orange with a light, sudsy head. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Bananas, plums, apricots. Flavor is hoppier than expected, but nicely balanced. Toasty fruit still, but very smooth. Not the best trappist, but still damn good.

A beer that surely deserves its status as a classic ale. This is less fruity and sweet than many tripels, with notes of straw and earth that evoke a saison. It gives you the styles characteristic pillowy head, though, as well as a golden body that fades to yellow around the perimeter of your stemware. Perhaps as a result of flavors that are more elemental than those of most tripels, this is drinkable to the point of quaffable for an ale of this potency. A great Friday afternoon aperitif both for dinner and for the weekend to follow.
(bottle) cloudy gold with medium white head; aroma initially sour and citrus then spice; balanced, dry, rather austere flavour; not sure why it is so highly rated because it is quite unimpressive
This is not like any beer Ive ever had before. Its kind of light, but the unique carbonation that gives it a great bite. Aroma is nice, but not very noticeable.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2011 On tap at BXL.  Pours a gently hazed gold, orange and brown highlights, and a medium sized beige head.  Soft caramel and toast, a little bit of alcohol.  Medium bodied, creamy and smooth.  Nice and smooth, toast, malt, and a bit of alcohol.  Warming gentle alcohol and spicy yeast on the finish.

Interestingly I rated this again forgetting that I had rated it before, and came out with exactly the same score.  Bottle, aged about two years.  Figured it was about time that I finally got around to rating the Chimays so, snow day rating while moving things about the house seemed the perfect time.  Pours a hazy dirty orange brown with a large off white head.  Boozy old candied citrus, oxidized malt and caramel candies, with a bananas foster note about it all. Medium bodied, sweet and full of warm bread and jam, toast and warming fruits.  Slow toast bitterness on the finish.  Yummy.

Poured from bottle into pint glass - huge foaming head - high carbonation - blonde/light brown coloring - nice balance of hops and malt flavor - very nice beer

\

Pours a hazy gold color with a short lived white head.The aroma is a banana and citrus.The flavor is of sweet fruit, slight hop bitterness with a tinge of alcohol.The finish is clean and the aftertaste is a tiny bit bitter.Overall a very good brew from Belgium.

fruity and yeasty aroma like uncooked bread dough and burnt caramel..opague amber color and pure white head..plenty of both head and lace..taste is sweet there is a peppery bitterness that balances a very fruity(apples,pineapples and burnt sugar) maltiness..all flavors clear and intense,but not an easy drinker..on the other hand i fifnished my bottle pretty fast..point of reference..tastes KIND of like dogfish head Midas touch with more carbonation

(Bottle 0,33l)
Strong fruit, light yeast aroma. Hazy with floating bits, orange color. Medium white head. Light sweet, light sour, fruit flavour. Light fizzy. Sticky texture. Full body. Light bitter, astringent, alcohol warm (but not offensive alcohol taste) finish.

(330ml bottle).  Pours hazy yellow-orange with white chunky head.  Aroma of apple and fruit.  Flavor is sweet and bitter (heavily hopped for a belgian beer).  medium bodied.  Finish is bitter with some yeastiness.  Great beer and my gateway beer into Triples and trappist beers.  An all-time favorite of mine.
Hummm, my review basically disappareed... Well.. Its an extremely well-balanced beer, of the spicy/caramel variety. If it would have been sligtly less carbonated...
On tap. Pours a hazy gold with a thick, rocky head. Aromas of fruit and yeast; flavor is about the same, with a slight bitterness in the finish...I love this stuff!

World Cup beer tasting at Lazy Boy Saloon beer #15.  Final beer of the tasting which tried its best to leave pleasant taste in my mouth despite the ending of USA vs ghana.  hazy beer with visible sentiment.  malty, doughy, and some caramel.  i never pick up chimay at store and not sure why.
caramel, bread, alcohol, cheese, smoke, golden, amber, hazy, frothy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, oily feel, lively, bitter, long finish,

Draft at Toad in the Hole. Translucent orange with diminishing soapy head. Mellow cedary aroma. Flavor is woody and faintly plasticky. Finishes very dry with pleasant rosemary and berry notes. Spice and phenolics dominate any malty elements. Not much in the way of body.

Pours a hazy light yellow brown with a carbonated light white head.  Aroma is fruit, alcohol, bread and yeast.  Taste has a nice carbonated mouth feel that fades to a delicate dried fruit, banana, bread, yeast and spice flavor.  A tremendous beer.

Si presenta con un bel colore oro antico e una schiuma pannosa ed abbondante.I profumi sono intensi ed eleganti:luppolo,spezie e note fruttate.Al palato dopo un attacco di morbido e dolce continua in una corsa asciutta e maltata con un tocco di acidità,per terminare in un finale decisamente luppolato.

Pours out lightly orange-amber coloured. Very big white head, that holds nice, and sticks to the glass. Hoppy-yeast, lightly sour aroma. Slightly oily substance, hoppy, spicy and some nuts-taste comes up.

Pours a very nice slightly murky golden color with lots of fluffy white foam on the head.  Virtually no lacing on the glass as you drink.

Aroma is slightly sweet and yeasty - I think Im getting some light caramel and nutty scents as well.

The flavor is remarkably well balanced.  This doesnt have any of the overwhelming yeastiness that I often pick up from other Belgian beers.  There is a bit of fruitiness to it with some slightly tart notes, but overall it is incredibly balanced, well carbonated, and drinkable.

~12 oz bottle. golden color, full white head, lively carbonation with a lot floating around in there. yeasty, bready aroma with a sharp underlying aroma of hops. the taste is doughy too with a nice hop bitterness in the background and finish and a very light taste of fruitiness in the finish.

(25.4 oz bottle)  I christened my new Chimay glass with the home brew.  Poured a hazy complexion from bottle fermentation (nice). Great malt and hop balance. A pleasure to drink.  The benchmark for Abbey Tripel.

I know Ive had this before, but I guess that I never remembered to rate it...

I had it on tap at Selmas in Rancho Santa Margarita, CA. The flavor was yeasty, with some hops. There was very little fruitiness that I would have expected.

Pours an amber colour with a small white head, slightly hazy with visible sediment. The aroma is of earthy hops, herbs, slight spice and fruit with a strong yeast scent as well. The taste is nice; sweeter up front and noticeably more bitter towards the finish. Full bodied, somewhat creamy mouth feel and lively carbonation. Overall a very nice tripel, good beer.

330ml bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours hazy, brownish-golden with a thick, lingering off-white head.  Aroma mainly of yeast, but the hops are noticeable which is not true for a lot of triples.  Hints of spice as well.  Initially tastes like spicy bread, with notes of hops.  The finish has a smooth yeast flavor with some alcohol mixed in.  Full bodied.  One of the best triples Ive had

(draught) opaque golden yellow with a lasting oily and creamy head. Nose of hay, grass, candi sugar and spicy hops. Taste is herbal, white pepper, grass, Candi sugar, spices. Oily and creamy finish. Quite drinkable with no hint of alcohol.

330 mL bottle.  Pours deep golden with a nice off-white head.  Aromas of honey, sweet red apple, biscuit, and bits of cloves and other spices.  Flavor has biscuit, apple, honey, grassy hops, and some earthiness and spices.  Nice bitter hop finish.  Very well done, a great beer.

Small bottle.  Hazy light golden beer.  Interesting notes of leafy and citrusy hopping dominate over notes of sweetness and earthly cereals.  Some floral notes also present.  No spicyness makes this one very pleasing.  I could have this one regularly if I had not to pay 11,95$ each bottle, in a restaurant...

Bottle.

A - Hazy golden orange color, somewhat like a dark cream soda. Fairly large, foamy, creamy white head. Decent retention with a thin patchy bubbly lacing.

S - Fairly typical Tripel aroma with some peachy, apricot, and other golden fruit. Good amount of orange citrus and floral aroma. Sweet honey and malt aroma also present with some yeast and spice.

T - Starts with an apple and pear taste with some light pale malt in the background. This gives way to more of a peach and apricot fruitiness. Mid to late sip some floral and earthy hops come out along with some spice (coriander, clove, and pepper). Underneath all that is a slight candi sugar/honey sweetness and some Belgian yeast. Touch of alcohol taste on the finish.

M - Medium body with a lot of carbonation. Warming, tingly feel.

D - Decently drinkable. A bit more spiced/hot and less sweet and fruity than others in the style. These dont overpower the palate, but they definitely make their presence felt. Pretty well balanced and could drink another just fine.

Notes: Vintage 2009. More spiced/herbed/hot version of a Tripel with less fruity/peachy sweetness. Its a good beer and enjoyable to drink but it isnt really my favorite Tripel. Its a tasty beer, and I would have it again, but I dont know if I would ever crave it, or really feel the need to drink another. Definitely worth trying though, just didnt wow me and wasnt my favorite interpretation of the style.

I kinda expected more from this one but at least its drinkable.  Piney hops nose with a thick foamy head.  Hazy orange amber color.  Flavor was kinda spice & minty hops upfront with yeasty cereal notes playing a part in the background.

Poured a hazy orange/amber with a large white head.  Aroma of fruit, malt, yeast, and spices.  Taste is very smooth with good malt flavors and spices.  Slightly fruity.  Finish is spicey.  Good balance and body for being 8%.
UPDATED: JUL 7, 2011 Bottle. Cloudy golden orange with nice big head. Aroma yeast with orange. Taste citrus with yeast. Nice beer.

11.2 oz. bottle from Kellers IGA.  Pours a cloudy orange-gold with a lot of visible yeast sediment and a small eggshell white head.  Aroma of Belgian yeast, candi sugar, apricot, straw, honey, caramel malts, and white raisins.  Flavor of Belgian yeast, candi sugar, caramel malts, honey, apricot, straw, hops, white raisins, and just a touch of warming alcohol late.  Medium-bodied, with really soft carbonation and a soft, malty mouthfeel.  I give this the slight edge over the Red because it feels so nice in the mouth.
.33l bottle.  Pour cloudy gold with average off white head.  Mild aroma of hops and yeast.  Not an overpowering tripel.  Not as complex as the Red and Blue.  Nice.

Pours blonde with a big, super-volatile white head (for gods sake dont shake the bottle at all). Nose is classic (and good) abbey tripel: belgian yeast, hops, coriander, and sweet wheat malt. The taste is full bodied and all of the flavors in the nose come out on the palate, along with a little bitter cirtus and what almost resembles green apples. Finish is long and bittersweet. A very well made beer.
33cl bottle. Great head. Aroma of pepper and resinous hops. Long dry bitter finish. Very fine.

Bottle 33cl. A yellow hazy ale with huge white head. Smell is very hoppy and spicy. Aroma are on fruit (blackcurrant) and spices such as cloves and wheat malt. Hop character is intensive on the bitter side, some dry hopping taste. Also citrus and yeast notes. Not bed but a bit too bitter, quite dry.

Thanks to hudsonphotog for sharing this bottle. 

A world classic that I had never gotten around to reviewing. The beer pours a hazy light copper color with a white head. The aroma is orange citrus with some pepper and Belgian yeast. The flavor is citrus fruit with quite a few spices and Belgian yeast. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A classic example of the style that never disappoints.

my final bottle of chimay, left the tripel for last. Was Enjoyed in my Trappist glass. The color was a orange a yellow hazy beer with a thin head. The aroma is flowery with yeast spice and hints or orange. The taste is a mild bitter ad sweetness is overriding but still gentle. The best part of this is the texture which is a bit thick with soft carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a hazy mid-brown, with a pillowy, lasting head. The nose is very sweet, with possibly a touch of fortified desert wine, tokay perhaps. This impression continues upon tasting the beer. With just moderate carbonation, and only the slightest hop bitterness, the overwhelming botrytis and raisin flavours give this a taste very similar to a tokay or botrytis semillon. The hops are marginally more pronounced in the finish, but it is still far too sweet. The ingredients list for this beer does include added sugar; significantly it comes above the hops, which are not in fact actual hops, but merely an extract. Hence, it is hardly surprising that this tastes far more like a sticky wine than a beer. I must confess, I am disappointed by this. Having read the reviews, and heard good things about Trappist abbey ales, I was expecting something pretty excellent, and this just isnt. It is passable, but it really isnt that great. I guess it makes a good argument for secularism really. It certainly makes the separation of church and beer seem a good idea.

This completes my ratings of the red, white, and blue Chimays.  It provides a sizable, fizzy, foamy head like a good Belgian should.  Cloudy medium brown color.  Pretty light aroma with some grass, citrus, and yeasty funk.  Malty, medium bodied, and crisp.  The hops contribute a bitter shimmer that lingers into the aftertaste.  Earthy, malty and affectionately bitter.  Unlike most abbey ales this has no esters to speak of.  A good brew whose quality is pretty close to the other Chimays.

Bottle. Pours a hazy amber beer with a medium white head. Nose is of hops, orangepeels, spice. Taste is fruity, citrus, hops, yeast. Sweet in the beginning, bitter in the middle, kind of spicy dry aftertaste. Good beer!

Prefer the blue over the white for Chimay.  Had this on tap at a local brewpub and was a .ittle overwhelmed by the sweet alcohol taste.  While I detected some sweet, dried fruits in both the nose and taste (dates, prunes, apricot), it just didnt do it for me.  The head was relavily thick and the palate was thick and creamy.

Bottled sample. Pale gold in colour with strong carbonation. Aromas are of mild coriander, pilsner malt, spicy yeast, and booze. Farily basic pilsner malt and spicy yeast combo in the mouth, with maybe a hint of under ripe orchard fruit. Light bodied and drinkable, if somewhat uncomplicated.
Pour is nice amber gold with foamy white head. Nose and taste is sweet raisins, molasses, beet sugar. Rated 7/1/02
On tap at Redbones in Boston. Clear light amber color with very nice off-white head and lots of lace. Impresive malt character, slight hop bitter. Nice lingering, slightly bitter aftertaste.

Had from bottle.  Pours orange-yellow with slight haze, good carbonation, and small to medium head.  Aromas of citrus, spice, malts, banana, and caramel.  Taste is complex mixing the caramel malts with a good hop citrus and nice spiciness to balance it all out.  Very well done, easy to drink triple.  Those monks know what theyre doing.
11 ounce bottle-gold pour-white head-aroma and taste of fruit,woody, -super smooth finish

From bottle poured into Trappist glass.  This beer is not as good as its big brother (Blue) or even its other brother (Red).  It lacks aroma...it has no noticeable qualities except a faint trace of hops.  The appearance is nice, especially in a Trappist glass.  The taste is nice, but not as complex as the other Chimay brews.  Has a good mouthfeel with a nice finish...definitely refreshing.  Overall it is a good beer, but not the best from Chimay. 3.8

Had it in its proper Chimay Chalice at the Pub Italia in Ottawa. Pours a gorgeous hazy golden-amber colour with a nice off-white head, which is creamy and has heavy retention. Also, beautiful foamy lacing. The aromas are fruity and has touches of Belgian yeast. Trying to guess of the fruits, I would say, pears, apples and citrus ones. The taste starts sweet with a fruity and floral flavour, then gets bitter in the middle, to then finish half smooth, half dry with a slight bitterness in the aftertaste. Got notes of caramel somewhere in there. Just plain delicious, especially for a fruit beer lover like me. This has to be my favorite Trappist brew so far. Love it !!

Nice golden amber body with a dusting of a pillowy white head.  Aromas of toast with some yeasty sourness.  Mouth feel is initially rather carbonated and semi-light.  Flavors of toast, sweet hay and some sour yeast.  Finishes off with a nice bitter addition.  Overall rather enjoyable.

Pours a beautiful hazy, copper-orange with a nice white head, Aromas of yeast, fresh cut grass, hops, Dry in the mouth, herbal and, peppery, some citrus, grapefruit.. Medium bodied with mild carbonation. Dry, bitter finish. Excellent abbey triple.
33cl bottle. Overall, a good beer, but not comparable to its bigger brothers to me.

bottle pour to trappist glass.  Pours a hazy golden orange.  Fruit and spice in the nose, green apple as the ale airs out.  Again, fruit and spice in the flavor with hops and bitter rounding out a medium body but quite full for a Tripel.  Good carbonation.  A solid brew.
Pours a hazy orangeish golden with a white head. Aroma is spicy, fruity, and yeasty. Flavor starts sweet and fruity, peppery spice, with a bitter hop finish.

Shared with friend at Melograno, São Paulo, Brazil. Poured from small bottle into the trademark Chimay glass. Color is amber-gold, slightly hazy. Fairly good head formation, with lively carbonation visible. Evident lacing on the wall of the glass as you drink it. Smells typical belgian ale, fruity, spicy. Medium bodied on the palate, with a moderate to strong bitterness in the finish. Considering the high ABV (8%), it is quite smooth and does not taste of alcohol as strongly as I expected. A very colorful experience. Id drink it again. Too bad its such an expensive little treat...

A- Translucent golden yellow body with 1/2 finger creamy white head. Great head retention-lasted through the entire glass. Leaves plenty of lacing behind. Lots of tiny bubbles can be seen rising to the top giving this tripel a very champagne-like appearance. Tiny yeast flakes can be seen suspended within the body.

S- Grapes dominate the nose. Behind the grapes is a balance of spicy yeast, floral hops, and citrus, peppery spices, and alcohol.

T- This flavor is full and complex. Sweet fruitiness of grapes and citrus is upfront-but is not dominant as the nose suggests. It is very well balanced with a background of spicy belgian yeast. Spices and the taste of floral hops present themselves for the finish but quickly disappear. Sweet, bready yeast lingers with a very low alcohol after burn.

P- Light carbonation and medium weight body. Smooth and creamy.

O- This was a very delicious brew but after one I was ready to move on to something else. This was excellent and my first Trappist beer. I will definitely have this one again. I even bought myself a Chimay chalice to enjoy it in at home.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 08-21-2007 16:53:01
On tap.  Nose is slightly sweet with raisins, spice, lighter malts, yeast.  Taste is lots more spiciness, slight hoppy bitterness.  Fairly dry overall.  Decent tripel.
Pours amber with a billowy white head. Solid aroma of hops, spice, and some light fruit. Flavor is much the same with a bitter band-aid taste.

Bottle to Trappists glass pours murky dark yellow with small white head.  Nice lacing.  Taste a bit lacking compared to other of the better Belgians, but a pretty typical fruity flavor otherwise.  Palate medium body.  alcohol well hidden.  Finish a bit bitter and long.  Overall nice but theres better out there.  Id drink it again though.
Pours from a bomber with a huge billowy head. Taste/aroma is like a typical high quality tripel, but leaves an unpleasant bitter after taste. It might be better with some aging.
Pours hszy orange.  Belgian yeast, candy sugar, banana, and yeast.  Hops in the finish,  totally awesome
A nice Trappist ale.  Tastes almost like a Wit, but with a Trappist twist.  What are you waiting for? GO GET ONE!

In goblet at the Yard House. Nice golden/amber color with a minimal/thin white head. Aroma of fruits and herbal hops with some spices. Goes down real smooth and refreshing. Tastes mildly of orange, but more of slight pine notes and spices. Tasty, but I really want to try the Bleue.
Pours a hazy gold with great soft beige head. Nose is fruity with some spices. Flavour is light sweet with spice hoppy finish. Good tripel
Bottle. Golden pour with a healthy white head on top. Aroma of fruit, yeast. Tastes of vanilla, yeast, spice, grapefruit, bitter/sweet. Very Belgian, really good on tap when Ive had it.
Sour. That sones it up. Typical gent belgin flavour dominated by a sour finish.

Honey and fruits in the aroma, together with a bit of alcohol. Looks really beautiful in the glass but lacks a bit in taste and palate. It has alot of honey, but it hasnt the fullness and thickness of its big brothet Chimay Bleu. But altogether a very nice beer.
33 cl bottle. Golden body with white head. Flavour is malt, sweet, yeast and hops.

330 mL bottle from the LCBO, poured in a branded Trappist glass. Pours cloudy orange-amber with a tall, frothy tan head. A few fine particles accumulated near the stem. Head has good retention and leaves some lace. On the nose, aromas of yeast and flowers, with grape and a hint of spice. Flavour is moderately sweet throughout, with notes of grape and some pepper and clove. Alcohol comes through. Finish is moderate and bitter. On the palate, medium in body with a smooth, creamy texture and lively carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice brew, but it does not reach the complexity of Chimay Bleue or Rouge. 2010-03-27
A wery well balanced and near to perfection Tripple, for me only beaten by westmalle and Westwleteren

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2010 Bouteille de 330ml achetée à la LCBO, bue dans un calice Chimay. Arôme houblonnée presque de houblon pellet, Bouche mordante, houblonnée, un peu sucrée, couleur blonde-dorée claire, Quelle bonne bière..

Aroma is fruity with a spicy tartness and a little yeast. A typical Belgian aroma. A deep yellow color with light, white head and slight lacing. Flavor is of banana, clove with a touch of bitterness throughout and some alcohol. Its smooth with light carbonation and a slight bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden orange with a thick foamy head.  Aroma of yeast, cloves, malt and mild hops.  Tastes like candy upfront followed by a nice hoppy finish.  Just really fresh tasting.  Nicely carbonated, not overdone, incredibly smooth.  I found this to be pretty simple, but it really has something special.  Even at the high ABV it went down too well.
Draft. Pours golden with a white head. Flavor is sugar sweetness with some yeasty notes a pinch of hops. Excellent.

On tap at the Saucer in San Antonio.  Pours a slightly hazy, light golden body with a sticky ivory head.  Nose is fruity, yeasty, some spices (clove) and a hint of vanilla.  Flavor is light cloves/spicy, yeasty, lightly sweet and some alcohol.  Active carbonation and a medium/full mouthfeel.  Slightly peppery in the very end.  Archetypal.  Great!!
Light gold color with large head. Flavor and aroma are strong with citrus notes, floral hops and light fruitiness. Very good

Big ole 1pt 9.4 Fl. Oz. Deep amber bearing fragments pushed all over by a copious yet light carbonation with a laced cotton head. The nose pleases with smooth banana, spices (clove), touch of vanilla, sweet caramel, undertones of zesty hops. My mouth is telling me a story of spices (coriander), slight alcohol poking through, banana, touch a caramel, slight bread, with added undertones of those zesty hops. An inviting triple but not over the top.
One of my favorite tripels. Well balanced aroma and flavor between malts,hpo and yeast. Fruits as orange, grapes and some spicies. Long lasting finale, dry and fruity.

750ml bottle, Present from Mark, Trappist and tulip glass.    Hazy orange with thick density of variable sized particles, large slightly off white foamy and creamy head mostly diminishing, good lacing.  Amazing complex array of aromas which keep varying as it warms - malty (honey, caramel, white bread)  fruity (very apricot, vinous, citrus - orange, banana), yeasty (cheese, earthy, and dough), spicy (ginger, pepper, clove).   Moderately sweet initially with moderate to heavy bitter finish.   Medium body, creamy texture, lively tingly carbonation, finish is long dry bitter orange alcoholic and very peppery and spicy.
In every aspect thoroughly enjoyable. Best enjoyed with friends that appreciate fine beer, almost too much of a good thing to drink on my own.

Caramel aroma, quite malty yet not overpowering. Cloudy amber appearance with a minimal head. Definite bitter taste but not unappealing due to the light/medium quality of it. 
Lively, lightly carbonated palate with a longer finish to it. Overall a fun beer that while complex, is not overpowering. Definitely recommended.

Amber/hazel pour, medium off white head.
Aroma of fresh hops, quite citrusy and floral. Some fruits as well. Very nice.
Very strong and bitter hops flavour, evolving to a yeasty fruity sweetness.
Very nice.
Bottle. Head is thick and white. Smell is earthy, hoppy, yeasty. This is a slow sipper. Taste is complex, fruity. Plums? Very good beer.
Bottle 330 ml.Cloudy orange color with big white head.Aroma light sweet and fruity.Nice bitter finish. Good beer.
Off tap from the Press,citrus, herbs, golden, minimal head, white foam, cloudy.

Provdatum: 2009-02-23 
Vitt krämigt skum, Ljus siraps färg.
Doft: Bröd, lite jäst, sötma.
Mild brödsmak, fudge (sötma) 
Anteckningar: Goa grejor

Pours a opaque cider color with a nice thick foamy beige head.  Aroma is a mix of sweet earthy malts and spices.  Taste was a mix of sweet malts, some alcohol, and a mild bitterness.  Good thickness, decent carbonation.  As a beer, very drinkable.  HOwever, its a bit pricey and would probably only buy it sparingly.
Bottle. Pours hazy orange with large foamy head. Aroma is faintly lightstruck, clove, orange peel, Belgian yeast. Flavor is slightly bitter, a bit skunked, clove. Fizzy mouthfeel.

My, my this is good stuff.  Second from my gift pack from Bill C.  Bottle to Trappist glass, of course.  Pours golden and opaque with thick white head.  I get alcohol and banana bread.  Taste is fruity sweet, but not overpowering at all.  Palate is as well balanced as the Blue, but not as chewy, finish is simply divine, which is what a  monk brew should conjure up.
opaque orange/amber body. short, quickly dissipating off-white head. mild belgian hoppiness. a little too sweet for my likeing. miold bitterness. with a thin feel.

Smells adorable and has a very complex  combination of taste sensations, which change over time. Starts from sweet, with bits of raisins, rapidly to a quite intense hoppy part on the back of the tongue, to end with some bittersweet tastes after a while, with hints of cocoa.
12 oz bottle from Princetons.  Cloudy orange pour with a big white head.  Strong yeasty aroma with a bit of funk.  Flavor is dry and hoppy with small notes of fruit.  Finish is also dry and hoppy.

Hazy honey coloured, with a thick creamy head. Spicy aroma with a hops tinge. Moderately carbonated. Sweet and fruity initially, very quickly becomes bitter. After taste hangs around. If I had to fault it, maybe a little too bitter, but overall a very nice beer.

Another Trappist classic, the Chimay Blanc (White) is a tripel which is, first and foremost among the most drinkable of all the tripel beers. It is fruity, sprouting with funky yeasts and hops, while still retaining the sweetness level needed for almost anyone to "get into the groove". Because this is a groovy Trappist beer. I can only imagine the monks getting out on a bright summer day, praising the Lord as they collect the hops and malts to break out this brew. It is mild, yet heavy on the palate - just to remind you of its 8% ABV which couldve been easily ignored otherwise. Really tasty and a great introduction to the world of triples - or Trappist beers in general. People say the Westmalle Tripel is the original tripel (and therein lies an expectation of greatness), but this is way better in my view.

If you ever want to sound like a beer snob simply drop the word Trappist into conversation and youll be immediately dubbed a connoisseur by anyone within earshot. Of course, this really only works if the persons hearing that word know that Trappist beers are often ranked among the best of the best of the best beers in the world, and as such they are for discriminating tastes only (or so the hegemony would have us believe).I think its a shame that a product with a rich, complex palate is something to be frowned upon by the mainstream (this is why I believe the average person prefers drinkability to genuine satisfaction  but thats a subject for another sermon). For all the people that would think that way I would point them to Chimay White. This is an authentic Belgian Trappist beer that is indeed rich and complex. However, what separates it from most brews of the style is how drinker-friendly it is. This is a tasty, smooth beer that masks its potency extremely well. You dont have to be a connoisseur to enjoy it, just someone that likes a delicious beer.APPEARANCE AND AROMABeing the beer geek that I am I poured a 750ml bottle of Chimay White into my official Chimay chalice and was surprised the beer produced a thick layer of off-white, spongy head. The body is bright orange but extremely hazy, although no sediment is present. Carbonation is noticeable, but is obscured due to the foggy appearance.The aroma is rather sweet and fruity  like a basket of peaches and nectarines. I also get a slight floral scent from the hops and some hints of spice (probably clove) from the yeast and malts. Despite its potency, alcohol is not detectable in the nose at all.TASTEI have had a few North American-style tripels before and while I enjoyed the complexity to their palates, I was a little off-put by the intensity of their palate. Chimay White is similar to those beers in taste, but its actual palate is much more inviting.Off the bat I get a soft creaminess from the head, followed by a sweet and somewhat citrusy body that is quite refreshing, actually. I assumed this beer would have a crisp, spicy palate but what I got was actually quite the opposite. Its very rich with a genuine fruity taste of peach, raisin and just a bit of orange. The description on Chimays website also mentions Muscat (a sweet white grape) and its no lie.The more I drink the more this beer opens up to me. Eventually the yeast makes itself known adding some powdery spice to the palate. I also get a slight banana and clove taste reminiscent of an authentic hefeweizen, but not nearly as strong. It all adds up for a very tasty and very satisfying beer.DRINKABILITYUnlike other tripels Ive tried, the spiciness of Chimay White doesnt overwhelm. This is a beer I can actually drink in gulps rather than confined to sips. The mouthfeel itself is extremely soft, whereas others Ive had were crisp making them a challenge to drink.The only caveat to this beer is its density. Chimay White weighs in at 8% ABV and it does make itself known after one serving (but not until AFTER the serving). There is NO trace of alcohol in the taste or aftertaste, which is all the more impressive considering its high potency. Regardless, I think if drank at the proper pace, Chimay White could be a session beer of sorts. At the very least its a very rewarding after-dinner treat.FINAL THOUGHTSAs of this writing my experience with Trappist beers is still fairly limited. However, I think its safe to say that Chimay White would be an excellent starter beer for the drinker looking for a higher-end beer with true drinkability. NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9JBI7Qo1xig

750 mL bottle pours murky amber with a frothy two finger off white head; nice lacing once the head is down.  Quite a musty and yeasty aroma with bready malts, dried apricots, clove, pepper.  Pretty similar the flavor: bready malts and yeast make up the majority of the flavor.  Its definitely musty, but in a better way than the Westmalle tripel.  Finishes dry with apricot, clove, and mango notes.  Medium bodied with a frothy mouthfeel and a medium-high level of carbonation.  I liked this quite a bit, but I think its a bit over-carbonated.  I let it sit for a little while which seemed to fix the bloating issue.
Tap.  Dark, hazy color.  Yeast, tea, and spice.  High in carbonation. Complex and balanced like a good tea.  Spicey and bitter.  A nice beer.

Bottle. Poured hazy golden with a big white head. Interesting aroma with esters and spice. Medium body with creamy mouthfeel and good carbonation. Flavour starts with sweetness - raisins, caramel and soft not tart fruitiness. It makes a fairly distinct transition to a big long bitter finish. Excellent beer and how can one criticise Chimay? but I thought it lacked perhaps in subtlty.
Got to try the 2007 tripel from the Rose and Crown as part of their SF Beer Week stash. Looks great, a light orange gold, nice head. Aroma of apples. Tastes good, very drinkable and fairly complex.
Pours a cloudy gold with a thick white head.  Aroma is cereal, banana and alcohol.  Taste is malty with a slightly bitter aftertaste of alcohol and cereal.  Nice brew.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2010 Bottle. Great pour and creamy head. Wonderful aroma of fruit and spice. Pepper and fruit notes in flavor, rich color and complexion. Full body, and a lovely texture to the palate, medium and smooth. Bitter finish and long on the tongue.

Draft at the Mellow Mushroom Mobile AL (!). Hazy yellow and very carbonated (as it should be). Nose is yeast, spices and a bit of alcohol. Taste of bready yeast, spiciness, some malts. Very carbonated and flavorful-fluffy yet a full body. I like this beer and it goes well in the summer.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Bottle. Abricots and malt in aroma. Golden yellow colour with white head.  Bittersweet grapefruitlike flavour. rich carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2010 Tap at cookie. Great beer. Aromas of apple, citrus, yeast, bread, and champagne. Taste has a sweet start, with bitterness taking over for a long finish. Palate is silky, almost creamy, with high carbonation, and medium-to-full body. Colour is dark yellow, with a frothy white head.

on tap. ottima tripel,buon aroma fruttato e floreale.al gusto si ritrova in frutto a polpa bianca non troppo maturo,il floreale bel sentore di malto.birra robusta ma abbastanza equilibrata e persistente.

A truly wonderful authentic Trappist tripel.

Theres so much going on! Starts out a bit peppery and fairly sweet, with loads of fruit notes (same ones as in the aroma). Then the hop taste starts coming through, together with a slight boozy taste, leaving a pleasant bitterness lingering in the after-taste. There is a fair amount of spice notes, notable coriander, nutmeg, and allspice. The sweetness and the peppery hoppiness definitely work very well together.

Drinks easily and has a medium body to it. A little boozy and peppery.
An excellent beer from an excellent brewery!
Glorious things of thee are spoken, Chimay White.  A hymn of praise should be written to extol thy greatness.  Why have I been remiss so long to enjoy thy bounty?
Growler fill from CBX. Very tasty. Has enough hops to give you a little smack in the palate after a sip and stays a while.

one of my first forasy into the world of triples. my palate is starting to gravitate from ipas and dipas to belgian beers and this one didnt disappoint. color is an amazing yellow gold, hazy, and tastes just like it looks. im still figuring out the difference between belgian beers, but if this is what i can expect, im in for a treat.
a solid triple. drinks well, balanced imo. not too citrusy, just right. bigger fan of doubles but i definitely like this triple.

I like dark beers the best, and after drinking Chimays Blue & Red, I expected this to be more of a whitbier which I dont particularly care for.  The coloring is amazing, a cloudy orange in the center, but as Im looking at the glass its light yellow/orange around the bottom and top of the glass.
