Aroma & taste are as described, and this has as much body and taste as I love in Belgian beers.  This could be my favorite of the three in the pack I picked up (with the goblet).

Bottle. Pours a cloudy deep orange with a large rocky head. Fades pretty quickly leaving some lacing. Aromas are pretty much as expected with the typical belgium yeast characters dominating. Plenty of banana, orange and clove. Flavours once agaain are dominated by the yeast showing heaps of banana and citrus. Some spices also. Finish is slightly sweet. Bloody good beer

Versa colore arancio, peristente schiuma bianca.Fresco aroma di frutta,di lievito,luppolo e spezie; Corpo pieno e abbastanza liscio, sapore piccante forse troppa carbonatazione, sapore di lievito e frutta con finale di amaro e piccante e pepato. 
Non la meglio delle Chimay,però lo dico piano o i frati trappisti mi fulminano!
Pours slightly hazy golden with a foamy white head. Aroma of berries, honey, yeast, oranges. Taste is mild citrus with a yeast spice and bread.

330mL bottle, pours a hazy golden yellow with a slowly-dissipating thick white head. Aroma is citrus, banana and hops, with some floral notes. Flavour follows accordingly with citrus and some spiciness on the finish. My favourite of the Chimay brews.

Pours with a luxurious rocky white head with a hazy golden almost orange colored beer beneath. Aroma has some light clove with some floral notes, some bubblegum and banana with a light hop zing. It really smells more floral than sweet and finishes with a bit of booziness. Ive always really dug the flavor of this one and by the first sip I can tell my bottle is "aged" a little longer than I would prefer, but this beer holds up fairly well and its still delicious. There is defiantly the good kind of mineral character to the beer and plenty of apple and fruitiness. The beer is full of spiciness some seems like hoppy spiciness and some seems like orange peel. Every thing is pretty well balanced. I need a fresher bottle.
pours hazy gold with thick frothy white head. aroma is bursting with spices and sugars. drinks very spicy with a sugary sweetness that I dont think fits. to much spice in this one for me

33cl bottle - Pours a hazy orange with a creamy white head. Aroma is banana and spice, with some yeastiness and dry herbal qualities. Pleasant smell, but Im just not a fan of this sort of spice profile. The taste doesnt do it for me at all. The spiciness is still there on the initial taste, and transitions into some serious bitterness--real grassy and medicinal. Theres some sharp alcohol in there as well, along with some orange rind, and white grape. Its all overpowered by the bitterness and some serious carbonation, however, and really ruins what could be a nice, subtle tripel. As much as I like the Red, Im not seeing the allure of this one.

Orangy color, longlasting white head; fresh hopped aroma of yeasty fruits and spices; mouthfeel is full and quite smooth despite a bit tangy carbonation; flavor of yeast and fruits with bitter and peppery spicy finish.
I liked the cloudy appearance of this beer. Not my favorite style, but nice floral aromas and a relatively light taste considering the alcohol content.

Pours a pale hazy orange colour with a big fluffy head which leaves much lacing. Aroma is complex, very fruity. Some fruitiness, and loads of yeast and spices. A hint of alcohol. Some wheatlike characteristics. Quite sweet, with a solid lingering semidry finish to top it off. Carbonation is lively, yet it feels smooth and full in the mouth. Alcohol heat reminds you it’s no lightweight. Overall a great beer.

Big creamy white head, golden colour.

A: Coriander, Yeast, citrus, spices, not that strong.

F: Yeast, coriander, spices, lemon, discrete ending bitterness

M: Crisp clean, fresh.

T: Triples are not my favourite style, but as always Chimay impresses.

11.2oz bottle poured into Trappist glass. Pours a very nice orangy color with a medium thick head that dissipates a bit, but is being regenerated by the carbonation.  Smells of fruits; orange, apple, with a bit of malt. The taste is very malty with a large bite from the flavor of Belgian yeast. Overall a good beer. Had been waiting a few weeks to open it and it lived up to expectations.
UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 Pours a hazy gold/orange. Taste and aroma is hops and fruits with a sweet, bitter aftertaste. Mild carbonation. Excellent beer.

"This is probably my favorite of the three Chimay ales available. A tightly crafted Tripel that has enough character to stand out from the typical mold. Not my favorite of the style, but grand nonetheless. Pours a very hazy golden-orange and has a lasting quarter inch thick white head and very nice lacing. Fragrant with sweet malts and a flowery bouquet coupled with pepper and yeast spiciness. Lemon and orange counter the spice nicely. Bountiful on the palate with a great peppery bitterness, I enjoyed the noble hop profile. Biscuits and citrus (mostly lemon) countered by that big noble hop push. My last beer of 2009."
draught.  had a two finger white foamy head. aroma of the sweetness from fruit and smell of hops.  good bitterness from the hops and not too sweet from fruit.

Draught. Hazy Orange with thin white head. Aroma is raisins and oranges and much much lighter lemon. Flavors are creamy and soothing but much the same notes as the nose. Flavors go sour and sweet; back and forth, back and forth but ending dry long and lasting.
Strong beer which hides it wonderfully (as all of Chimays line-up). Cloudy light brown.  Sweet fruity flavour. Easier to drink than most triples. Has a raw feel to it.

Bottle. Pours a pale hazy yellow with a big fluffy head which leaves much lacing. Nice. The aroma is complex, very fruity. Some banana, some light tropical fruitiness, and loads of yeast and spices. A hint of alcohol. Some wheatlike characteristics. Quite sweet, with a solid lingering semidry finish to top it off. Carbonation is lively, yet it feels smooth and full in the mouth. Refreshing and drinkable, yet the alcohol heat reminds you its no lightweight. Definitely a good one.

330 mL Bottle. The label is marked with a "serve before end of 2012" best-before date. Hazy gold body with a one-finger foamy white head that settles to a clingy creamy layer. Aroma is rich, complex, mild but fruity-malty. Faint nuances of wine, raisins, and spice. MMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM!!! Very bizarre yet interesting: silky smooth all the way, a rich fruity-malty flavor, bubblegum and cherry cough drop accompany the hops in the aftertaste, and then a warm fine-brandy-like finish. This beer has tied on my scoreboard with its own sibling, Chimay Bleue.

Leaving the debate of whether or not to lay down corked Belgian 750ml bottles, of which Chimay quite literally and visually warns against doing on their labels, there is also the debate of when their three different beers are best enjoyed by. The Grand Reserve is truly the most age worthy; gaining fine notes of port and rich vinous qualities the longer she safely rests in her bottle. The Premier and Cinq Cents though are a different story. Chimay themselves advice to enjoy both within a year of their life-time, maybe a little more than a year on the Cinq Cents, a Belgian Tripel, but no more than that. Should I take that as the written gospel and adhere not for fear of some divine retribution? Gospel was written to be challenged and broken when needed, in my not so humble opinion, and I shall explain to you exactly why.


Exiting stage right and entering stage left is my corked 750ml bottle of Chimay Cinq Cents, a Belgian Tripel of heavenly proportions. As I undo her wire cage, I always take mind to keep a finger atop the cork to save myself a rocket launch of spectacularly messy proportions. Cage removed, I free her cork with a pop and gaze lovingly at the sensual mist slowly crawling out of the bottles neck, free at last and ready to please. Now, many have asked me how/where one can find the age on a Chimay bottle and save for the life of me you wont find it anywhere readily noticeable on the bottle. Verily, the bottle date is on the top rim of the cork, an unfortunate placement because more often than not that very important wire cage is covering the date with its cap. Thats ok though; I do enjoy a healthy dosing of surprise in my life which upon closer inspection of this cork is what I received. Fellow friends, family, beer geeks, and Chimay spokespersons, I have before me a 2006 Chimay Cinq Cents and my excitement level just went from giddy to full on beer geek ecstasy. I tell you, I couldnt pour her fast enough into my glass, hands atremble in excited anticipation. Illustrious hazy orange, straw, and gold depths with a splattering of amber sit beautifully under a huge puffy pithy head of the orange variety. She fades in splendid regalia, leaving lace every where she touches. A slow stream of bubbles laze their way to the surface, bursting in joyous abandon. There is a smidgen of dregs resting in the cusp of my glass, and without further ado I fully embrace her nose for all her worth. Spice, yeast, and dough ride atop banana cream while flurries of nutmeg and cinnamon tickle. Whole oranges lay before me, and as I slice into their ripe depths, juices flow and pithy esters mingle. For a playful nip in the finish, white pepper and green pepper, to mismatched cousins that manage to mingle harmonious with each other and the whole of my Cenq Cents nose. I feel like a kid at Christmas morning, hands at the ready to rip into her presents aglow with mystery and delight, and so I do. Drawing deep for the first of many amazing quaffs, green pepper and white pepper tickle and tease the front of my tongue which grins happily under a crunchy interplay of sliced and toasted Italian bread upon. Adding to the dryness of her palate is green grass and fresh bales of hay drying in the warm summer sun. The dryness could be attributed to her age, but it is far from detrimental to her palate. My breath is peppered with coriander and orange pith while an undercurrent of honeycomb sweetness carries her palate from start to finish. Her finish is dry and brittle with cinnamon, nutmeg, and dried flowers. Filling out the meat of her palate are oranges, pith, and bananas with their skins included. Warmth slowly starts to spread her supple fingers through my throat and into my chest, a wonderful counterbalance to the dryness of her palate which is simply divine. Setting pen and paper down, I divulge my full attentions upon this aged masterpiece.


There is no doubt that the 2006 Chimay Cinq Cents was far drier than a fresher bottle, and I am OK with that. I love the rich sweetness of a fresh Cinq Cents, but what age offers to this Trappist beauty is sophistication blessed with the perfect measure of dry earthiness. By all means, sup on a fresh one, but dont be afraid to defy the Chimay dictum and age one for a few years and fall in love all over again as I did.

Vintage 2008. Serving date: 2009-01-23. Served in snifter.

Presentation: 330 ml bottle with freshness date (Best before end of 2010) and recommended serving temperature, glassware and cellaring procedure on the label.

Golden yellow with brownish hues. Rather hazy. A semi-hard pour into my large-bodied snifter creates a big white head that looks creamy and thick. The head settles rather slowly and leaves a nice coat and some lacings.

Citric notes and fruity aromas (mostly bananas I think) in the smell. Some wheat and subtle yeast aromas are here as well.

Citric and banana-like fruit flavors. Yeast and wheat provides a nice grainy and earthy character. The alcohol is present and leaves a little twang, but its unbelievably well-balanced. The big and long finish is a bit dry, slightly alcoholic and has a distinct but gentle bitterness that sits side by side with a pleasant spices and white pepper. The finish is really good on this one, and its semi-dry spicy character seems everlasting.

Rather smooth and creamy considering its medium body and the generous amount of carbonation.

Another great Belgian classic, and all in all a wonderful beer. The aromas are perhaps not overly interesting, but the taste is so well-balanced and complex. As for the alcohol, you definitely notice it, but it fits into the overall character.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2010 Only had this once and that was a couple months ago. Unfortunately I didnt take down the details. I do remember that it scored well on all counts. Will gladly get this beer again to give full rating. For now though this was good.

31-DEC-2009, bottle.
Dark in colour for a tripple. Hazy, light head.
Nose is fine and tripple-like.
Light carbonation.
Nothing special, just an easy drinking beer.

Squat bottle poured into Chimay glass. Golden body, the foam outlasts the beer. Fruit aroma (maybe apricots), but the taste is a bit more stern. Fair amount of hop bitterness, yeasty, spicy, white grapes... almost winey. Dry finish. I drank this warmer than the recommended 45, which probably brought out more flavors at the expense of refreshment.
Poured golden with dense white head.  Musty aroma.  Spicy flavor with hint of Belgian candi sugar.  Slightly musty, dry horseblanket flavor.  Dry finish.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2011 Bottle. The pour was a cloudy amber-brown with a large (2-3 fingers) off white foamy head that had great retention and produced some really good lacing that lasted throughout.

The aroma had a gentle scent of  bread malts, a very mild resin hops and a nice dose of a leathery yeast with a hints of raisins, caramel, banana and a touch of vanilla. 

It had a bitter-sweet taste with a hint of dried fruit and vanilla at first and finished with a slight emphasis on the hops yet remaining quite malty with notes of banana and some spice at the end. The flavor was left to linger for an average amount of time leaving a nice warming sensation behind.

Mouthfeel was medium to full in body with a very creamy yet dry texture with a mild carbonation. 

Overall an absolutely tasty Trappist Ale that lets the fruit and malts blend together ever so perfectly. It is as I would call it, a very nice relaxing sipper".

Not a very strong aroma. Slightly darker than other tripels, very sparkling with a nice frothy head.
Nice flowery hoppiness with cheesiness. Long and slightly bitter finish.
This is again a great choice from Chimay, there is a bitterness to the aftertaste but it is not overpowering you can definetely enjoy the fruity aroma of this beer and it is another great choice
zeer pittig biertje een lekkere smaak van gerstemout, hop en gist. de afdrong een lichtjes droog

Bottle.  Pours a dark amber hazy color with a large, dense white head.  Lacing is ridiculously strong.  Aromas of spruce, banana, dough, and hay.  Palate is exceptionally smooth with a very creamy finish.  Tastes of banana, butterscotch, bread and smooth citrus.  This beer is just plain awesome.  Greatness has been achieved.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2009 This was an unbelievable beer.  Personally Im a fan of Trappist ales, so its probably a bit of a bias. It was on tap, a fantastic two finger head pour.  At first i wasnt so accustomed to it but as i drank, it became amazingly better.  The muscat flavor is probably the most prevalent and noticeable.  For anyone who enjoys the  Trappist beers, this is an excellent tripel.

bottle @ home. Got this beer as a christmas present. I like this beer. Pours a golden yellow beer with a huge white head. Aroma contains hints of fruits and bitterness. The taste is also sweet with bitter notes. Great aftertaste. Want to drink this one again!

Small bottle, 

pours a hazy mixture of peach skin colors  reds and yellows with particles floating around, made a two finger white head, head is persistent and hangs around, leaves lots of lacing on the glass as I drank, 

aromas of lemon citrus, light fruit, fresh floral scents, faint white sugar sweetness in the background,

flavors of light orange fruit, pale malt, faint cake mix, a little orange and sugar sweetness at the beginning of the sip, 
finish is dry and has some bitterness with a touch of pepper and field herbs trailing afterwards, 

mouth feel is less than medium, 

nice tasting Triple with little sweetness, no alcohol in aroma or flavor, and ends pretty dry.

From bottle on 12/24/09.  Pours a hazy orange with sizeable off-white, creamy head.  Aromas of sweet spices, yeast, light on the malts.  Taste is dry and slightly sweet.  Spices are a positive in this tripel offering, not a hinderance.  Alcohol is well-hidden - simply an excellent and world-class abbey tripel!
strong fruit aroma, golden, hazy, frothy, rocky head, medium sweetness, very bitter, full body, slick feel, soft carbonation, long finish, bitter, good heavy trappist
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

text:
I have not had the Chimay white in many years so I ordered one on tap at a local mexican restaurant. Cloudy orange as I remembered with a spicy smell. The flavor was strong bubblegum, hops, really robust with a bit of spice towards the finish. Nice soft mouthfeel and easy to drink. The strength of the flavor was easily the best part about this tripel, nice but I still think the dubbel is their best beer.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 12-25-2009 03:00:23
UPDATED: DEC 2, 2010 amber with a nice big, lasting fluffy head, aroma and taste from yeast and hops. Sets the standard for this kind of beer.

Had this many times over the years but never rated it. Small bottle. Pours a murky golden with a great deal of carbonation resulting in a thick, pillowy head that diminishes slowly. Aroma is slightly sweet, small zest of lemon and white bread. Taste is doughy with a muted sweetness. Hops ride in at the end to linger well. Still quite effervescent, a flaw that I know diminishes with aging (this is a very young bottle). Overall quite excellent BUT not the legend I remember it as...perhaps Ive had enough quality tripels now to mark this down a tiny bit from where I would have a few years back. Still very good.

Unbelievably, on tap at the Red Zone bar and grill in Fresno, CA.  Hazy straw colored with small head to lace.  Nose is nice light Belgian fruity yeast.  Taste is same, with a nice background of bitterness.  Belgian style sweetness is obvious, but not overpowering.  Nice balance.  Im not typically a big Belgian fan, but I liked this one.Too bad the pint was $11.00 instead of the $4.50 all the other brews were.
Thanks Chibbyman. Bronze pour with a white head. Nice carbonation is noticeable during the pour. Aroma of hops, yeast, spices. Flavor is citrusy, coriander, yeasty, hops little bitter.

Bottle.  Hop -slight fruit aroma. Golden Haze body with tall fluffy head.  Nice balance of hops, banana, wheat and spice... Dry finish with a slight bitter aftertaste... very easy to drink and enjoyable
Hazy white, golden with a decent white head.  Sweet, spiced aroma and taste.  A bit of dry pineapple and grapes off the hops.  Dry finish leaves you thirsting for more.

Pours a hazy gold with a pillowy head that slowly settles down to a thin covering.  Aroma is mostly earthy with a slight floral contribution from the hops.  Mildly sweet and fruity with a drying finish.  Medium bodied with smooth carbonation.

Bottle. The triple smells very sweet and malty, strong aroma of bread, a soft fruity smell. The head is large, light beige and creamy with a long duration. The body is cloudy and orange-brown. The taste is malty with a light bitter touch. The finish is bitter and light metallic. The body is very creamy and silky, medium strong with a normal carbonation.
I did drink one of these beers but has been awhile ago and I dont recall all of the details - good beer though and will have it again.

Bottled, pours clear amber/golden in color, with small white head. It has aromas of floral hops and citrus rind with a touch of yeast. It has a light body with a slightly bitter bite. It is a smooth triple with a carbonated finish of floral hoppiness.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2010 (several vintages without significant aging)
(a 1998 in 2010)

gl-§opq, full bod, med co2, creamy head~, 

§malty T1, fruity hoppy malty T2, §bitter warm T3 Tf.

12 yr old - fruity, sweet, woody, caramel, bright, sherry.

Pours almost clear golden with a thick white head. Aroma is yeasty and of freshly baked bread and citrus. Flavor is bitter and full. Creamy texture and good carbonation. Nice long bittersweet finish. Very decent triple.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2012 Refigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours a dark golden color that is a little hazy with a nice head that disapears fairly quickly.  The taste is fruity (tones are mostly pear and apple), malty, and is warming.  Good beer.  Prefered a 2008 bottle in 2012 over a 2012 bottle.

330 ml bottle served with a Chimay Blue and Chimay Cheese. Pretty good stuff. Pours a hazy dark orange with a creamy foamy head. Aromas are fruity, yeasty, and a little hoppy. Flavors arent really sweet at all but have good a good fruit component. Pretty of yeasty, dough flavors. Pretty bready as well. Goes great with Chimay Cheese if you can find it. Found mine at Whole Foods.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2012 Gold with floaties. Head is white and settles to a bare coat. 3 Quinces, pears, peaches, mandarins, earth, leather, cloves, cardamom pods, white pepper. Complex fruit sweet sour combination. Spicy. Noticeable alcohol. [3.7] 750ml bottle, 2009. Just hazy gold with what settles as a coat of white head. Fruity as above with gentle but insistent spice and drying bitterness. Not that exciting but utterly seamless. [3.8]Large, lasting white head. Sweet mandarins and dried fruit, lovely spices, classy balance.

Bottle into trappist glass. Pours a hazy orange with a thick foamy head that dissipates quickly. The aroma is yeasty and a little sweet (apple or pear, perhaps). Lively carbonation on the tongue precedes a yeasty, bready flavor. It leaves a dry bitterness on the tongue--a little like grapefruit zest. Its worth a try, but their Grande Reserve is so much better.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2010 One of the most balance blondes.  My favorite beer when eating sushi.  A thick, lively beer with plenty of flavor.  Updated: What makes this beer so special is the complexity and the balance of all that is going on in this fine brew.   You have the nice delicate sweetness and carbonation that you get with you Belgian strings but a nice balancing hit of hops.  I do have to knock this beer down to a 4.9 however because I can only give one 5 rating and until Ive rated many more beers, I am not ready to annoint this a 5.   But its darn near perfect to me.
To me Chimays triple comes across as over carbonated and to bitter. The appearance is a hazy orange color.
Bottle. Pours completely opaque golden brown with plenty of long lasting foam. Flavor of sweet candy sugar with a bready aspect, a little spiciness, some sour citrus notes, and a dry bitter finish.

Dark hazy orange coloured with a huge dense head on top. Aroma is sharp hops and alcohol. Flavour is light caramell, grassy sharp hops and some alcohol. Somewhat phenolic and harsh but still refreshing and drinkable on a summer day. Body has a very lively, close to harsh carbonation and the beer ends on a dry and grassy note with light lingering caramell.

Pours a hazy golden with a giant white head, tiny bits in suspension, looks quite viscous, significant lacing... Aroma is dominated by belgian yeast, with notes of apple, bubblegum... Flavor follows complexly with notes of vanilla, yeast, fruits... Very creamy, with a dry finish...

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2015 huge offwhite frothy and creamy head. excellent lacin. mostly diminishing. dark yellow thick flat body. Aroma: moderate hoppy, citrus orange, honey. if: moderate bitter light sweet. ff: moderate bitter and moderate sweet (honeyish and fruity); long duration. Palate: lively carbonation, light medium body, oily texture and metallic and moderate alcoholic finish. Delicious fruity taste, reminding of white wine. 200s

21.nov.09.:creamy huge white head. excellent lacing. fully lasting. sparkling cloudy thick amber body. aroma: apple, moderate yeasty flowers. if: moderate bitter. ff: light sweet moderate bitter. long duration. palate: medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation and chalky finish.nao tem o dulçor de uma tripel, parece uma Belgian strong ale; disfarça bem os 8%

Bottled, golden pour with thick white head, big aras of bread/yeast sweet fruits with slight grassy background, slight malt sweetness with bigger then expected floral hops with lingering sweet fruits with a hint of alcohol warmth

Lovely golden amber colored liquid. Nice two-finger foamy white head. Okay retention and some quite decent lacing.

Bananas. Powerful smell of bananas strikes first. Nice caramely malt scent. Earthy yeastiness. Slight spiciness to it.

Pan-fried bananas with carmelized brown sugar and hints of clove and corriander. Nice yeasty bread notes. Roasted malt notes make a slight appearance.

Good creamy smooth feeling in the mouth. Very good carbonation level. Nice tiny little bubbles that dance over your tongue and down your throat.

With the alcohol so well hidden, this is an excellently drinkable brew. Nice and easy.

Aromas of corianer, anise, white pepper, orange. Metallic, wet blanket yeast. Some bready, butterscotch malts.

Flavor starts with big spicy anise dominatation followed by a yeast explosion. Builds to a sour, bitter climax with smoother fruity malt notes in the finish. A Very pleasant and complex brew.  Some burnt wood, molasses notes in there as well.

The texture is well carbed but pleasant, with a good amount of pucker. The finish is light and dry.

Hazy golden yellow beer with fine white mousse. Aroma is slight peppery with hints of malts and some yeast. Taste is bready, cereals and some refreshing hops. aftertaste is nice with a bready malty feeling and ends with a good touch of hop.

Almost year old bottle.  Pours a deep golden to straw color, reasonably opaque, with a nice creamy off white head that lasts reasonably well.  Nose is fruity, lots of orange.  A bit of hops, also citrusy.  Hints of yeast are in there as well.  Flavor is much the same, plenty of light fruity notes.  Nice and bitter, plenty of hop flavour in there, good and citrusy.  Theres a bit of a malty backing, and it very slightly warms your insides from alcohol.  In the mouth it has a nice feeling, appropriately thick, nicely carbonated.  Very pleasant beer.

It poured hazy orange liquid with a huge icecream looking foam that rose like a mountain above the rim of the glass. As it receded it left little craters and lots of lacing along the side of the glass. This is a great look for a beer, very appealing.

It had a fairly strong smell of yeast, oranges, other citrus fruits, malt and a hint of hops. There where some more smells which I couldnt quite place.

The mouthfeel was smooth, despite a medium amount of carbonation. It had a medium body and medium bitterness. It tasted similar to what it smelled, yeast, oranges, citrus and a hint of hops. Not very sweet, a bit dry and felt complex. There where more tastes that I couldnt put my finger on. A very nice beer.

33 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA. Hazy deep golden colour, volcanic like fermentation rising from the bottom. Still frothy head, coriander, citrus and yeaty/farmhouse aroma. Very smooth, clean first sip. Active in the mouth with gentle ongoing carbonation, sweet and dry peppery finish.

Bottle. I smelled notes of citrus, yeast, and slight hops. Poured a gorgeous cloudy unfiltered golden color. Tasted acidic lemon, bread, cereal, and a slight hop finish. Active carbonation on the palate with the tingling sensation on the way down. This is one of my favorite abbey tripels, and in my opinion is the best offering from Chimay.

750 mL bottle from my local Farm Fresh (purchased November 2008, enjoyed 1 year later).  Golden yellowish-orange pour with a fizzy off-white head.  Aroma of bready yeast and a hint of Belgian candi sweetness.  The first thing I notice about the taste is just how dry this is.  I also pick up on a honey sweetness mixed with a flowery bitterness from the hops.  A very good tripel.

Its always nice to open a beer with a real cork. But the gentle plop was just the beginning. It was obvious that the bottle contained sediments, but a gentle pour gave an almost clear beer in a orange/honey shade, with lots of bubbles and a light white foam. 
The aroma was complex with notes of mandarin, hobs, and ginger/muscat notes.
The taste had a sweet mandarin and marcipan taste complimentet with light bitter hops and a refreshing acidity. Nice fill in the mouth and a good lasting bittersweet aftertaste.

bottle- pours golden honey color with nice creamy, off-white head. What I noticed the most right off the bat was the alcohol in the nose with respect to the bleu and the rouge, it was much stronger. The aroma was of spicy, bready apricot. The taste was raisin and orange with only the faintest note of...(liquorice?). The finish was a bit too bitter for my taste and I could really taste the alcohol. Having said that I can appreciate the quality but I prefer bleu.

75cl corked and wired bottle.

Pours a cloudy amber with a huge white head with great retention and decent lacing. Very nice looking beer.

Aroma is of grapefruit and coriander. Medium-bodied Belgian tripel with ok, but not really substantial mouth feel. Medium carbonation.

Taste of herbal spices, yeast and, again, coriander - much, much less sweet than the aroma indicated. Sweet and sour finish, spicy herbal after taste. More sessionable than many other Belgian tripels (Grimbergen, for one, comes to mind), agreeably non-sweetish. And no perfume either! Well-balanced, smooth and highly drinkable brew, with a barely noticeable higher abv.

Pours hazy light yellow.  The aroma is yeasty and malty, bready undertones.  With the head rising the aroma of hops comes to life and completes a great aroma.  Has a barley bitter yeast taste that is washed down with a malty but hop tinged fall on to the palate.

Once I cracked the beer open, I got a very pungent smell of yeast and sweetness. This was a very misleading start for the beer. In the glass, the beer had a very murky, translucent appearance. It had a golden appearance (it looked just as expensive as it is) with a white-ish head. But, the head was very small signifying a lighter beer (EDIT: I poured a glass a couple days later in a pilsner glass and the head was so big that I only poured 70% of the glass out and the head overflowed). The carbonation is also pretty consistent within the beer but it doesnt form into a head - it just falls up and down within the beer. As for the taste, Chimay White starts off very sharp. It hits you right off the bat with the taste of alcohol and the roasted barley and yeast. It eventually mellows out with the smoothness of the brew but as you swallow it, the bitterness kicks in again, just like most other European beers. This was not nearly as fruity as any of the other Chimay brews but it did have a slight citrus bite. In terms of texture, the beer flowed from bitter, to smooth, to bitter again - a very interesting curve in the palate.
hazy golden ale with subtle fresh aroma. Fresh fruity flavour. Bitter aftertaste. Very drinkable, cant feel the ABVs.

A good Belgian Ale. Very light yellow color. The flavors were very subtle to my unsophisticated palate but nothing stands out. It lacks a wow factor, but it was very drinkable and pleasant beer with an aftertaste that was really enjoyable.

On tap at theAustin Flying Saucer on October 24, 2009.  Yellowy light-amber color.  Thin head after 15 minutes.  Light coriander in the aroma, not much else.  Very clean and... boring, actually.  Flavor is controlled by the yeast, spice and hops.  Its finish is lightly sour with yeast.  A great beer, but in my opinion not very pleasant unless youre a devout fan of the Belgian fare.

Pours a slightly hazy apricot with a tall, chunky off white head that fades to 1 finger after a while and holds pretty well there. Aroma is grass, citrus, sweet bread spices, coriander, lots of floral hops, a hint of bubble gum and pepper. Flavor is sweet cereal gran, yeasty bread, lemon poppyseed bread, wheat, straw, citrus, light fruity notes, a hint of earthy hearbal hops and some mineral notes. Finishes with herbal, citrus hops mineral notes a light bitterness and a little spice. Palate is medium bodied, pretty highly carbonated with a slightly creamy entry leading to a dry, somewhat chalky finish. Good stuff overall, a really nice tripel that seems to be available everywhere.

330ml Bottle. Pours hazy golden orange with a big white head that lasts well. Nose is slightly funky with notes of yeast, citrus, honey and spice. Good flavour that strikes a nice balance between sweet and spicy notes, with hints of honey, coriander, banana and clove. Quite highly carbonated which doesnt spoil the mouthfeel at all and with a lingering sweetish spicy finish. This is a great beer and considering how hard it is to get a tripel just right, all the more impressive.
Had this beer on tap at a lounge on melrose. Light head with a profound texture and a beautiful amber color. Could drink all day!

This is my least favorite Chimay.  Since I perfer donker or bruin Strong Belgium Ales, I was not too impressed with Chimay Blanche.  The aroma is a bit citrusy or almost banana from the yeast selection, The taste is light and carbonated at first and the finish good from the bittering hops.  The overall taste is not very full.   I think the Gouden Carolus Tripel is more complete.

Poured with a  nice head that took a while to disappear.  Ive never been all that good at issolating flavours and such but I can say that its pretty much everything you can expect from a good Trappist ale.  It was spicy with a hint of sweetness but a bitter a finish.  I appreciated though that the bitter finish (while enjoyable for a few moments)  didnt linger.

Id say its quite similar but not as good as a Delirium Treemens.
750ml bottle: tulip: now thats the stuff!!!  Hoppy, fruity wonderland.  Well balanced, medium carbonation, sweet, bitter, bright, fluffy... a true great.
33cl bottle, Alko. Golden slightly hazy in color. Citrus and yeast aroma. bitter finish.

Hazy golden body with a dirty white head. Pretty thick head that leaves spot lacing. Aroma was a yeasty spice with pepper and orange peel. Taste was the same. Great carbonated creamy mouthfeel. A full bodied beer that left a nice candied citric bite at the end.

my personal favorite of the chimay line. one of my favorite beers of all time. with that said. it pours a murky, cloudy orange with an off white head. smells of various belgian yeasts, fresh citrus fruits and a hint of hops. taste is almost identical to the smell, yeasty, very citrusy fruity and a strong hop taste with a swallow of a slight bitterness. smooth and delicious!!
Bottle from Whole Foods.  Had a floral bitterness that I didnt really enjoy.
Bottle. Pours deep orange gold. Head is off-white, thick, and lasts awhile. Aroma of fruits and spice. Firm body with a smooth finish. Very good tripel.
09-09-13 330 ml bottle. hazy orange golden colour. medium fading whiet head. nice grainy taste

Pours a nice golden orange with a bright white head which dissipates slowly leaving a little bit of lacing on the glass. Aroma is of grains and citrusy hops. Taste is medium bodied grains, with a strong hop presence. There is a citrus aftertaste which is due to the hops.
UPDATED: NOV 12, 2009 TAP: hazy yellow pour, fluffy white head. Some bread on the nose, lemon and spice on taste, pretty good tripel.
Golden in colour. Mild cloudiness, with a thin head. A great fresh hop and yeast combo. Dried figs and a touch of bitterness. A great trappist!

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2009 Copper pour, long lasting head. Aroma is citrus mostly orange, heavy hops with some spice (ginger and cinnamon I think). The mouthfeel is nice, quite full, strongly carbonated. Taste is alcohol, citrus and spice, more tasty hops here, big alcohol kick.

Copper, unfiltered. Nice head retention. Foam non-homogenious.

Aroma: Citrusy fruits and some sweetness. Nice, but bites a bit.

 Nice balance. Sweet, citrusy. Fantastic symphony.

Flat, mouth watering.

 Very nice, though alcohol a little much for me.
Bottle.  Cloudy, copper color.  One of the best Abbey Tripels you can buy.  Excellent balance of light sweetness with 8% ABV kick.

330ml bottle. Light copper in colour with a pillowy and creamy foam head. Well carbonated and looks robust. Aromas of spiced fruit, cinnamon and citrus and a strong flavour tht hits all parts of the mouth.

Gold coloured, pours out with a big white head, thick, remains for a long period in the glass. Aromas of ornage peels, hops and freshness. Is tastes a bit bitter, not unpleasant,with hints of orange and slightly acidic. Its not sweet despite the added sugar. Its a nice tripel with a full taste, and a pleasantly bitter  long finish.

Pours a nice hazy orange color with a medium to small white head that is tightly knit and kinda frothy. The aroma is a mix of floral hops, warm yeast, and light clove. The flavor is soft, mellow, and complex. Sweet at first, quickly fading into a spiced mix of what seems like white grapes and a light Belgian wit. It then fades to a soft bitterness that seems to come out of nowhere, accompanied by the faintest hint of alcohol warming. Mouthfeel goes from light and sweet to thick and soft, then slightly bitter and leaves a little sugar on the teeth. A lot of depth to this one, an awesome sipper.
Bottle.  Pours a cloudy brown color with a decent off white head.  Aromas and flavors of clove and banana.  A fair bitter edge to it.  Medium bodied.  Not bad.

An excellent beer, I slightly plain in appearance. Taste is a high point, I only slightly prefer the grand reserve. Drinkability is deceptively high for the alcohol content. Chimay is really one of
The few brews that you can never go wrong with. Would order again.
Definitely my favourite example of the style to date. Terribly smooth with just the right tiny bit of hop bite in it.
Think I prefer blue to this one. The wife loves these and likes the blue more as well. Yet to try red.
Pours hazy golden/orange with thin white head.  Aroma of bananas and yeast.  Taste   is fairly spicy with yeast and a slight hop bite.  Highly carbonated.  Decent.

Enjoyed from an 11.2oz bottle in a tulip glass.  The beer pours a surprinsingly dark amber color, far more than most triples in terms of SRM.  However, the darker color evidences its worth in the aroma, as the beer shows malt first, perhaps Munich or a heavy hand with Aromatic.  A nice melange of yeast-derived esters add some dark fruits to that mix.  The palate is malty up front, tasting almost of a Vienna lager.  Malt carries through the mid- and late palate, complimented by a nice hop balance, and supporting fruity (but not over-the-top) yeast notes.  The finish is neutral to slightly sweet, but certainly not cloying.  As I work through the glass, I am greeted by a pleasant warmth that is welcomed, even on a warm day.  Overall, perhaps a bit on the edge in terms of style, but perhaps right were a true tripel should be.
Bottle.  Poured a cloudy yellow color and smelled strongly of yeast.  Tasted yeasty and a slightly citrusy.
On draught at Birreria Paradiso.  Cloudy amber orange, aroma of raw pizza dough.  Flavor had hints of orange peel and clove.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2009 750 into a trappist glass.  Red is still my favorite, but this is also delicious!  A very good tripel. Trying again on tap. Big yeast, cream, and esters in the aroma and taste. Good stuff.
Not too much point giving the finer details due to the large amount of ratings. But I thought it was a solid beer with a great nose and first few sips but doesnt finish quite as well as I had hoped.
Bottle poured into a Trappist glass produced a very light, tan head and beautiful bright orange body.  Good balance of sweetness and bitterness.  Smell and taste reminded me of white grapes.

white frothy head. golden orangish poor. sweet aroma of banana, caramel, white grape, and yeast. Bit boozy.  Bit fizzy at front. still a lot of sweetness of dried bananas and dark fruit such as raisins as well as  yeast. Cinnamon spice as well. but still balanced. tasty

hazy gold pour with bubbley white head.  aromas of white grapes, some booziness, dark sweet fruit, raisin, date.  Yeasty mouthful of sweet sugary malt, dried fruit, very complex, wonderful tripel.  A classic

Really liked this one. Pours a hazy off white goldish color. Lots of bubbles. Grassy aroma...some citrus notes too. Has a slight hop note and some spiced citrus as well. Will definately be buying a big boy bottle of this one!
Pours a golden orange with barely any head but lots of rising bubbles.  Aromas of yeast, raisin, and funk.  Tastes of yeast, funk, lactic, bitter hops, peppery hops.  Complex.

raisins, coriander, and wheat in the smell, it is a hazy amber-orange with a thick lasting head. its very dry, taste is a typical triple, coriander, drying taste, spices, a little honey sweetness at the end, very light like honey syrup. the mouthfeel is incredibly smooth, thick and full.  this is a great great every now and then ultra quality beer.

Hazy golden color, white head, aroma of Belgian yeast and some spices. Very yeasty taste with some citrus notes and mild hop character. Medium palate that is befitting of the style...it is what it is...
24.01.2004, 0,33l Bottle. Fargen er lys gyllen og ølet er uklart. Ristet flasken litt før jeg drakk den slik at alt kom med. Tydelig preg av sitrus. Mye bitterhet gjør den litt skarp. Veldig god.

330 ml bottle. Hazy orange body with a huge, creamy off-white head. Aroma is fruity and spicy with some banana and caramel. Flavor is sweet caramel malt, fruity like oranges, spicy, yeast and a hint of dry fruit. Medium-plus  body and a nice warming finish with a pleasant bitterness. A complex beer and among the finest samples of triple.

Absolutely fantastic tripel! Best of its style ive had.
I got it on tap from the Yardhouse in Phoenix. the aroma was difficult to distinguish considering the setting, but it was definitely yeast and raisin, and perhaps a bit more.
Taste was nice and spicy, with hops, and some cinnamon. Mouthfeel was smooth and creamy. Ill go back for more and more.

Bottle at the Garrison Ale House in Fredericton.

A: The bottle was brought to me, and then poured into a tulip glass by my server... noooo!! It was all poured into the glass, at an angle the whole time, in one pour, resulting in barely any head, and no opportunity for swirling the last of the beer. Crap. So, obviously the appearance has been affected. However, the beer was still a nice, dark orange color, and very hazy.

S: Great aroma of yeast and fruitiness... some citrus and maybe banana as well? Very enjoyable.

T: Very nice taste... starts off with the yeastiness, then the citrus notes come creeping in. Very slight presence of alcohol at the end, with the warming sensation, but its all good.

M: Nice and smooth on the palate, slightly creamy. Good carbonation, not overwhelming at all.

D: Another fantastic tripel... Id love to try it again, if only so I could get a proper pour, but I have no doubt I would enjoy it at least as much. A great sipping beer.
Rich amber colour, fluffy white head.  heavy, dense, lots of sediment.  Very well balanced, very bright, medium bitter. Notes of peaches.

Pours a bright gold with a big, dense, off-white head. Lots of sparkly citrus in this one - esters are hugely present, with a big hop contingent, Belgian yeast and a tiny bit of candi sugar. Definitely hop-forward for a tripel. Nice and dry, great effervescence, really smooth for something this sparkly. Just a tad heavy on the starchy aspects - the yeast really plays a part in here - but really nice other than that.
Had this at the Yardhouse. Very aromatic triple. Lots of yeast and fruit on the nose. Loved how this one tasted of fruits and bread dough. Very good.

aroma is of yeast and some tropical fruits. a bit sweet but not offensive.  appearance is closer to golden (translucent) then blonde.  flavor is quite sweet and plenty estery... setting it a bit apart from the other trappist tripels. palate is not as dry as the others either, while yeast is present it doesnt mop the moisture from your mouth like some do.
Great Belgian triple.  Im a sucker for the style and you all know this one already.  More complex than Blue, for me, and when served on tap, hops come through.  Beautifully made beer.

Tap at PIB. Pours a lovely orange with yellow highlights and a tight white head. Aroma full of yeast, coriander, honey. Flavor is very spicy, coriander and pepper and some yeast and light honey. Has a nice snap to it that I very much enjoy. Would love to do side by sides of the three Chimay beers someday.

Bottle.  I have had this a few times and hadnt yet rated, so here goes.  Pours a vibrant golden color, very hazy, and has a half inch white head.  The aromas are nice, yeast and apricots dominate.  Flavors include fresh bread, coriander, honey and some great hops.  The palate is pretty close to perfect, refreshing yet solid.  This one had been stored for awhile, and felt like it had some serious alcohol, but no alcohol flavors.  Great beer.
On tap @ Trion Tavern.  It was decent.  Not really what I was looking for though.  Ive had several tripels that I like a lot better.

Tap. This beer didnt live up to the hype, but w.o concern of price, this is a good beer. Aromas of pound cake, banana, clove, wheat pair with the taste. Not too overwhelming though, and I bet there are way better tripels out there.

draft at Public House 7/15/09. Pours a crisp but cloudy golden orange color with a fluffy white head. Nose is yeasty and musty with some light fruit notes of apricots and peaches. Palate is full with light carbonation. Flavors of light must and fruit like the apricots and peaches noted above.
Tap at Bier Circus (Brussels).  Nice light body, with cinnamon maybe ginger overtones.  A great, spicy beer that defines the style.

Amazingly, I havent rated any of the offerings from Chimay...  Bottled; pours a cloudy golden color with a small white head.  Well hopped aroma, fresh baked bread, ground coriander, and sweet honey.  Well carbonated body reveals a nutty, yeasty brew.  Roasted biscuit malts give way to a bitter, hoppy finish.  I have avoided this beer over the past 10 years, as it was my least favorite beer from Chimay.  Times and tastes have changed; this is a world class beer.  Still not a fan of the kegged version, however.
Bottle. Pours cloudy golden with a big creamy head. Tangerine aroma. Strong spicy taste, nice hops as well makes this a fabolous beer. Dry finish

Darker than other tripels. Strong aroma, with more hops than usual.
Tastes strong, with alcohol and esters and hops. Bitter. I used to like it more, and I think its too agressive comparing to other tripels.

murky cider color with stable head and good lacing. a - tangerines & tonic, white pepper & wet hay. t - a light but looooong hop. some ginger, some cotton candy, more pepper and gin? mf - creamy but light.

Served chilled. Pours cloudy golden with large white head.  Taste is spicy with notes of fruit and hop.  Alcohol taste is present but not overpowering.  Hop taste in the finish.  This is very well balanced.  A delightful experience to be savored.

Draught at Q-Brick in Osaka. Very good hops, for both aroma and bitterness. Big, long bitter finish. Yeasty, fruity nose, with biscuity malt. Smooth, full, and mellow flavor with a touch of creaminess. Lovely, with better hops than the bottled version.
Bottle. Very nice and fruity with a nice light copper body and a decent sized head, really nice and smooth to drink.

I had this on tap as part of a "Belgian Flight" at Ashleys in Ann Arbor, MI with my friend BeerBaron617.  It was a nice golden color with virtually no head.  As a result of the wrong glassware (small 6 oz. glasses) I think the aroma was a bit null... However taste was all there.  It was a bit musty with a lot of banana flavor.  It had a lot of carbonation and a light fruity taste.  I will definitely check this out again.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2009 Mmmmmm! Very spicy, reminds me a lot of a slightly less yeasty La Fin Du Monde (which was in fact the first "good" beer I ever had.) It tingles the inside of my mouth after swallowing. Slightly harsh on the tongue at first, maybe from the alcohol? However, it doesnt taste boozy at all. Very dry finish. Quite good overall, havent had the Blue yet, but worlds ahead of the Red.

Bottle.
I has this beer chilled as per Chimays serving instructions.  Color and head were nice, but aroma had nothing. Sweetish malts, but no fruitiness. Perhaps an old bottle?  Beer was good, more bitter than the Red. Alcholic strength not detectable.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2013 33cl bottle from Wine Company, Slough. Slightly hazy amber with a loose off-white head; fresh aroma of hops and cinnamon, lightly carbonated; rich, buttery texture, sweet raisin and caramel malt flavours with some warming spice and alcohol to finish. Very pleasant.
Bottle 0.33 l. Amber hazy colour, strong gigantic white head. Very yeasty and hoppy aroma & palate with notes of bananas, oranges, apples and spices.

33cl bottle poured into a Chimay Trappist glass.  Cloudy copper with two finger creamy off-white head.  Aroma is bubblegum and alcohol.  Flavor is predominantly bitter hops and alcohol with slight bubblegum.  High carbonation.  Finish is warming alcohol.  Pretty good but not the best example of a tripel by far.

pours cloudy amber red with a thick lacy head. aroma is somewhat citrusy and spicy. flavor is malty and heavy on alcohol, with some brown fruit notes. aftertaste has a whiskey-like burn. not bad, but the red and especially the blue Chimay is better.
Bottle. Perfectly nice tripel! Yeasty, spicy and fruity (orange) with a light hoppy bitterness in the finish,

Had on draft at the Dilly Deli.  This tripel had little or no aroma surpisingly, especially compared with the Tripel Karmeliet I had the night before.  It was smooth, easy drinking tripel with some spicy dryness, fruity, malty sweetness and some yeast.  A tad on the cloudy side, this is a good tripel, but not as good as Tripel Karmeliet.

Draft at Mr. Dunderbaks.  Poured a light amber color with a frothy off-white head.  Nose is caramel, yeast, banana, spice and some phenols.  Medium bodied, somewhat soft carbonation.  Flavor is caramel malt with notes of fruit and spice with a mild bitterness.  Finishes dry.
750 mL bottle.  Hazy golden pour with a thick frothy head.  Aroma of hops, pepper and yeast.  Great taste of yeast, bananas, spices, bread with a slightly sharp bitter hoppy finish.

In my opinion Chimays finest. Soft complexity of flavours in the nose, and taste, wonderful aroma. No overwhelming alcohol. Aroma is citrusy, some orange peels. Taste is soft orange, a bit of barley. Great mouthfeel. Great marriage of everything. You can drink tihs forever, and its easily available. Great stuff.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2011 Golden-orange colour with a fine fluffy white head. Mellow citrus aroma, with esters, spices and herbal hoppiness. Creamy, full mouthfeel with a slightly alcoholic and bitter, yet balanced finish. The flavour is dominated by maltiness and "burny" yeast (how do you describe that?). Really not impressive considering the flavour and the palate, this is too much like an average (or marginally above-average) strong wheat beer.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2009 New rating. Last bottle was off. Hazy light orange  with a little redness and big white head. Aroma is clean, but with a hint of sourness. Flavor is bold, spicy, alcohol presence. Feel is smooth and warming.
This beer is as near to perfect as you can get for me.  It looks beautiful, it has a lovely, small head that sticks around the whole time.  It drinks awesomely.

From the 1 pt. 9.4 fl. oz. corked bottle  marked L08-751. The pour is a cloudy copper-amber with a good topping of foamy off-white head and plenty of lacing.  The aroma is a breathtaking yeasty, hoppy and bready scent that reminds me I am drinking an authentic Belgian Abbey Ale.  The mouthfeel is a bolder texture and creamy on the tongue.  The taste is just tart enough to notice but not enough to pucker up.  A topnotch brew.

Hazy light copper with a large head showing some persistence and great lacing.
Aroma is quite enticing, doughy yeast, white wine, light fruits (apple, pear, white grapes?) and just a hint of spicy phenols and sharp lemon.
Flavour doesnt follow through, more doughy yeast, sweet candi sugar and some spicy alcohol. Otherwise lacking in complexity. Nondescript bitterness makes for a finish not unlike most macro pale lagers.
Too much carbonation (not a big deal, just let it sit for a while). Also theres some slight astringency present.
Hazy yellow colour with some sediment.  Hop nose.  Taste is a full palate of hop and yeast.  A little bitterness in the aftertaste.  Overall one of the better beers Ive ever had.

330mL bottle from BevMo (Mission Valley, San Diego).  Pours a murky amber / burnt orange color with a thick off-white head.  The sweet aroma includes hoppy citrus (lemon mainly), earthy/musty malt, and yeast.  Tastes a little malty, but the hop bitterness dominates and has a bit of metallic harshness.  Tends toward being more bitter and less sweet than many of the other tripels.  Also seems more dry than the other tripels.  Its drinkable, but somethings off here.

Bouteille de 33 cl. Arômes de levure fruitée et légèrement épicée, une touche de houblon et de céréales. Robe blonde, belle effervescence et légère mousse. En bouche, la levure typique de Chimay (fruitée et légèrement épicée) est accompagnée par des céréales légèrement sucrées. Finale bien sèche et très légèrement amère. Une bonne bière pour accompagner un repas.
Nice golden color with some off white golden streaks. The aroma has hints of honey and spice. Not too overpowering, which makes for a very drinkable beer. Would highly recommend. Cheers to this one.

Appears hazy reddish orange with a thick rich head. Smells yeasty with hints of orange and some floral aromas. There is a sharp bite added with mixed spicy bitterness. The taste slowly mellows out, with a smooth clean finish. This is easily drinkable, in fact I drank it way to quickly without realizing it. It achieves both refreshment and complexity. There is just the right amount of alcohol presence, not overpowering, but you know its there

Bottle - Shared this one with a buddy.  Pours cloudy yellow with a huge 4 finger white fluffy head.  Its yeasty, but I really cant pick out any other obvious flavors.  I really enjoyed the smoothness on the end.  Aftertaste has a touch of alcohol.  I do enjoy Chimay Red just a bit more, but this is still near the top of my list.
Bottle. Out of the three Chimay brews, I feel this is the weakest. This tripel is pretty good but not great.

I was not impressed.. I actually switch Glasses to see if it would make it better.. It helped but not enough.. Half way through drinking this I was thinking to myself that NB trippel is better than this... My opinion is Tripel Karmeliet is by far the better tripel out of all of them.. Great appearnce and body with hughe carbonation. But I longed for more spice with this brew.. It was way too mellow for a tripel... Bummer
golden orange with fluffy white head. aromas of banana, spices and eathy hoppiness. up front bitterness and high carbonation. tasty stuff and a true classic!

This tripel pours golden yellow with a slight orange tint. It has a strong white head that stays and then fades into a ring. The aroma is light and hops-filled with slight fruity characteristics. The taste is instantly bitter which lets the taster know that there is a great deal of hops in this brew, but quietly fades into a dry, fruity taste.

This is a beer you cant get here in Edmonton. Ive been wanting to sample it for a very long time, with the hope it would be as good as the red and blue label. Wholly crap was I disappointed! What the hell happened to this one!!!! The beer did pour a nice cloudy light orange color, with a thick white head and had a very floral scent that got stronger the warmer the beer got, but it was very light feeling in my mouth with some carbonation. I think it was the taste of this beer that really let me down; it was very light tasting with sweetness, and some citrus in the background but the flavor felt very watered down to me. There was bitter sweet after taste that disappeared almost instantly. I want to try this beer again to give it another chance because I was pretty loaded while playing poker at the time of the sampling. I wouldnt say it was a bad beer it just didnt live up to my expectations, or the quality of the other Chimays

330 ml bottle in Belgium, Brown sugar and citrius aroma, Lots of long lasting carbonation.Light medium brown color.Slightly bitter metalic finish. After running all over Belguim this beer just did not meet what I expected. Still a great beer.

From bottle at The Beer Engine, Lakewood, OH.  Pours cloudy medium orange with solid bright white head that slowly deflates.   Smells like piney wet dog in a great way with a citrusy bubbly mouth feel that is refreshing.  Very green apple/green grape feel in the flavor. Yum.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2011 Re-re-rerate - July 19, 2011. On tap at the Sugarbowl.
On tap at The Sugarbowl bitches! God damn deep fried anchovy stuffed olives fucking rule. 3 orders in and my sodium intake is at 700%. Another great pour with a large fluffy white head that leaves stupid lacing. The aroma is a little hard to place but Ive picked up some things: the orange candy with spices is stellar, so refreshing that it seems to open up my nasal passage. Its a warm orange - similar to soccer slices in a plastic bag at half time. This beer excels to a level that surprised me big time as the flavours are so in my face. The yeast is fairly prominent but not overpowering even if it is leading feature here. Spicy orange candy followed by plenty of yeasty lingerings. So good. Incredible on tap.
last bottle marks were 7473 15 = 3.6


Review from summer 08
Yay! Aged Chimay! Poured out a very nice amber / orange brew with a large, thick off white puffy cap, 360 degrees of lacing throughout and a huge amount of sediment. Slightly sour nose, huge yeast that is very prominent. Man, this has massive aroma. Slightly musty, some citurs (ripe pinapple), mid to mid range spices, a touch of smoke??? (huh?) - a very fresh smelling beer indeed. Pretty tasty too. No alcohol to be found, nice medium spicy yeast, soft mild pepper, noticable malts when warmer. Not a thick tasting beer thats for sure. I just dumped in all the sediment and, as expected, there was a big increase in the potentcy of the spices. Lots of smooth carbonation, medium light bodied. Has a nice yeasty, spicy blend in the after taste to go along with a hard bitter finish that is not overpowering. A very tasty, mouth watering beer. 
*****
Edmonton swillfest in my basement with the usual dolts - very excited to get a hold of another bottle of the white (it had been about 3 years). Impressive solid fluffy head perched on top a light orangish brew. A little weak on the aroma - floral (although this may have been beercronicsheros perfume) and quite yeasty - a little dissapointing. First flavour to hit my mouth was some soft yeast which seemed to stronger followed by a suprising bitterness, more than I expected and some sour undertones. Bitterness was quite spicy too (tis a good thing!)and I never really noticed the 8%. Interesting taste that Im not sure I liked. Finished empty. Quite dissapointing - maybe not the beer to sample following Rochefort 10, but when you expect a beer to be unreal, you can get unreal results. Need another bottle to re-sample.

Bottle from Denmark.
Full fruity beer, apples, peaches. Fine balance. Very Belgian, very drinkable, a true classic.

Relatively young 33cL bottle.  Spicy herbal nose, spicy and dry with some light phenols and lighter noble aroma hops in the deep background.  Cloudy orange-amber with a rocky tan head.  Extremely dry (unexpectedly so!) with a very mildly tannic grape-skin aftertaste, light bitterness and complex malt.  Spicy hops and a little bread, alcohol is superbly hidden, Id have guessed half the abv.  Subtle, nuanced, and has a humdinger of a wallop!  A mature brew worth seeking out.
Solid body, sweet, but still bubbly.  Had lots of spice, yeasty.  Sweetness comes from a raisiny sweet grape appeal.  A little heavier than I think of for tripels.
Very good. well balanced with some fruit up front and a hoppy finish. I think this is one of the better tripples.

Bottle from Systembolaget.
Pours hazy golden, a white head leaves lots of lacing.
Smells of belgian yeast, spices and hops.
Sweet hoppy spicy taste.
Had a really nice aroma of grapes and yeast. A very clean taste of raisins, spices, and other tropical fruits. Finished very smoothly, mmm what a good beer.

Chimay on tap? Only at Canal St Pub, at least in this crap town.

The smell was very atypcial of most tripels I enjoy. Westmalle and Bernardus Tripels have a certain belgian tripel smell, no one knows how to describe it but this doenst have it. Not does it have the american tripel honey nose, nor the canadiana tripel clove nose. 
It smells very nicehowever.

The taste is great. Very typical Tripel taste, nothing overally fantastic. There are much better Tirpels for your money out there.

This beer is recommended, but not if other tripels are available. Try a Westmalle, or Bernardus Tripel if you want a true Belgian experience

Tasted at the GOBF. Pours a light hazy amber with a thick fluffy white head. Slightly fruity, earthy hop, musty aroma. Spicy hop bitter taste with a nice light malt body and a nice balancing sweetness.
Sampled at the GOBF.  Not as bold as the Blue. Much lighter and fruitier.  Nice honey flavor with the grainy and wheat flavor.
pours a cloudy amber color with a head that fades relatively quickly.  it smells of spice, apricot, and sweetness.  tastes of orange and clove.

Pours an unfiltered blonde amber with a gererous cream colored head. It has aromas of wheat, apricot, apple spice, and honey. Has an earthy taste coupled with flavors of yeast and subdued hops. There is some moderate carbonation but the alcohol is virtually hidden. A very nice beer to muse over.
A great blonde beer, honey color, great palate! Drunk in 330 cl bottle, good impression. Try it out!
A beautiful golden color in the glass.  Drinks smooth and easy, but you never forget the mild hoppiness.  Easy to drink too many of these.
Pours a hazy gold color with a nice white head. Strong taste and cloudy gold color with nice white foam. Nice bitter taste and flavors of vanilla. Nice long blend of flavors. Excellent beer.
My favorite of the three Chimays. Not as acidic as the other two but has a very nice aftertaste. Slightly fruity taste and wheat flavors.

Another impressive beer from this brewery.  typical Belgian wheat flavour, but what makes this beer so impressive is the high alcohol content that is not evident in the taste.  In fact, I was surprised to see that this was 8% ABV.
From the tap poured amber with a good amount of head.  Nice sweet malty flavor with a lasting finish.

Bottle, 33cl. Pours an unclear orange/golden beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is fruity and yeast. The flavor has fruits, yeast and a little alcohol. The palate is a little bitter, but still balanced. Overall this beer is easy drinkable, dispite the alcohollevel.

bottle.
Gentle pour shows a hazy light orange color with a full inch and a half of thick white head that clears slowly to leave a thin layer of head and plenty of lacing.  Nose of candi sugar and sticky sweet fruity phenols.  Sweetness very heavy on the nose.  Flavor does away with the overbearing sweet nose; crisp spice notes of coriander and some orange spice.  Grainy yeast sharpness.  Smooth tamed sugar sweetness and fruity boozy phenols.  The nose may have been simple and sweet, but the flavor is incredibly deep and complex.  Palate is full with some creamy sweetness.  Suprisingly crisp finish.  Overall... well, shit, its a superb brew.  The nose disappoints a bit, but that is basically forgotten once the flavor is experienced.

Draft - Poured a slightly hazy golden amber in color with a decent white head. Aroma is strong of spicy hops, citrus, some dark fruit and bready Belgian yeast.  Flavor follows pretty closely.  Finish is spicy and slightly bitter.  Really good...
Pours a hazy deep gold. Sweet nose, spicy, cloves, some banana. Flavor is spices, floral spiced hops, sweet candy sugar. Nicely carbed.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2009 poured golden and hazy with white head aromas and flavors of spices and friuts  been sitting on this one for a while after reading forums about how this is not as good as blue but a hell of a lot better than red now i m affraid to crack  open red

Aroma is spicy, yeasty, some orange peel, moderate amount of light fruityness.  The appearance is a golden red color, strong white head, good lacing on glass.  The Falvor is similar to the aroma, spicy, hoppy, yeasty, slighly fruity.  The finish is more spicyness, and bittering hops.  This is a decent trpiel, true to its style.

First rating in quite a while; im a bit out of condition.  Served in a large shiraz glass poured from a 750ml bottle.  Aroma of dried fruits and port, better than it sounds!  Creamy in the mouth, but also dry afters.

Small bottle. Light brown and cloudy with a fluffy white head. A big aroma - yeasty, perfumy. Tastes of caramelised malt, raisons, yeasty, and has a strong bitter finish with some alcohol warming. A really enjoyable beer.
Hazy orange, huge white head. Spicy, yeasty, slightest hint of wheaty banana. Fruity aroma. Slightly oily feel.

No 720
Rated: 17.04.2009
Bottle brown, 330 ml
Appearance: Pours bright amber, honey like, sunny, orangy - reddish body, carbonation is natural and rather weak, body is very muddy due to a high yeast sediment resulting from long aging, head is off - white, slightly beige and whipped cream like in colour, deep, dense, compact, initially medium and slowly decreasing to small, there is a quite nice lacing.
Aroma: Very nice bitterness and dryness coming from the background, at front there is a gentle, milky, creamy, soft, silky, crispy aroma of malt, white bread, dough and gentle touch of cookies, yeasts and kind of tart wood, probably from aging, notes of raisin, muscat, orange, orange peal, champaigne, white wine grapes, coriander, perfumy touch of spices, quite assertive.
Flavour: Very strong and essential taste from the very beginning like in the example of Chimay Rouge, very strong and bitter hops which together with astringent spices contribute to the dry character of the beer, solid grainy base with notes of wheat and barley, dryness is balanced by smooth yeast contributing to the mellow texture. Nice alcoholic warmth in the aftertaste, alcohol doesnt spoil the taste. Champaigne, white wine grapes, raisin, coriander, lemon, orange peal, earthy touches, dough and cookies, corn, long and pleasant finish. The great representative of its style.
Palate: Body is full, texture is dry, carbonation on palate is weak, finish feel is highly astringent, moderately alcoholic despite its 8%, very clean, aromatic hoppy, spicy.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2009 Hazy, opaque orange color with creamy, rocky head. Complex spicy aroma with coriander, cheese, bananas, and notes of dark fuits. The flavor is very similar. Complex spicy, and yeasty with cheeses. Ends spicy and medium dry. Dense texture with lively carbonation.

09 - 08 - 07
Amber-orange color with medium haziness and frothy white head. Alcoholic figs, sugar candy, coriander, slight muscatel sweetness in the aroma. Good balance between the fruity esters and the herbal hops in the mouthfeel. More balanced body than Westmalle Triple.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2010 Re-rate from an 11.2oz bottle. My rating stays the same. Still a very pretty beer with a solid all-around aroma and flavor. Fruity, yeasty, and earthy with a nice bitterness. Original Rating: April 14, 2009. On tap at the Flying Saucer in KC. Pours a hazy, darker golden-orange body with an inch thick, dense and creamy, dirty white head that dissipates slowly and leaves loads of lacing. Very nice looking tripel. Aroma is soft, but spicy. Fruity, yeasty, bubble gum, and earthy hops. Flavor is similar. Soft and semi-sweet malts in the beginning with the assortment of subtle fruits. Banana, raisin, melon, orange. Finishes earthy and slightly bitter with a decent lingering flavor. Dry and mildly peppered. Light bodied and very easy drinking. Overall, a very nice tripel. Well balanced and flavorful. Nice stuff.
Bright orange pour with a thinning white head, aroma has strong orange and fruit presence, flavor is balanced sweetness with hoppiness, spices are present through the finish along with bitterness.
Looked fine for what it was. Alcohol was well-hidden, with a little fruit flavor and a nice bready body. Glad I tried it.

Hazy golden brown pour into thick foamy white head that slowly dissipates into sticky lacing that melts down the glass. Plenty of spicy bits floating in the glass. Aroma of citrusy hops and yeasty toasted bread. Initial flavor of citrusy fruit with a slighlty bitter hoppy finish.

On tap @ Deluxe. Pour was gold with a finger of collapsing white head. The aroma is that of wheat and orange peels. Taste is typical of a belgian tripel with a spicy/yeasty finish. Overall a nice beer, but not the best of Chimay.
NICE GOLDEN COLOR WITH A LOT OF CARBONATION. NICE SWEET SWEET SMELL WITH HINTS OF CITRUS. A SWEET BOUQUET OF FLAVOR, ONE OF THE WORLDS BEST AND OLDEST TRIPLES. A VERY SWEET TASTING BEER.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 
Location: 12 oz bottle, 8/6/12


Aroma: The aroma is full of Belgian yeast and spice, with notes of fruit and caramel

Appearance: It pours a dark golden color with a large frothy foam of off-white head and heavy lace

Flavor: The taste is mid-plus sweet and mid-plus spicy, similar to the nose component-wise

Palate: The body is medium-plus, it has a tingly mouthfeel to it, and it drinks nicely with a dry finish

Overall Impression: 
This one definitely needed a re-rate, as I was lacking quite a bit in the details.  Anyway, this one is a classic.  I dont drink it that often, mostly due to the regular price point, but it is still a really good beer that I always enjoy when I drink one.  I think the score is about right, so Im going to leave it where it is.

Location: 750 from Rodmans, October 08


Overall Impression: 
Nice, enjoyable tripel, not the absolute top of its style, but its a great style. Old Score: 8/4/8/3/15

Bouteille de 330 ml. Nos yeux observent une bière de couleur ambrée fonçée ainsi quun col de mousse très imposant et durable qui cache complètement la bière du début jusquà la fin de la dégustation. Au nez on découvre des arômes de levure fruitée, de pain, de miel et de houblon floral. En bouche le corps est moyen-rond avec une effervescence moyenne. On goûte des saveurs tout en finesse de levure fruitée, de pain, de sucre, de fleurs avec en finale une amertume sèche.
Bottle. Cloudy orange colour. Fenolic, spicy, fruity and sweet but balanced by quite a bit of hops. Also some alcohol noticeble.
From the bottle. Hazy amber coulour. Aroma is very yeasty. Flavour is strong and alcoholic. This is a great tripple complex and deep.
Bottle from the LCBO.  Hazy, dark golden brown pour. Smooth with a definitive trappist ale finish. I will buy this again.

On tap at the Ginger Man in NYC. Good Tripel, but with a strong Irish/Scotch whiskey character, almost as if it was aged in pre-used oak. Would be curious to try this in a bottle and see how it compared.

A hazy golden brew with a lot of yeast sediment with a small white head that doesnt really stick around. Pretty weak aroma of grain/wheat/hay, a little musky. The skirt Im drinking with says citrus, but I cant tell. Flavor is similarly weak but theres the usual belgian yeast spiciness, and some bitterness at the end. Not my favorite trappist, but if youre looking for a light one this is it.

Bottle.  Pured golden with a big white head.  Aroma of wheat, orange, yeast, light spice.  Taste is similar with some light hop coming through as well.  Finish is a little dry and the mouth is very carbonated.  Very easy drinking, excellent tripel.

Poured a golden hue that when settle had a sit head on top. Seemed to have a lot more carbonation then the red or blue labels. A somewhat strong bitter after taste, but was great going down with the slight flavor of fruit.

bottle,pours golden brown colour and 
a fine head, slight hazy appearance.
strong frity hops aroma
a strong acoholic bitter taste , not my favourite chimay but still a great beer

Sandy brown/orange with some suspended sediment.  Bubbly fizzy head fell very quickly to a thin white head.  Soft aroma of dry wheat and some orange.  Golden raisin, very dry yeast character, firm hop astringency.

341ml bottle in trappist glass. Poured hazy orange with medium white head. Lots of carbonation on the glass. Aroma is malty, spicy and wheat. Small bitterness on the finish which may be the only downside. Rating #68
Very smooth with a bubbly mouthfeel and it looks fantastic with a large white head. Taste is not as complex as blue or even red, but it is still a great triple.
Bottle. Apperance; dark yello, hazy with a big white head. Aroma; Fruits, with a flavor with fruits and yeast. Good, but not like the Bleue.

Pours golden brown with a big head.  Smell yeasty to me.  8% and you cant tell.  Smooth for a strong beer.  Not too much flavor in my opinion.  Slight caramel taste.  Glad I tried it, but wont buy it for some time.
From a small bottle. Wasnt able to finish the whole bottle, I think it was because of the lack of acidity.

Hazy golden in color.... Slightly fruity aroma... Slight bitterness in the flavor, yet smooth and drinkable like a wheat beer... Nice contrast from the brown sugar and sweetness of the Chimay blue... Still prefer the blue though...
In my mind, the best Belgian triple in the world.  Love it and could sit and drink 10 of them.  Nothin more to say except drink it if you havent already.

11.20oz bottle. This is my least favorite of the three Chimay styles I have tasted. It is a good example of a Belgian Tripel though I am not really that into Belgian Triples so I am not rating it as high as it probably should be. Pours a cloudy golden color. Yeasty and bready with hints of pepper.

The best tripel Ive had so far. This used to be my least favorite style of Belgian but after this I dont know. Light fruity aroma, with very cloudy, dark yellow with a huge white head. Flavor is fruity, sweet, hoppy and bready. Palate is medium, a bit chewy, and as smooth as it gets. Overall this beer is awesome.
Pale golden cloudy color.  Smells of fruit and tastes fruity and yeasty.  Nice crisp mouthfeel with a nice hint of bitterness.

Pours a cloudy orange-gold with a two finger white head.  There is a noticeable amount of sediment floating after the pour.  Aroma is malty, spicy, and yeasty.  Some fruit in the smell also.  Taste is malt, spice, a little orange peel, dark fruit.  Very good beer, but not as great as I expected.

bottle. Poured cloudy amber with sediment and off-white tight bubbled head. Sharp mouthfeel, very dry and a bit sour. Bitter peppery hop finish that lingers and warms you up a bit. Quite overpouring, a want to drink a different beer to quench my thirst made by this one.

Pale golden color, white head. Aroma of hops and malts, some clove spices and yeast. Flavor is very malty, but nicely balanced by the hoppy bitterness and a slightly yeasty taste. Very smooth palate, soft and creamy mouthfeel with a medium texture. A nice balanced beer.
Bottle and on draught. Nice golden amber. Nice amount of fruitiness. Nice and light. Slight punch to finish. Effervescent: The real champagne of beers. Actually, my favorite of the three Chimays.
From bottle. Pours nicely with a light amber colour. Very slight malty aroma with nice lacing.  A little carbonated for my taste. Very nice, semi-sweet aftertaste, almost bitter but in a good way.

Serving:  11.2 oz bottle coded 08-318.  Poured very slowly into my authentic Chimay glass.

A: Hazy deep copper.  Perfect marsmellow head.  This is probably the best head I have ever seen on a beer thus far.  Also, it stays thick and creamy the whole time Im drinking it.  Tons of bubbles racing around inside.

S:  Spice, fruit, hops, esters, bread/yeast.

T:  Sweet malt followed shortly by a firm hop bitterness.  Alcohol not evident.  Slight fruit, less than the Red.

M:  Medium bodied, oily, carbonated well, dryish finish.

D:  Just a tad bit less drinkable than the Red.  Could be due to more hops or less fruitiness.  Although it is still very good.

A little beerish somewhat chewy malt kind of smell with  pine and pine bark aromas.
Hazy knid of darkish apricot color with funneling action and some sediment suspension.
Sweet chewy pale malt, maybe same (Wheat) grain, taste with a hint of broth and grapefruit.
Medium bodied, smooth resinous feel, crisp and soft carbonation, with a dry finish.
Very drinkable, I know the Blue is popular, this might be my favorite of the bunch.

Bottle.  Poured a large, frothy white head.  Lasting.  Beautiful lacing.  Deep golden color, bordering on orange.  Nice haze expected of a bottle conditioned beer with visible, but not excessive yeast clouds.  A nice malty aroma - not overpowering.  A little bread and some straw/grassy smells.  Also a bit musty...perhaps from the yeast.  Pleasant, soft carbonation.  Nice flavors at the beginning - malty, bready and a little bitterness to balance it out.  Some fruity/raisiny flavor.  Bitterness is light, but picks up on the finish.  A distinct alcohol finish that lingers too long.
Bottle.  Golden with a huge white and long lasting head.  Aroma:  fruits, hops, spices  Flavor: fruity hops

Orange/gold color and hazy.  Thinnish white head, slightly above average for a tripel.  Aroma of hops, dark fruits (raisins) and spices (cinnamon and some nutmeg).  Flavor is hoppy, with light spiciness and some bittersweet effects in the finish.  Overall a complex and enjoyable beer.
Bottle. Unclear golden colour with a big white head. Aroma and flavour of hops, yeast, fruit, spice and malt.

Hazy golden pour with some lively carbonation and a huge white head. Nice fruity aroma (citrus mostly), some spice and honey also. The flavor does not live up to the aroma. Tastes like watery bread at first, tons of yeast and malt notes, eventually a mild hop/alcohol bitterness shows up to balance things out a little bit, but fails to save the day. There are some decent dark fruit notes in there - Im getting mostly raisin - but they dont stand up to the yeasty bread flavor. Mouthfeel is pretty lively, but not really exceptional. Im not really sure what to think about this beer. The appearance and aroma had me expecting greatness, but this one proved to be a bit of a letdown.
bottle - hazy orange brown beer with a beige head. Fruity yeast aroma. Flavour has a nice spicy bitterness, malty.
