Aroma is nice with cloves, citrus, and belgian yeast. Flavor follows suit and is nicely dry and slightly bitter along with the expected malt sweetness. Its been ages since I last had this beer and I must say I am quite surprised with how much I enjoyed it.

Aroma is slightly hoppy with floral undertones - very crisp and neat.  Pours with a nice white head that persists.  Nice lacing, cloudy body.  A sweet start with a bitter finish (which nicely disguises the 8% ABV), this ale is smooth and tasty.  There is something in the taste that makes me think of wildflowers...Light and creamy on the tongue with a tingling sensation as the bubbles from the head pass over.

Hazy orangey yellow with big and intense pale head. Nose is soft, gently wheaty and spicy. Same dry, earth like aroma as in Chimays port salut. Flavor starts malty and soft, but finishes dry and chalky with some hops and peppery spiciness. Very appetizing. Mouthfeel medium to full bodied with quite strong, but smooth carbonation.
Fairly fruit flavored beer that mixes well with  yeast. Slightly bitter aftertaste, but refreshing.

330ml bottle in namesake chalice.  Murky orange colour under a small fizzy head.  Sediment laden.  Aromas of orange,hops, dried apricot and yeast.  Fruit and pepper come through strong...alcohol is felt and welcomed all the way down to the gut.  Well crafted to say the least.
A család "fehér farkasa".Ez a legkesernyésebb a három "színes" közül!Egyszer jó lenne megkóstolni a "grandot" is!Addig is ennél maradok a testvérek közül.Egyébként bármikor jöhet bármelyik!

Pours a cloudy golden color with a creamy white head and some beautiful lacing in a trappist glass.  Great aromas of bread, hops and fruit.  Waited a bit for the head to settle before partaking, and the wait was worth it!  Fruit and yeast dominates. with some hops and an alcohol bite.  Finish is ever so slightly bitter.  Those Belgians have done it again!  Great beer!

Pours a hazy golden color with a white head. Aromas of bread, dough, flowers, grass and citrus. Excellent flavors of hops and fruitiness with a slightly bitter finish. Medium body with a creamy mouthfeel and lively carbonation that tingles on the tongue.  A very well made tripel, one of my favories.
Im not one for really fruity beers, but this one blends the abundance of fruit witha  good alcohol content.  Great aroma and taste.  Goes down smooth with some welcome aftertaste

Very hazy gold color. Lots of white head at the top, but I later found out that I stored it improperly (store upright, not on its side). Strong taste, cant tell the flavor, but its strong. I prefer Chimay Red more than White.

Pours a cloudy gold with a huge white head.  The nose is very fruity with bananas and candied orange.  There is a nice hoppy bitterness on the tongue and it finishes crisp with a nice bitter after taste.  Nice carbonation and the alcohol is nicely hidden.

The date stamp on the cork is 03/07.The beer was poured into Chimay glasses and produced a thick off-white head. The head eventually dropped to 1/4 inch but never faded totally. The beer is a highly-carbonated bright amber orange, and its quite attractive. (Food should please the eyes as well as the palate.) The aroma is surprisingly hoppy with a underlying sweet malt and hints of fruit. The aromas are precursors to the flavor palette. A complex blend of hoppy, fruity and yeasty. There are a range of spices lingering in there as well; pepper, cinnamon are noted. A faint candy sweetness waits in the background. The aftertaste has some drying bitterness with peachy fruitiness in the end. I found the alcohol to be very well-masked.
Large bottle. Hazy golden with white head. Floral! Quite high carbonization. A nice tripel that I can recommend to the person that enjoys tripels.
Botella. Comprada en supermercado. Muy buena. Gran aroma. Amarga. A pesar de lo bueno de la cerveza, no me conquistò.

pours hazy gold with very nice fothy white head,nice fruity nose hints of raisin,yeast.very nice aroma..aaaahhhh.tastes sweet at first.nice bitterness along sides of tounge and a dry bitter quick finish.Makes you want another drink.Very nice enjoyable beer.

very very heady, I didnt have the correct glass to pour it into and it was foaming all over the place. Definitely foams more than the the Chimay Blue. Very good taste, has a decent spice taste but much less than the Chimay Blue. The alcohol content is not as prevalent as the Blue. Would buy again.
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text:
Poured as usual into the ol Chimay goblet.  Golden in color, with a thin white head that leaves lots of lacing.

Smell is a bit underwhelming, with spices and mustiness.

Taste is medicinal with lots of spices and yeast.  Theres also a bright estery fruitiness.  Some booziness is apparent here.

Carbonation is a bit high.  Lightness in body contributes to the booziness taking over the palate with too much warmth.
It had a cloudy yellow body, slighty fruity, and slightly hoppy.  Needless to say, it was very well balanced.

Pours a hazy brown-gold color with a substantial white, fluffy head.  Aroma is of fruit and yeast.  Flavors include some spices, yeast, alcohol, citrus, hops, and it is a little bitter.  Quite good though.

11.2 oz. bottle.
Mmm! Chimay-may! This beer is pretty good, but for only 8% I thought that the alcohol taste was too prevalent. I think I prefer the other Chimay beers to this one.

Nice beer. bottle from Glenville beverage. Served 50 degrees in a tulip glass. Pours a dark, cloudy yellow. Huge, thick white head. Nice Brussels lacing. Smells of hops and yeast. Taste is definetly hoppy and a little yeast, maybe a little raisin. Nice beer. Ill get it again.

Ive had many a Chimay (and love them) before, but I just picked up a 3 pack to rate today, so ill start with the first.  Pours a cloudy peach color with a creamy white head.  Aroma is a bit faint, but I smell a little spice and bananas.  Flavor is the same, good overall.

33 cl bottle, hazy golden pour with large head that quickly dissipates to a fine ring, hopyy upfront with good fruity flavor, finish tailed off a little too much and became more bitter than I would like.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2008 Pours reddish gold with a consistent thick head.  Aroma of banaas, apples, raisins, and aromatic hops.  Well balanced beer.  Can definitely tatse the hops.  Bitter finish with some spice.  Excellent beer.

In the 330 mL bottle from Beertopia. Im surprised that I had not rated this one before. Lucky for me that Beertopia breaks up the holiday pack and sells these individually. Pours deep gold with an enormous concrete-like off white head. This head stays rock hard throughout the drink. It is almost a solid. The aroma is mildly fruity, but also has a bread dough scent like the baking of rolls. The flavor has a mid point sweetness that gives rise to a big orange peel bitterness on the back of the tongue that just sits there and gouges you. Plenty of black pepper on this one as well.

Pours a hazy blond apple cider color.  Small fizzy white head.  Nose of bananas, clove, yeast, and just a whispering of alcohol.  A great bitterness that is very light.  Some yeasty bread flavors with a nice fruity layer.  Leaves a pretty dry finish.  I know everyone loves the blue, but the white is definitely my favorite.
Big head, and cloudy amber color. More bitter and less fruity than the Blue. Aftertaste is also a nice hop bitterness.

Fruity weizen aroma.  Pours cloudy straw with a thin white head.  Alcohol is quite noticeable, very bitter.  Moderately dry finish  that seems to coat the tongue with a stinging spicy bitterness.  Not at all what I expected, more hop aroma and less alcohol would set this off.  Has its weaknesses but overall a powerful beer.

Poured an 11.2 ounce bottle into a Chimay goblet. Hazy orange with an enormous head that could have been eaten with a fork. Left an intricate lacing all the way down.
Aromas of moderate citrus hoppiness, with some spices.
Hops were much more evident in the flavor, which included spices that were probably peppermint.
Full bodied with lively carbonation, very smooth and highly drinkable.
An excellent beer, Im glad its readily available.

poured into Chimay chalice dark golden hazy appearance.  Beautiful delicate yet dense head.  Instantly, the distinct aromas of fresh hops and yeast tantilize the senses.  Velvety smooth texture in the mouth, making the palate want more.  Citrus notes with plum and raisin combine with a somewhat dry aftertaste make each mouthful a delight.  Harmonious balance.  Belgian abbey ales are truly superior.

0/33l bottle.  Big dense head, hazy orange colour,yeasty aroma with notes of vanila and mandarine.  taste is extremly dry  the with notes of vanila rose petals and mandarine. Aftertaste is long with a fresh lemony sourness. excellent balance.

Poured a very hazy honey-yellow with what looked like pulp. White head. Aroma is light but there are undertones of sugar and yeast. Flavor is definitely yeast with sugared lemon. Body is fairly light with just a bit of carbonation. Definitely a good tripel.

The bottle poured murky color like unfiltered apple juice, with off white, slightly peach tinted head. Pretty complete lacing. The aroma is sweet and yeasty, like a syrupy citrus fruit, like a mango danish. Absolutely delicious. Dry with a bitter bite like aspirin. Great balance.
Pale golden colored. Unclear. A  large white head lasting a few minutes. Spicy/peppery aroma. Soft fruity flavor with a sourish bitter aftertaste. Dry mouthfeel.

ive tasted a bottle of 75 cl 
ive served at 6 degrees the beer it is a unique combination of the fresh hops and yeast
the 75 version is softer than the 33cl
Bottle at home. cereal, spruce, golden, hazy, frothy, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, lively,

Messy gold color with rich, rocky white head with spotty lacing. Nose of citrus, orange, banana and belgian spices. Flavor is bright and crisp lemony-orange citrus with some hoppy bitterness. Finish is mildly dry with a bitter bite.

On tap.  Pours a golden yellow with a frothy white head.  Aroma of sweet fruits, some floral hops and yeast.  Tastes of citrus fruits, sweet fruits, yeast and alittle bitter hops round out this brew.  Great mouthfeel not to thick or thin... just right.

Solid head of foam, with a delicate aroma really entice you tosavor every sip of tis winner.  A very agreeable, mild, but noticeable finish encourages patient enjoyment of this light wonder.  The taste is quite balanced, without being overwhelmed by bitterness or any one ingredient--you can almost forget that this is an 8% alcohol brew.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2008 Outstanding. Beautiful golden hue, not overly carbonated. Needs to be served slightly chilled to bring out all the flavors. Hints of citrus and a significant yeast flavor, but blends together very nicely. Extremely well balanced, nothing is overpowering. My favorite aspect about this beer is that it is very easy to drink and not overly dense. I feel like I could enjoy a few of these without being slowed down. Very nice weight, and has instantly become my favorite beer.
On Tap.... nice creamy head that lasted. Had a nice citrus orange peel nose. Taste more citrus with a hoppy finish pretty good but expensive for a small tulip glass in columbus, oh.

Pours a caramel color with a medium-sized frothy white head/lacing and plenty of particulate.  Aroma is citrus, orange zest, a little lemon, banana, and some spiciness.  Taste is fruity, floral, and has a bitter hoppy finish.  Not as "bright" tasting as other Tripels.

330ml bottle, cloudy honey gold hue, with a fluffy white head, yeasty, fruity nose of citrus, with a hint of spiciness, a marmalade, orangey accent, bready dough, and a hint of sweet pale malt in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied, with a zesty, spritzy, fruity character, with some grapefruit, lemon, orange fruitiness, with a nice flowery citrus hop bouquet, with a faint honeyed pale malt accent, and kind of edible flower petal note, leading towards leafy dry hoppy finish.
Pours a hazy blond with white head. The aroma is sweet with honey notes. The taste is sweet but with a bit of bitterness in the finish.
750mL bottle.  Golden color.  Aroma of banana, bread, yeast.  Flavor is malty, bitterness in the finish.  More bitter than most triples.  Dry finish.

Poured a light golden color with a huge creamy head that left nice lacing.  It had a yeasty banana aroma with some slight nuttiness.  It drank in a similar fashion with presence of hops, cloves.  Kind of bittersweet, but not great.  Very strong, dry finish.

75 cl bottle from the cellar. Cork date was 07/2001. 
Pours a cloudy orange yellow hue. Has a 1 finger head which faded in a couple of minutes leaving a smattering of lace. The smell is of spices ; black pepper, lemongrass etc. The beer tastes like it was stored in an oak barrel ; a pretty strong smoked wood, musty, vinous taste with a hint of black pepper, cloves and oranges. Finishes with a tangey, dry hop tone. 
A most excellent Belgian pale.Dec 2003
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Had in Philadelphia, PA. Nice beer, but considering the price difference between it and other white beers, I see no reason to go out of my way to buy it. Hoegaarden might not be as good, but bottle for bottle, I can buy 4 or 5 of them for each Chimay.
tasted alongside the blue and red, this was the middle ground of the three. not bad but i will stick with the blue
Malty smell and a little bitter taste. Not Chimays best offering. I will stick to Blue.
Large white foamy head.  Golden color.  Aroma of malt and hops.  Similar taste with a nice hop bite finish.
Pours a hazy golden color, with a nice head.  Plenty of carbonation, and an overall good beer.  I liked this one, and will have again.

midddle yellow hazy golden with  with a offwhite creamy head
smells of malt hops fruit,corrianderlike 
smoothspicyness
tasts fruity corrianderlike
aftertaste spice and bittersweet

Wow!

Poured from 11.2 oz bottle.  Creamy off-white head and hazy amber color.  Lots of carbonation.  Very hoppy aroma with hints of a citric smell.  It barely reminds me of the wheat but it doesnt have the rotten banana flavor.  Very dry finish.

Sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel".  Pours clear orange/amber with a creamy off white head.  Malt orange and yeast in the nose.  Fruity flavors.  Toffee, caramel, earthy/ a little dirty with lots of alcohol.  Fizzy carbonation.  Meh.  Chimay has always done terrible in our blind tastings.  This one is not an exception.

11.2 ounce bottle. Pours a hazy yellow with a very large, frothy head. Smells of fruit and wheat with a hint of floral. Contained quite a bit of carbonation but did not take away from the overall taste. Slight lacing on the side of the glass due to the large head. Tasted of fruit and hops with a strong lingering of alcohol. A tasty beer!
Not a bad beer, but mine was just WAY to carbonated! It tasted like my mouth was on fire because of it. Actually I couldnt really taste anything except for the carbonation.

Bottle.  Fluffy white head & golden wheat color.  Strong wheat aroma with slight sweet & fruit notes.  Flavorful beginning heavy wheat flavor & slight spice.  Long middle strong flavors & fizzy.  Ends with a wheaty aftertaste with a slight alcohol flavor.  Balanced with strong flavors of wheat highlighted with with spice & alcohol notes.

330ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy pale orange with a firm, billowy head.  Aroma is full and somewhat tart, with citrus and floral notes at the forefront along with some hints of dark fruit, yeast, and honey.  Taste is full and tart, with strong initial notes of hops and yeast giving way to a crisper finish full of spice and a slightly alcoholic kick.  The caliber of the ingredients and brewer shows in this wonderfully fresh beer.

A thick, airy head crowns this beautifully unfiltered earthen-toned beer with an, admittedly, light aroma consisting of yeast and apples.
Extremely peachy with a lingering finish of bread and grass; not as robust as some of the other Chimay ales, but it has a complexity like none other.
Much like a champagne, Chimay is meant as a sipping beer.

In Belgium style bottle - Golden yellow. hazy unclear color. Fruity smell, spicey smelling and lightly tasting. Easy to drink, alc unnoticeable. Only bitter in after taste which is good. Easy to drink in large quanities. With all the compliments i could give this beer, i still enjoy the complexity of the stronger Trappist beers, including the Chimay Blue.
very tasty.  I waited a long time to try this one.  I was not disappointed.  wonderful aroma.

sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel". pours amber with white head. nose is yeasty, malty, mild fruit. flavor is extremely sharp alcohol and very yeasty. thin body, fizzy carbonation, oh so poor.

Nice big white head. Murky blond color. Wheat aroma with spices, yeast, and dark fruits.  Flavor is like a wit beer with the complex flavors of a strong dark Belgian ale.  Dry palate, vigorous carbonation, and a bitter finish.
Poured an excellent head.  Tasted fruity and what a delecious mouth feel.  It must be the water that makes these monk beers so good.
The "White" poured beautifully with the purest softest head Id ever seen.  Flavors were lightly fruity and slightly hoppy and it resonated in the mouth and palate.  Good strength and hue.

Bottle. By far my favorite Chimay. Nicely balanced aroma of spicy hops/yeast and sweet malt. Not too overpowering in the dusty/dry yeast category. Some spice (clove and cinnamon), hops (grass) and malt (honey and white grapes). Pours a nice looking hazy copper/orange with a big foamy white head leaving decent lacing. Hops, yeast and malt all play nicely on the tongue. A touch of honey sweetness, yeast spiciness and grassy hops. Medium bodied with decent carbonation.

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of yeast, spices, pepper, cloves, and a little syrup.  Poured orange/amber in color with a huge, foamy, rocky, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Lots of medium-sized floating particles.   Medium bitter flavor.  Tastes of pepper, cloves, yeast, and some caramel.   Medium body.  Average texture.  Lively carbonation.  Pepper finish.

An excellent beer.  Pours cloudy, dark anber with significant head.  Aroma is full and inviting, lots of spice.  Taste is delicious with a creamy, lively, palate. .   Lots of different spices in the nose.  Definitly a sipping beer.

Pours to an off-white, thick head. Initial taste was malty and creamy.Prevailing flavors of bananas and fruits. Finish was complex, roasty and sweet. Aftertaste was short and slightly bitter. Very good beer.

750mL bottle poured into a Tripel Karmeliet chalice.

It is a darker color of copper with a wonderfully rich creamy head leaving an excellant ring and spotty lacing on the glass. Yeasty aromas come through, as well as biscuits, bread, clove, nutmeg, and banana. Taste is much of the same with the alcohol hidden very well and just a bit of hop presence in the finish. Medium body with light carbonation that tingles nicely on the tongue. Very nice to drink, always a solid choice.

On tap at the Sharper Edge Bistro. Pours a light, cloudy gold with a frothy head that entices. The aroma is light citrus/fruit, spices and yeast. The taste is great: a spiced and fruit mix, a real presence of hops, a great bitter/sweet mix, and a strong dry finish. Really good. Easy to drink but also complex and well made.
Beautiful orange amber color with a nice head. Tastes of wheat, hops, apricots, raisins... good stuff. My new favorite Trappist style beer.
Very nice... as Borat would say.. thjs ties with the blue for my favorite trappist.... The only thing that sux about this is the price.  i=I wish it wouldnt run out.

Bottle: Pours light orange with a good thick head.  Aroma is nothing to write home about.  However, once you move past the aroma, this beer is great.  Full palate and flavor.  Malty with a fruity undertone.  Mmm good.

Bottle - Poured into brandy snifter (perhaps not the best choice, but just for kicks). Nice, pale orange color, great head. Flavor is excellent, with a malty fruitiness and hints of, again, oranges and alcohol. Beautiful beer.
Pours with a hazy golden color.  The taste is somewhat dry, you can also definitely taste the yeast.  Very enjoyable as a sipping beer, fruit notes in the aroma and taste.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy orange with a decent amount of floaties.  Small white head.  Aroma of orange and some grassy notes.  First thing I noticed was the huge carbonation.  It definitely gave me a jolt I wasnt really expecting (but not in a bad way).  Flavor was of sweet malts and a bit of yeast.  The finish was dry and peppery.  Nice beer.

Aroma of citrus, pine nuts, and some spices.  Appears a cloudy amber with a thick white head. Flavor is a faint citrus.  Palate is extremely smooth with no aftertaste - goes down very easily.  Personally I would prefer more flavor to the beer.

Pours hazy with golden colour. A large creamy head. A bit sour, slightly yeasty and fruity bouquet. Taste is a fascinating combination of sweet and sour elements. Flowery and fruity notes, some citrus and mildly yeast. Quite a lot of hops. Leaves a bit dry mouthfeel, just the kind that makes you want more.

Bottle poured hazy gold big pillowy head .Aromas of fruit (yeast) and spices. Nice clean mouthfeel good carbonation. Flavors of sweet fruit and malt with a lite bitter hop finish This is a soild triple not one of my personal best but solid none the less

Hazy golden colour with white, stable and foamy head. Aroma has some spices and flowers. Flavour is very hoppy, making it dry and bitter. Pine flavours. Lots of carbonation. Too bitter for me, looks and smells good though.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2008 Bottle from my new local offy. This is a lovely drink. Sat with my mate moby having a drink on a saturday. Ploughing through a load of average stuff and we had one bottle of this to drink which was a very welcome break. A lot nicer. Really really tasty. Like a lot.

This beer popped open and almost took my eye out before I even got the metal thing twisted complety off. This is the best looking bier I have seen in a while and leaves a pillowy white head on top with a lacing that "just wont quit". Smells fruity, hoppy, and clovey. It has a fairly suddle scent to it. The flavor is dominated by hops. It tastes fruity as well , but dominated by hops. I can see where it would taste awsome if I could get more fruity smell and taste to it. I wonder why it was so dominated by hops.
Bottle-Memphis. Hazy gold color with lots of carbonation. Spicy nose with cherry and apricot notes.  Very easy to drink and delicious.
Gift pack from LCBO, tried this one first. Pours golden brownish, thick head. Spicy/fruity/yeasty aroma all kinda at once. Flavour is about the same with a nice bitter finish.

8/12 0.33 l bottle at Hopdevil. Murky golden bodied with medium long living white head. Impressive strong orange and grapefruit aroma and malty with generally sourish unpasteurized feel. Flavor is more or less typical for Tripels, bitter with notes of sweet malts and very yeasty. Nice, you get as one would expect. Quite carbonated, didnt understand that thing. Long pleasant bittersweet finish. Very nice tripel.

Bottle from LCBO. Unless there was something horribly wrong with this bottle... then this was just plain horrible. Very offensive  to the palate, with a sharp mouthfeel. Unbalanced bitter domination in the brew with an undertone of generic lager-like taste. I was very disappointed, and expected better out of Chimay.
Very creamy mouthfeel... Hazy blond color, with more hops, this could have been great, as is... just really good.

From 75cl bottle. Hazy golden color with a puffy white head. Hops and dried raisins in the nose, extremely aromatic. A sour approach in mouth then becomes bitter at the finish, like an orange marmelade, in a good complexity. Light carbonated body that hides a strong alcohol content,but you will feel it afterwards. A wonderful trippel, that sets the standard for it.

0.33l bottle. Pours a hazy golden yellow with lots of visible carbonation. Head is quite frothy. Smells very nice, quite sweet. Very hoppy, but not overly strong. Taste is very strong, and I found it quite hard hitting. Rather sweet and a little bitter. Palate is a little thick and a little sour. The taste lightens up quickly and becomes much nicer.

Corked 750. Huge skunky odor. This stuff even tastes skunked. I didnt think skunkiness was possible in a brown bottle beer produced from hop extract. I couldnt even come close to finishing this one, so this is a mercy rating.
Pours a darkish orange with large head. Aroma of spices, fruit, and belgian yeast.  Nice sweetness, sour, finishes with just enough bitterness.
25.4 oz, and hand grenade; fruity and spicy flavor with an almost creamy smoothness to it.

Bottle (330ml). Poured an dark orange with yellow highlights, with a massive off-white head which was fairly diminishing. Aroma was big with sour musk and vanilla on the nose flowed by all spice undertones. Flavor was initially sweet with tastes of marmalade which came to a moderate sourness with clove like characteristics. Medium to full bodied with a creamy mouth feel and a light alcohol/astringent finish.

Bottle; pours a murky, dark gold with a lage white head.  Aroma of citrus, sugar, yeast and grain.  Solid, albeit not spectacular for the style.  Flavor was as expected; rich in malt, yeast and citrus.  Spicy and fruity notes were somewhat mellow.  Mouthfeel was fine.  My march towards rating the top 50 accessible continues...now I just have to get the "easily" accessible Westy 12.
33cl Bottle. Pours cloudy golden with thick white head and lots of lacing. Sort of citric aroma. Musky thick flavor. Harsh palate. I wasnt impressed.

My least favourite Chimay. bit too musky, and a bit of a weird, almost clay-ish flavour. 

I had it a while ago, to be honest, and dont remember much of it. I wont get it again, most likely. Chimay Bleu is better.
Aroma is not as strong as the Red, however it is still very rich.  Appearance is orangeish brown color.  Flavor is quite sour, but the aftertaste is smooth.   My least favorite Chimay.

25.4 oz. Bottle  Nose is slightly doughey with a bit of fruit.  Great looking kind of cloudy with a big head.  The flavor profile is really musky coming from fruity notes and hops.  Very well balanced beer, has a wheat quality too it.  Mouth feel is lively and the alcohol is much more apparent on this Chimay than the others.  Overall Id have another, but will mostly likely buy the red or blue over this one.  Really a fine well balanced and mildly complex brew.  Thank you Monks!

What a great beer!  Nice poor with a foggy gold color which settles well.  Great fruity aroma which carries through to the flavor and aftertatste.  Truly an excellent choice if you love Belgium beers.
330 mL bottle at Flat Rock Saloon.  Poured hazy orange with thin, fizzy head.  Mild citrus aroma.  Definite spicy, pepper flavor with a bitter finish.

Pours a slightly attractive orange-brown color with frothy white head.  Aroma of citrus, candied sugar, dark fruit, and yeast.  Flavor, as with the Chimay Red, is very subdued, predominated by citrus and floral hops and complimented by bready malts.  I liked this more than the Red, but not as much as Blue.  I still think Chimays flavors are a bit underwhelming compared to their great aroma and appearance.

Pours pale amber, cloudy. Large, thick head... good lacing. Aroma mostly citrus, some yeast. A tad fizzy (but not too bad). Taste is tart with coriander. Slight bitterness.  Finishes mostly clean. Very refreshing.

11.2 oz bottle purchased at Spirits. Pours with an incredible white pillowy head, what else would you expect from a Trappist ale? Slightyl hazy orange/amber with fairly nice lacing. Big yeast aroma with notes of grain and malt. Palate is rather dry with a slight alcohol wrming and a medium mouthfeel. Bready flavor with some possible notes of banana and a bitter finish. Stick with the blue if your drinking Chimay its worth the extra money.
Bottle 33 cl. Pours a cloudy golden with a medium white head. Taste is fresh, sour with hints of citrus, spice, yeast and some hope. Aftertaste is bitter but also metallic and a bit unnatural. OK

330ml bottle, 8% a/v From an LCBO gift pack

Pours a hazy orange colour with a thick, long lasting light tan head. Looks GORGEOUS. The nose is very spicy and reminscent of white beers, likely the yeast im smelling. There is also some malt present. The taste is very spicy and has a solid alcohol backing. Very hoppy as well. The taste is like a white beer that has been very generously dosed with hops. Personally I enjoyed this beer very much, but I can also see some people not enjoying it at all. To those people, send me the rest of your Chimay :-).

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2008 A very nice Triple, but I am not the biggest fan of Triples compared to other Trappist ales. Appearance is the typical Triple yellow with a big foamy white head. Taste and mouthfeel are very dry and not as fruity as I would have liked. I personally would select one of Chimays two other common offerings.
Bottled, a large off-white head, cloudy body. Aroma was light and lacking for a turn of a century trapest brew.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2008 Bottle: some fruity sweetness (banana ans sweet oranges), some spice, some yeast but mainly it’s a pretty dry beer, good dose of herbal hoppy bitterness all the way through, dry, almost metallic finish, very good beer.

Bottled 33cl. A hazy dark yellow beer with rich white head. Aroma is fruity and yeast. Notes of orange and banana. Taste is sweet and spicy. Peppery and alcoholic mouthfeel.  Some bitterness in the end.
Bottle at Eulogy in Philadelphia.  Poured a golden orange with a lacing off-white head.  Citrusy aroma.  A potent rich dried fruity flavor, sweet.  Rich creamy mouth feel.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2007 From Chimay, another nice ale.  Well balanced with the nose and aroma of a fine triple abbey, but with the loving care of a Trappist beer behind its near perfection in it class.  All in all a good ale.

Bottle, aged 1 year in my closet.  Pours a cloudy gold/tan color with a large pillowy head, dissipates after a real long time.  Aroma of pepper, grass, hay, coriander (even if its not actually in this brew), a little doughy malt and just a little pleasant alcohol heat.  Smooth flavor is a bit more caramelly at first, with some grapes(chardonnay-like)  to follow.  Some wheat and grass flavors occur, followed by bitter pepper and spice.  Finishes with a slight bit of doughy malt and that grassy bitter pepper flavor.  Some sort of sweetish earthy flavor in there too, but the aftertaste is rather pepper.  Medium mouthfeel, highly carbonated, but keeping this bottle for a year really softened up the mouthfeel nicely.  One of the nicer tripels out there IMO, but not as good as Westmalle.

Poured this into an actual Chimay glass that came with the set. Thick white head, champagne in color.  Very bubbly.  Smells of zesty hops.  At first, slight strong on the palate, but then subsides in a nice aftertatse.  Alochol apparent but not overpowering.  Had a mild smokey flavor, I think.  Overall, a  top notch beer.  Probably one of the priciest beers around, but hey you get what you pay for. Would love to try this on tap!

2 ounce sample at 99 Bottles, Federal Way, WA.  White head.  Little lacing.  Lightly cloudy body.  Melted butter color.  Major aromas and flavors include light nuttiness, slight mustiness, hint of lemon, leather, spices.  Primary flavor is lemony-mustiness.  Fairly dry and slightly bitter finish.  Good.  Reminds me of old books, which is a wonderful thing.
Golden and a little cloudy.  Not as rich or full as some, but dry and peppery and nice.  Warming feeling, the alcohol is only barely hidden.
Foamy head, nose of pickled ginger, muscat grape. Sweet and sour. Crisp, deep, round, and full. A bit of woodsmoke with the muscat grape finish.

Had this beer on 3/7/2007.  Aroma is a light sweet malt scent that reminds me a bit of a White.  Color is a pale hazy gold with good carbonation and a nice tight head.  Taste malty, crisp and bitter.  Starting with light/medium body it goes down crisp and fizzy.  Finish comes in with a mild malt flavor and a faint hop flavor then it ends with a nice bitterness.  After there is a slight fruity back tone.  It just doesnt have that fruity yeast taste that is in the other two beers.  Would be a great beer for a nice summer afternoon.

This beer pours a light yellow and slightly golden color with lots of head formation typical of this style.  Aroma is light, perfume-y and champagne-like, with abundant clove-y spiciness.  Flavor is also light, alcoholic, and flowery with abundant clove notes and yeasty flavors.  Quite nice.

Recommended.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2009 I love Chimay Blue and Rouge, but the Blanche just has a sour Hefeweizen taste. Had this stuff on tap at The Venetian. The flavor was a crisp start mellowing into a yeasty flavor. Dont get me wrong - this was fairly decent. There was just this aftertaste that wasnt hops and wasnt alcohol. SECOND ANALYSIS: Has the flavor of fresh scotch tape - and this isnt a bad thing! Nice Tripel, but not my favorite of the genre. Still has that back biting bitter flavor, which has grown on me.
Aroma of yeast, coriander, and banana peels. Mouthfeel is strong and dry.  Flavors of white grapes, golden raisisns, and some bread crust.  Finish has estery banana and citrus noes.

Pours a cloudy gold-brown with a loose, frothy, beige head that laces nicely. The aroma is of yeast, pear, apple, citrus, white grapes, candy sugar and faint alcohol. Medium-bodied and fairly lively with a yeasty dry finish and a touch of alcohol warmth. The flavor is citric and yeasty with spice/pepper layered over raisin and apple. A decent enough tripel, but I was expecting more from this one given Chimays reputation. At $4+ for a 33cl bottle, I doubt that Ill be coming back to this one any time soon.
Excellent beer. Pours copper with a lightly yellowed thick head. Aroma of citrus and pine/clove spiciness. Tastes slightly clove up front with a quick bitter finish. Milky texture.
Golden/Amber colour with a bubbly white head. Yeast, hops, citrus and raisin. Creamy with a bit of carbonation and a slightly bitter aftertaste. Very Nice.

On tap at Milltown, Carrboro. Been a while since Ive actually had this, and it remains delightful. Beautiful looking cloudy orange in a Trappist glass, with a healthy and substantial head. Lots of spice and a tad of citrus in the aroma, and the mouthfeel is quite lustrous. Awesome dry finish is a bit of a surprise, but makes this dangerously drinkable. Fine stuff.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2008 Im quite partial to Chimay white. Refreshingly simple character, clean dry finish, mild bouquet, hazy appearance, and good mouthfeel (tho at times a little gassy) but with a killer yeast profile that totally removes it from sweet tripel hell and takes it more into the realm of saison. Welcoming, quenching, accessible beer.

On tap at Three Floyds Brewpub, and served in a Chimay trappist glass.  This tripel poured a clear golden/orange color with a one-finger thick, tight head of white bubbles.  Some very nice lacing was left around the glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of lemongrass, slightly spicy yeast esthers, and also some notes of orange peel.  The flavor consisted of spicy and bready yeast esthers, orange, caramel, and also a touch of light lemon.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied and full of lively, crisp carbonation.  A very nice beer, but not on the same level as the Blue.

Pour is a cloudy blond with a large white head.  Aroma is yeasty and creamy.  Flavor is some spice and lemon with some yeast following up. Finsih is very creamy and smooth.  Still this is just average as nothing really stands out.

750, corked and baled. Pours medium coppery amber with a towering, bubbly platinum-blonde head. Ample lace on the way down the glass. Crisp but mild nose of hay and lemons--understated and lovely. Nice lightish medium body, super clean and drinkable. Bit of sharpness to the mid-palate, seems to be from the hops. Theres a nice herbal hop cling to the finish. This is a crisp beer in every way from popping the cork to the last swallow. Wonderful stuff and a world classic thats more than earned its lofty reputation.
A fun beer in a fun glass high ABV and it is TASTY belguim white, I wish they were all this M m m m m!!

11.2oz bottle.  Aroma is yeasty with a little fruit.  Huge white head that mostly diminished and left good lacing.  Hazy medium orange amber hue with lots of tiny particles.  Flavor is yeasty and sweet malts with a short finish.  Palate is medium bodied and lively.  I couldnt pick up any hop notes and the bitterness wasnt that noticeable.  Nothing great here, no reason to try again.

On tap.  Pours an amber color with a white head.  Aroma is of lemon,  spices, yeast, and some caramel malts.  Light on the palate with lemon, spices, and yeast being the stronger flavors with a background of the caramel malts.  Finishes with only a slight hint of alcohol warming.  Very delicious.

Poured a lot like an ale (transparent  orange-brown) but has a huge, cloudy and slightly off-white head.  Aroma was light and perfumey.  Fresh rain, evergreen, and lemon.  Distinct and amazing.  The flavor is exceptional and the palate is incredible.  Subtle yet very complex.  Taste is champagne, not quite yet ripe orange, leather, and soap lather.  Despite the fact that these dont sound like good flavors, this is an amazingly unique flavor.  The finish is smooth and slightly yeasty.  The flavor is mellow in the finish with plenty of time to enjoy.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2008 Poured into trappist glass from bottle. Wonderful spice and light attractive aroma.This tripel is definitely a sipper though. As tripels go, its one of the best. Pillowy dense head like a heavenly cloud. Drinks incredibly smooth yet with real depth and substance of flavor. Certainly a bit syrupy not unlike most other tripels. Well-hidden alcohol for a trippel and a finish that manages density and silkiness with definition. Very good.
On tap, from old notes.  Hazy deep amber with light tan head, initial flavors of ripe fruit and subtle spiciness, aftertaste is laced with caramelized sugar and earthy hops.
Hazy amber beer with nice big head. Aroma of flowers, wheat, coriander and fruits. Fruits and orange peel dominates the flavor. Very refreshing.

Bottle: Trappist Glass.
One of the nicest commercial ones from Belgium.
Great murkey looking nut-orange colour with a great big white head. One of the best balanced flavours. Hints of Hops, fruit (Not too much) and of course yeast, but like I said well balanced. Almost as good as their Grand Reserve. Laceing is ok, not the best as it gets a bit thin, but with dynamics like that, who cares??? Good carbonation, not to effervescent, slightly creamy. A truly well rounded one to savour and enjoy.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2008 Pours bright orange with fluffy white head.  Head dies down, but remains through drinking like a lid on the brew.  Mells of malty yeast.  Taste is smooth and full with orange, hints of lavender and subtle mint.  Orange/peach finish.

on tap
A great tripel that steers clear of the often noted offputting fruity linger in the finish. Nice balance of malt and yeast flavors with the bonus addtion of a clear note of spiciness to add to the richness. Certainly a benchmark tripel.
To me, this is definately one of the Triples to compare all other Tripels to.

For me one of teh best beers ! 
Cloudy dark golden color. Nose of fruit, yeast and hops. Taste fruits with raisins and some alcohol. Good in balance.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2010 330 ml bottle. poured cloudy golden with a huge froathy white head. aromas off yeast, hops, citrus fruit and spice. wonderfully balanced with no trace of the 8%. a truely great drinking experience.

Bottle. Pours deep orange with strong fruity aroma. Nice creamy lasting  head.Taste is somewhat spicy with notes of plums. Carbonation is good and not over the top. Overall very balanced and a joy to drink.
Dry, hoppy, and even grapey, almost wine-like flavor, but very nice.  Medium body.  Very good.

Poured burnt orange, head bubbled away.  Heavy fruit aroma.  Hits the mouth with mild carbonation and malt, finish with hops and very dry.  My least favorite among the Chimays, but good none the less.

As with Chimay Rouge, it was this asrsenal of Belgian beers that first introduced me to the world of Trappist brews. I like the other Chimay brews more than the tripel however, every time Ive had this beer, Ive felt a bit overwhelmed by alcoholic tones with an unbalanced mix of yeast and light fruits. Many other Trappists out there better to search for.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2008 On tap at Delilahs in Chicago.  Golden with creamy white head.  Aroma of spice, sweet malt and alc.  Flavor was very spicey, cardamom, though orange and other yeast notes, alc, very fruity, medium sweet, nice.  Creamy, medium body.  Overall a very nice beer with a little too much alc.  -------- as part of the blind "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel" tasting.  Cloudy orange amber with thick white head.  Orange and yeast aroma with slight malt.  Flavor is sharp alc with yeast, orange, aged red fruit and raisin.  Fizzy carbonation with medium body.  And alcy mess with horrible palate.

Dark golden color with a thick white head.  Esters and phenols strong in the nose and get stronger as the beer warms.  The fruityness is caried over in the flavor as well as the spice and alcohol.  Quite tasty.

A peachy orange pour with a surprising mild off white head. A pungent corriander smell that really isnt as pronounced as I would have expected. A spicy flavor with hints of clove(I know it isnt clove but that is what its like to me) It has a hint of bitter on the finish. Good carbonation and solid mouthfeel. Crisp clean beer that is solid all round.

1pt 9.4 ozer in trappist glass, saffron hue with slightly frothy creamy lasting white head, excellent lacing, hazy, bananas and clove, lightly carbonated texture, slightly bitter, slightly dried fruit/grape tang, a bit straw malt and soapy yeasty, not as hoppy as description.  After skunky bitterness lasts in hind of mount.
A cloudy golden colour brew. The nose gives away the intensity of the brew. Notes of fruit, raisins and plums. Some apple in the taste with raisins and some alcohol. A very well balanced beer.
bottle. Golden with frothy white head. Aroma of mimosa flowers. Nice lacing, tastes of orange, spice, yeast, fruit.  Noticable carbonation, good mouthfeel and length.  Nice beer.

On tap at Map Room, Chicago.  Maybe Im not a Chimay person-- I wasnt overly impressed.  Although it does have a unique, musty flavor.  I suppose its a classic flavor, but I dont have a palate for this particular Belgian.  I prefer Tripel Karmeliet over this beer.
UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007 11 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Fort lauderdale, FL. $3.79 Very good.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2007 Bottle conditioned and courtesy of the LCBO. Drank before after the Chimay Rouge so I could compare these two styles from the monastery. Pours a burnished gold with an effervescent white head, which diminishes to leave moderate lacing. Smells of fruit and spice, but lighter than the rouge. Initial mouthfeel is very pleasant and reminded me of raisins and grapefruit. Bitterness kicks in as the liquid hits the back of the mouth, and I imagine this would be a good accompaniment to rich foods, as it would clean the palate of any fats. Its tough to pick between the white and the red, as they are both well-made and complex beers, but my personal preference leans towards the spicier taste of the red. Now to find a Chimay Blue...

330 mL bottle. Pours cloudy gold. Aroma is alcohol, corn, dates, and dried fruit. The nose hits fruity, carmelized apple and raisins turn into a hoppy, alcohol bite. Undistinguished spices complement the transition. Feels different at the front of the mouth than at the back. Complex. Medium long finish. Medium body.
33 cl bottle - Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a large off white head.  Thick lacing.  Aroma and flavor is esters and yeast.  Medium body.  Smooth mouthfeel.  A good beer.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2009 old rating:
6/4/7/4/16 - 3.7

pours a cloudy amber with a large white head, and good lacing.

smell of fruit, bread dough, sweet, and a hint of citrus and spice.

taste is sweet, almost a pink grapefruit, yeast, spice, white pepper, and light malt.

Bottle into glass.  Nice frothy head that left plenty of lacing. Aroma of grapes and just general sweetness. INcredibly smooth drinking with the alcohol detectable at the finish.  Carbonation was a little high for my taste.  All in all just an excellent beer.

Had on tap at Brews in Granville. Poured a grainy golden color. Smell was mostly hops with a hint of fruit.. Taste was bread, oranges, cinnamon, and grapes. Very good, but of the three, I still prefer the Red.

Bottle. The beer poured with a hazy, orange-gold color with a huge pillowy head that left a lot of lacing on the glass.
Slight citrus and bread aroma. Slightly fruity flavor with a bit of hop bitterness and citrus. Of the Chimay Red, White and Blue, I think this is the easiest drinking of the three. Very good.

330ml bottle 
8.0% ABV 
I tried this beer on September 13, 2007 at Smokeless Joes in Toronto.  The beer poured hazy brown with a large generous whitish head.  The aroma was a combination of malt, and fruits.  I was expecting yeast, it was not there.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied, crisp, with high carbonation.  The flavour was malty with some bread.

33 cL bottle. Pours hazy orange with a huge huge off-white creamy head. Lovely spiced yeasty and caramel malty aroma. Soft caramel flavoured with a small spice note breaking through in the beginning. Goes into a more yeast and spice dominated flavour. Ends slight bitter and spiced. This is by far my favourite chimay and one of the best belgians of all.

From thee Horsebrass Pub-Poured a deep and glowing grainy yellow.  Vinous, bready with a candy bar/medicinal/yeasty . Lively and evidently bold alcoholic head. Smooth enough to burn you.  Boozy vapors in the finish.

750ml bottle.  hue is of a tangerine peel mixed with a slight rust and accented with a golden autumnal haze.  head is fluffy at onset, then reveals an average belgian over-the-top foamy head.  aromas accentuate yeasts, and dry oak with back-end spice notes. dried raisins and apricots are there, but not pronounced at all.  as it warms, the citrus style fruits arrive to the forefront, as does a hint of alcohol.    for a tripel, it actually has notes of smoke and tfruit; an interesting combination.  very carbonated, as expected from the belgain style.  the taste also reveals a complex bouquet of fruit rind, mainly lemon and orange, perhaps some starfruit on the tail.  the spiciness is more pronounced here and strings through to the finish.  for the complexity and depth of character, i give it an A+; however, this is a beer to covet, and not a beer to match with anything other than Chimay cheeses, or high quality craft cheeses.  this isnt a food beer, but more of a sampler brew.  It is interesting to not the yeast differences which translate to subtle taste differences, though pretty straight-forward.  also, as the ale warms, the flavor profile changes; the sweetness increases, but so does the hop presence.  Drinkability is (un)fortunately not at the highest level here.

Tap. Great yeast aromas of dough, mustiness and damp basement, moderate hop smell of lemon, and a light malt note of light bread, with a mix of spices. Head is creamy/fizzy, white, with excellent lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is a slightly hazy gold/orange. Flavor starts moderately acidic and the long finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic and heavily bitter. Palate is medium, creamy with a touch of slickness, and the carbonation is lively. It finshes on a strong astringent note. Another Chimay Ill be having more of.

11 oz bottle from Bevmo. Pours a cloudy rich orange-gold with an ample white head that fades slowly. Aroma was light and slightly sweet with some bread yeasts. Flavor was pleasantly biter with a hops forward effect, rounding out the flavor was some spice, walnuts, vanilla and sweet candied plums. Mouthfeel was full, smooth and creamy. Finish was long and extra sweet.  I downgraded the flavor rating because I don’t care for the overt sweetness. Overall, this is a most intriguingly crafted brew. I may drink it again for desert or after-dinner.

330ml bottle. Deep gold colour with a tight, moderate white head. Aroma of sweet malt, spice and oranges. Flavour was cloyingly sweet with apricots, and some hops in the finish. Good but there are much better tripels out there.

This is an awfully good beer.  Its golden in color, and has floral aroma, almost like an APA.  Taste is smooth, and a nice balance of hops and yeast.  Feels like most of it was absorbed into my tongue.  Very good.

Pours a murkey dark golden colour with a creamy white had that has good retention. Aroma has some light notes of fruit and spice but is prodominately yeast and dough. The flavour starts out with a light fruity sweetness and a touch of spice in the middle which quickly gives way to a bitter hop bite that lasts long after the beer has been swallowed. The mouthfeel is near perfect, creamy and foamy, and smooth. A top notch brew.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2010 33cl bottle from systembolaget in Lund.   Pours a murky golden amber with a lasting white head that leaves good lacing.   Aroma of banana, caramel, and cinamon, with a pronounced yeasty doughiness.   Flavor is much of the same, but with a cloying sweetness that takes over and runs with the flavor.  Theres some hop presence, but overall not enough to balance the sweetness out.   Body is thick and smooth, with lively carbonation.   This is a decent brew, but my least favorite of the Chimays.   Red is smoother, and blue is more complex.   This is my first tripel, so maybe Ill give it another shot. 

Rerate:   Draught at The Red.   My tastes have definitely changes since first sampling this back in Lund.   Nice tropical fruit and spice in the nose.   Definitely not cloying like I thought back then, but not dry for the style.   Probably my favorite of the three now.(8,4,7,4,15=38)
33cl bottle again.   I got this one in the gift pack as a christmas present.   I havet had this in awhile and though it fitting to sit down and reassess it.   Cloudy gold-orange with a medium-large white head that leaves some lasting foam and light lace in my Duvel Green tulip.   My first impression is of the mouthfeel--it is quite chalky and dry.   Bitterness seems to stand out, as well as alcohol.   The aroma is quite yeasty with some banana and orange peel, along with some herbal and spicy hops.   The flavor is lightly sweet up front and then herbal and quite bitter in the finish.   Dry and chalky in the end, with a touch of alcohol.   Its pretty funny to look back on my original review and see that my complaint about the beer was that it was sweet, though maybe it was much fresher in europe than over here. Definitely not as clean feeling as the draught version.   (7,4,7,3,14=3.5)

Poured with HUGE head and nice lacing (still staring at me from the empty glass). Color was a tad darker than other Trippels Ive had. The mouthfeel on this was perfect. It kind of foamed in my mouth...just perfect amount of carbonation. The flavor was a tad weak in my opinion, but a solid trippel nonetheless. What struck me about this beer was the hoppiness that Ive not seen present in many other Belgians.
While this beer is a very good one, it has a strong flavor which is done just right, Id say this is their hoppiest beer.  If you drink a Chimay you cant go wrong.

Pour is a cloudy haze of gold color with a really great head that clings to the glass and wont go away.  Piquant aroma of yeast with some hops and fruit.  Flavor is just ok, spicy with a long dry finish.  Not that impressed.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2011 
Name: Chimay Cinq Cents (Gold)
Date: November 28, 2002
Mode: Bottle
Source: Stones River, Murfreesboro
Appearance: Hazy dark yellow, big frothy white head
Aroma: sweet spicy aroma
Flavor: dry malt flavor, lots of spicyness, no trace of alcohol

Name: Chimay Cinq Cents (Gold)
Date: March 23, 2003
Mode: draft
Source: bardo
malty, spicy, bitter, why is this beer so overrated?

Name: Chimay Cinq Cents (Gold)
Date: June 23, 2005
Mode: draft
Source: freakin frog
Score: ii to i
light bitterness, light fruity malt, very drinkable, but still boring

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 2/10; Overall: 5/20
Rating: 1.8/5.0Score: * /4

The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Pours a dark and cloudy apricot, full of lovely pearl necklaces of carbonation and topped by a big ol sudsy head.

The aroma is hops, coriander, tangerine, and (!) rubbing alcohol.

The mouthfeel is smooth, with medium carbonation.

The taste is aspirin, bitter hops (big on this), tangy grapefruit, cookie dough, butterscotch, a smidgen of coriander, and not much sweetness at all.  As it warms, it becomes more cider-like.

Pretty solid, but it likely would improve with age.  I was a bit disappointed because I enjoyed Chimay Red so much, but oh well.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2009 330ml bottle. Pours a really attractive hazy-golden colour, with a sizeable white head. The aromas are subtle, coriander, spice, bread, all covered up by an umbrella of yeast. The flavour is as usual a blend of all of the above, a little rough due to the alcohol burn, but at the same time with a subtle hint of dusty smokiness, surprisingly. Fruity sweetness is prominent, melon, mango, pineapple etc. Its not overly smooth, though somewhat creamy, but I like the fllavours and there are a lot of them to be appreciated. The finish is very dry, and my only complaint is the lack of banana flavour. The yeast signature here is just awesome though, seems vaguley dank at times, and actually this beer makes me think of Orval, just without the Brett. Weird but awesome.
Good beer by all accounts but cannot hold a candle to the Blue Cap, I wont complain about drinking it though.
Pours a burnished gold with ample white head.  Aroma and taste of banana, white pepper, and spice.  Nice bitter finish.   Dry.  Better than I remember.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2007 My least favorite Chimay, but still pretty darn good. Pours a light golden orange  with foamy head. Hops and dried fruit make up the taste with a slightly bitter finish. Let it warm a bit and it opens up beautifully.

Bottle at Dæmningen - shared with Mette. Cloudy straw yellow - white head. Aroma: Aples, fruity, light yeasty, sharp licorice. Taste: Bitterness, spicy, yeasty, citrus zest bitterness, light cardboard. Bitter dry finish !!

poured into Chimay Tulip.  pours a semi cloudy gold with full frothy head.  light smooth crisp aroma, slight sour notes.  yeast front with smooth almos dry finish.  slight bitter finish.  smooth and light, great with food.

Pours a very nice light golden color with plenty of yeasties in it.  Smell is belgian yeast with a hint of alcohol.  Taste is spicy with some more belgian yeast and a bit of funk going on.  In my opinion this is the best chimay of the three.  Full mouthfeel and creamy.  Nice.

750 ml bottle. Freshness date not noted.
Hazy golden with a large sticky white head.
Aroma is fruity and floral, with notes of grapes, raisin, honey, and a touch of citrus zest. Gets a little boozy if allowed to warm too much.
Flavor is sweet, honey, fruity, floral, bready, with a nice  long dry finish to balance it out.
Al-tho the alcohol is apparent in the aroma, it is well hidden in the flavor.
Very pleasant brew to drink. Lots of flavour and aroma. Alcohol is well hidden. A little bit of too much of a dry aftertaste for me however.
One of the better whites. While you can buy Chimay Red, White, or Blue about anywhere in the U.S., I still remember drinking it on tap in some pretty lame bars in San Francisco.

Golden coloured, mostrly lasting head (medium bubbles), leaves a long finishing flavour on the mouth. Its aroma and flavour combine perfectly and is its highest point. Sweet, but not too much. Alcoohol at the very right mesure.
Way too hoppy.  Now that Ive had all three, I can say without a doubt that the red is the best.

On tap @ Falling Rock poured a clear gold with a large lasting white head. Aromas of fruitiness, spice and a hint of honey. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of bread, light fruitiness, light honey and a hint of spice with a smooth dry finish.

33cl bottle. Pours a hazy peach colored body with a pillowy giant white head that quickly fades away. Spotty lacing. On the nose I get raisins, white grapes, tangerines, banana and bread dough. The flavor is intense: grapes, figs, raisins, citrus, yeast and floral hops. Medium bodied, somewhat sticky on the palate. Finish is spicy, bitter and medium in length. A disappointment overall as I quited liked the Rouge.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2007 Just wonderful! One of the beers I would need to have a barren island.  Chimay White pours a beautiful head, with a nice cloudy burnt golden color. The beer has a complex aroma and with subtle hints of banana. A leaner Belgian triple, if one could be called such a thing. Nice balance of bitterness and wonderful use of yeast, As a matter of fact, it really demonstrates why yeast is such a important ingredient in brewing. Cheers to the monks!!!

11.2 oz bottle poured into tulip glass. Aroma is of sweetness, bread, and fruit. Head is ample and creamy. Color is slightly cloudy gold. Mouthfeel is excellent, typical of great Belgian ales. Easy to drink with no indication of 8% abv. Some fruit flavor (especially raisin) present throughout taste. Also a little tartness. Leaves a good, however brief, aftertaste.

330ml bottle.  Pours a hazy straw/golden with a beautiful creamy head.  Aroma is some floral hops with yeast, apricot, and some pepper.  Flavor is peppery yeast, some raisin, apricot, and banana, as well as some bready malt.  An excellent tripel, one of my favorites.
bread, golden, hazy, white foam, peppry finish, medium bitterness, medium body, soft carbonation, long finish,

Golden hazy colour with a large frothy, white head. Aroma is mostly hops and yest, maybe with hints of fruit and caramel, but with a definate hint of coriander. Nothing exciting. Carbonated, rich, but smooth, palate. Flavour is surprisingly rich compared with aroma. It tastes of all that was within the aroma, but much richer. What the flavour has, that the aroma lacks, is this really rich and defined peppery finish. The high alcohol level is not to be traced in neither flavour or aroma.
Flaske. Ekstrem lækker tripel. Farven er lys uklar gul, og duften er af gær og en smule banan. Smagen er hmmmmm.

on tap @ the small bar in chicago. golden in color with a wispy thin white cap. a dry bready aroma is present with a touch of sweet grain and brown sugar. lightly fruity hints of peach and apricot. nice oily mouthfeel. good toasty characteristic with a fine caramel middle. a floral and aromatic hop bitterness rounds out the finish.

Cloudy golden poor with a thin sticky and bubbly off-white head. Aromas of citrus,  coriander, green grapes, fresh hops, banana peelings and pears.  Nice longlasting bitter mouthfeel.  Slightly less sweeter than the aromas lead you to beleive.  (green) Spicy flavors that i cant put my finger on with hints of white pepper?... Surprisingly great beer!
My first foray into the Trappists when doing graduate work at LSU, and still a favorite. Fruity flavor, hazy with sediment, I still favor it over the red and blue...maybe its just sentiment.

Aroma is strong and mouthwatering, and has a definite fruity overtone, either apple or pear. It pours a nice clear yellowish amber with a thick and somewhat persistent head. Flavor is about equally malty and hoppy, with a strong fruit hint; I noticed an unpleasant metallic aftertaste, though. Maybe this was just a bum batch. Other than the metallic bite, this is a very good beer.

11.2oz Bottle
$3.69
Sams Downers Grove

Chimays tripel pours a murky, hazy orange that turns more golden when held to the light. Some sediment but its very small and just makes for a hazy body. 1+ finger white creamy head that recedes to a half finger and leaves lacing on its way down. Thick drink lines after each sip.

Smell is quite fruity with peach being the main component along with pear and green apple. A doughy rye bread maltiness struts around in the background. Yeasty spiciness swirls around and is subtle at times while standing out at other times. Theres a darker somewhat heavy sugar quality along with wildflower petals.

Flavors transition seamlessly up front. Peach and pear start things off along with a helping of candi sugar. Even some creamy banana. Doughy malts and a mix of spicy alcohol and a spiciness from the yeast show up mid palate. The spiciness follows through to the finish where it meets up with a slightly sticky sweetness. Dusty yeast character on the swallow.

Medium body with a creamy texture as it hits the tongue. A little too sticky for a tripel, for my liking anyways. 

Easy drinking tripel. My glass is disappearing pretty quick. Good fruity flavors make for an enjoyable sipper.

A solid tripel from one of the few remaining Trappist Breweries. An enjoyable treat when in the mood for a slightly heavier bodied tripel.

7/22/07

Golden cloudy color. Has a white and abundant head. The aroma is with many yeast and spices (piquant).
The flavor is very agreeable, the hop is exquisite. The end is very good, fruit-bearing, lightly an acid. Undoubtedly, a very good beer.

Stubby bottle from Cardinal.  I love the red cap Chimay, so I was looking forward to the white cap.  I must note that I do not care for this particular style in general.  The conditioning usually boats me too much, however the effects are usually stellar.  At any rate I poured this extremely slow, still yielded a 2 finger lasting head.  To me this was all spice.  taste was mostly crushed black pepper, with a hint of orange underneath.  This ale probably has the biggest contrast between the initial taste and the back end...Its a good quality brew, just not my cup of tea...

Pours a dark hazy gold with a thick off white creamy head. Aroma is grainy, banana & citrus (orange, red grapefruit?) Flavour is delicious! Sweet yet tart with a hidden alc flavour that comes out near the end. Notes of citrus fruits, light honey malt sweetness, a dry bitter finish that has a hook of alc. at the tail.

Bottle. A hazy amber color with a nice white head. The nose is of mainly a spicy orange hop combo. The flavor actually seemed relatively normal to me - some fruit characterisitics and spice but just a couple notches better than the average.

First beer I tried at Houstons Flying Saucer.  I had always heard of Chimay, but I wasnt all that impressed with this.  It was just a pretty average, malty beer.  I was hoping for something similar to a Wit Beer.

A golden beer with a fluffy white head. Some honey and yeast aroma with floral notes. Sweetish flavor initially with honey notes and, more faintly, some orange zest. The European hops add some real dimension and mild bitterness in the back--something that too many big, Belgian tripels lack. Forget the Chimay goblet, this is really nice swirled around in a big snifter glass. I wish as many bars carried this as carry the red and blue.

My favorite variety by Chimay...it has a light cloudy appearance, with bubbles flowing upward in a singular stream, with obvious crisp carbonation. Taste is sweet but bitter at the same time, a coating layering itself upon the tongue but then melting away, leaving an aftertaste of grapefruit and candied orange rind. Probably my favorite tripel thus far, I measure all others to it.

[448-20070726] Sample @ LCBO-Summerhill. Buttery yeasty wheat field aroma. Hazy, orange light brown body with a long-lasting creamy white head. Dry and fruity orange flavour initially with a sweet malty aftertaste. Medium body left a strange alcoholic kick in the last sip. Vaguely reminiscent of a candy from childhood.
the first trappist beer i tried and still one of my favourites.  It has a complex yeasty flavour always an enjoyable experience

This comes across super dry and really salty. Very hard to drink. I like my tripels with more sugar and less bite. Pours the typical yellow color with a big bubbly head. Smells like brewers yeast. Not that great.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2007 Slightly reddish gold (the red was perhaps due to slightly dim lighting), hazy, with a large plume of white suds that took a while to settle down. I detected vinegar when I first started to smell it, but that quickly gave way to a yeasty mix of fruits, especially banana, with something like peaches as well as raisins. Also, contrary to the commercial description, I found that the smell was slightly acidic, but that didnt really matter to me. The taste carried sweet fruits at first: peaches, nectarines, and raisins, if I were to put a name to the flavors. The finish was slightly bready and bitter, and all of this was surrounded by a general spiciness and mild/moderate banana tones. I liked it all very much. It was pleasant, dynamic, and refreshing. Although it is an abbey ale, this one is not so strong or complex as to capture your full attention like some of the others do, yet it retains skilled trappist craftsmanship and is certainly worth trying more than once.

Pours a hazy light gold color with a huge, well retained, foamy light tan head.  Smells of mild candy sugar, a little spice, citrus fruit, and yeast.  The taste has a nice spice character to it, a little sweet, but the spices somewhat dominate the sweetness.  Just a slight little bitterness at the end, but nothing bad.  Tripels are usually a little boring to me, but this has enough spiciness to it, that it keeps it interesting.  Solid.
pretty good tripel but a little too sweet for me. get the rochefort 8 over this. the caramel is just simply too much

Bottle conditioned, 330ml, aged 6.5yrs. Clear gold with white head. The beer was obviously still working in the bottle giving a full spicy, slightly caramel rounded flavour. The flavours had amalgamated into a slightly over rich puddingy type taste with a touch of brandy on the back of the tongue. Nicely fruity on the finish, lovely.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2008 330 ml bottle - pours hazy glowing orange with a good-sized white head.  Aroma typical Belgian spiciness - yeasty goodness.  Flavour is what sets this one apart.  Banana, raisins, peach, almond, anise, some fresh bread.  Dry, steely, mildly bitter finish.  A very delicious (and unexpected) citrusy hopping in this one.  Solid, solid stuff.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2011 Deep hazy amber with a fine sized head. Nicely bitter aroma with toasted malt and esters. The flavour is well balanced, earthy bitterness, a little sharp, restrained malt and quite dry. Nice medium to full body but a little over carbonated. A decent beer, maybe the nicest of the Chimays.

From a bottle this poured into he Chimay glass a hazy golden color that looked kind of like honey.  Nose is kind of mild, with banana the main aroma with some yeast and mild hops.  Mouthfeel good but not exceptional.  Flavor good and fruity, with a nice long finish that has just a hint of bitterness. Not the blockbuster brews of the Red and Blue, but nevertheless quite good.
Not my favorite Chimay.  Much more bitter than the other two with much less of the fruity flavor.
Pours a nice cloudy goldern color with a soapy white head.  Aroma of bananas, hops and some yeast.  Taste matches the aroma.  Not quite as good as the blue, but a worthy drink.
UPDATED: JUL 16, 2007 a very drinkable beer for its alc% and cloud, and unlike many of the better Belguim beers, its not too hard to find in your liquor stores.
i tried this last night and i did not care for the taste of this beer at all.

I love the cloudy secret look of this beer. the head is thick and rich, aroma full of promises.
Taste is full of fruits, honey, almonds and cinnamon even. 
Dry and bitter finish, almost salty.
A great beer.
Solid tripel, different than other tripels in its lighter body.  Dry, with some green fruitiness.  Finish is dry hops and pale malts with some sugary sweetness.

You cant say anything about this beer thats unique from any other tripel.  It pours a cloudy golden color with a white head.  Aroma is largely of cloves and banana, with a taste that has the same, along with sweet and hop notes.  Solid, solid beer.
Not as good as the blue but a pretty strong entry for a great brewery. A great looking beer with a nice head. A bit hoppy and a bit sweet at the same time. very dry finish. Very good.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2013 A hazy, orange beer with a strong and enourmous and white head. The nose is fruity, slightly sweet, spicy, bananas and hops. Taste is quite dry, fruitfull, bananas and lots of spices, some flowers. The end is quite dry and hoppy. High carbonation but its reduced quickly into the reasonably level. Quite dry, tastefull, spicy and easy-to-drink trappist with much of character.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2007 fra le tripel dabbazia non è certo la migliore, e si aggiudica anche la palma di peggiore esperimento Chimay. Tuttavia abbastanza bevibile.
comprata da Squillari, pagata 2.50, una piccola delusione, considerando che le altre Chimay in fondo non le disdegno. Questa in giro si trova meno spesso delle altre due... per fortuna!
Very strong alcohol flavor for being 8%, must be the tripel in it lol. Good malts and a great balance of spices. Tastes like a traditional abbey brewed belgian.

Pours golden honey colour, hazy, with ample white, fluffy head. Good head retention  and pretty lacing. Fruity hoppy aroma with touch of banana and trappist yeast. Flavour is very fruity with some malt sweetness balanced with hop bitterness. Finishes crisply dry with pleasant hop bitterness. Alcohol well disguised. This is a classy brew.

Aroma is of banana and yeasty. Pours a hazy amber body with a foamy with head that last long. A spiral formed pilar of bubbles is rising from the middle of my Chimay glass, very beatiful. Flavor is fruity with a strong taste of hops. Its a spicy taste of cloves. Bitter aftertaste from the hops. Palate is very carbonated, but it fits vell with this beer.

Bottle -- Golden honey colour with very fne carbonation. Pours with a huge, sudsy white head with lots of retention and lacing. Aroma is hops with citrus and flowers. Flavour is superb, with fruity sweeteness up front and a pleasant bitter finish. Gorgeous alcohol glow! A very fine brew.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2009 Hazy golden with huge pillowy white head.  Flowery hoppy bouquet with whispers of spice and banana.  There is also a yeasty, bread/wheat scent which adds to the intriguing aroma.  The taste is wheaty, hoppy and simply wonderful. The end is my favorite part, with a crisp finish that begs for another sip. I remember very my first Chimay Tripel  and it was perhaps the first "real" beer I have ever had.  It has a special place for me and it remains a personal favorite.
xxx What needs to be said about Chimay, great brewery, great beer, never a bad batch.
Hazy orange.  Big foamy head.  Nice lacing. Good mouth feel.  Nice Lighter Tripel.

Easily one of the better Trappist brews available. A lovely coppery/golden appears in the glass while a fairly large white head fills the remainder of the glass. Citrus is evident in both the flavor and palate.Finishes very crisp and clean  that leaves a desire for another glass, and since its 750ml, you can.
330 mL bottle.  Clear golden amber with a big fluffy white head.  Sweet fruity aroma with notes of sugar and alcohol.  Bright clean palate.  Sweet fruity taste with a slightly bitter finish.

11.2 oz bottle.  Poured a hazy light orange color with a huge billowing stark white head, which left behind foam remnants.  White pepper, orange peel,  and sugary sweetness on the nose.  The sweetness leads off the taste, with the Belgian yeastiness filling in afterwards.  Finish is dry and has a weak sourish thing going on.  Overall, not my favorite tripel, but certainly a classic interpretation of the style.

11.2 oz bottle.  Clean, "pure" nose, foamy head, much darker than I expected- an orange amber color.  Much softer on the palate than most tripels- flavors are a bit more subtle.  After a few sips, the alcohol really hit- wow.  Very nice beer overall.

11.2 Fl Oz bottle.  Pour is a slightly cloudy orange yellow with a big, slowly fading white head.  Some carbonation bubbles as well.  Aroma is a bit skunky until it opens up to a yeasty, bready malt and a hint of hop.  Taste is a bit sweet orange peel with a nice hop finish.  Real nice body to this one.  A bit of the skunk and funk re-appeared on the after taste.  I am not convinces this was well cared for / fresh bottle.  The alcohol is pretty well masked in this one.

orange pour slight copperness to it, nice fluffy full tan head. it has a fragrant citrus floral aroma. the body is viscous with small crisp lively bubbles. it tastes mostly of carmel malt with some oranges and coriander and a nice and light bitterness. beautifully balanced and well rounded beer

large bottle as shown. Poured a hazy golden color with a medium white head that stays. The aroma is citrus and hoppy. Nice lacing with a very sweet taste and a crisp finish. Another glorious brew from chimay.
Golden colour, Much light scent on trappiste side. Well balanced and fresh taste taste but you can feel the acholhe at last. Beautifull beer with beautifull taste.

Good belgian, apricot color. More ember then i expected. Lightly smells of yeast. Long alcohol finish, may have been a little too carbinated. Tastes of delicate hops and hints of orange, tingles the tounge.
On Draft in Paris. Honey colour in the glass with a medium sized head. Flavours of wheat, honey and noticiable alcohol. Long alcoholic finish. Very enjoyable.

Orange-honey colored cloudy pour.  Large lumpy white head.  Fairly high carbonation.  Aromas are orange, yeast, mild spices, white wine.  Taste follows suit.  Very sweet, almost like a yeasty, spicy, citrus syrup, but balanced out fairly well with mild hops.  Very good beer.  Pairs well with spicy foods.  Refreshing.  I go back and forth between this and the Blue for my favorite Chimay.
your run in the mill chaamay, nothing to complex here pours blond with thick creamy head light lacing

Oranangey, golden colour with a thick white head. Aromas of citrus fruits, hops and nutmeg. Taste is similar with tart apple pie, bitter hops with a well balanced dry finish. Not as good as complex in flavour as chimay blu but a good beer

pours with an enormous white head, took a while to get to something manageable to drink. lots of aroma of orange which transfers to the taste in the mouth too with some delicate hop tastes too, very pleasant, kind of tingles on the tongue. complex finish, some breadiness, yeasty too

Huge rocky white head, lasting with perfect laces. Misty and spritzy orange body. Sweet citrus, yellow apples and hayish hops in the aroma. Clean and fresh taste; dry malts, mild and noble bittering hops, weak but pleasant fruitiness. Medium -bodied. Crisp and dry mouthfeel. This beer was one  of my first Belgians ever tasted. Ooh,  its so nice... reliable, and very enjoyable.

Had on tap-heaven...was poured in an actual Chimay chalice glass with a great head. Dark rich warm blush-rust color, held the head for a nice period...slight fruit, spice aroma. Starts smooth and melts on tougne, small hops bite, great finish but does not coat mouth with aftertaste...leaves you ready for next drink. Thank God for monks.

Bottle. Drinked it at Oveja Negra pub. Golden colour, nice white head. A little bit fizzy at the beginning. Aroma is sweet, apricot anda candy... Taste is caramel but citrus as well. Spicy. It has the charactreristical flavour of belgian yeast very well combinated with the flavour of hops. Bitterness is excellent. Finish is great too, dry and alcohol in the aftertaste. I agree with some comments here, carbonatation is a little bit high. But in sum... is a lovely beer!!!

750ml bottle - Golden in color, and hazy.  Thick white head which dissipates fairly quickly, after a minute or so.  May be due to the glass Im using.  The aroma begins as a hoppy, almost citrusy tone which becomes fruitier the longer you draw it in.  Nice body with good maltiness, the flavor begins with an initial sweet fruitiness that becomes spicy, and finishes with a nice dry, hoppy bitterness.  High carbonation, maybe a bit too carbonated.  Long finish with an alcohol warmth.  All around a very nice beer.

Draft - Slightly hazy dark golden body, beautiful lasting creamy white head, elegant lacing; Beautiful fresh and complex nose, very elegant balance of malt and hop, great; Soft textured body with slightly sharp carbonation, bitter and slightly sweet; Long finish quite bitter of both malt and hop, lots of aroma. Great fresh, very drinkable beer.

(33 cl bottle from Systembolaget)Best before 2009.Ive never been a fan of the White Chimay, but had this sit for a few months to see if perhaps it turned out better.Lots of co2, almost on the brink of gushing. Pulls the sediment up from the bottom of the bttle.Shady ornage color, big tan head.Belgian ale yeast, spicy (clove mostly) and hints of smoke scent. Some milk or yogurt as well.Rather spicy yeasty taste, also dryish and some paper.Spritzy mouthfeel, low bitterness.Alcohol aftertaste, also warming.Didnt do any great success with that short storage, got another bottle that Ill leave for some 2 more years.

Bottle from the LCBO. Ive had this particular bottle on hand for quite some time - 2 or 3 years, Id guess - but it still seems to be in nice shape. Pours a slightly hazy sunset golden-amber with a good sized snow white head. Aroma is fruity and slightly yeasty, with some tangy sharpness in the background. Great body and mouthfeel, very nice. Flavour starts fairly sweet, developing some spiciness in the middle, and finishes with notes of yeast and a surprising hit of hops right at the end. Complex enough to be interesting, but balanced enough to be very easy to drink.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2012 75cl bottle. hazy honey colour with a lively head. Bubbles everywhere. Smell is fresh, citric with a blend of apricot, banana and apple, held together by a wheaty heaviness, like brown bread.
Rather bitter-sour. I get all kinds of promising sweet, fruiy tastes in the beginning which mix well with the bitterness. Slight alcoholic twang.
Hazy amber color.Thick white head.Floral fruity aroma.The flavor has an early sweetness that gradually turns spicy then to bitter.The finish is a lingering bitterness.
Pale amber, hazy rich head. Banana aroma. Lively and complex. Very flavourful and fruity. Peppery
750ml bottle.  Deep orange with nice head.  Fruity sweet with a bitter hop finish.  Excellent.

Ive only had a few tripels, but this one blows them all away.  Doesnt hurt that I had it in one of the best bars Ive ever been to, the Toronado in SF.  Go if you get a chance.
