UPDATED: OCT 11, 2009 Bottle.  Sweet aroma - apple, peach.  Orange tan color with small head.  Light peach/apple flavor with moderate acidic/astringent finish.  Subdued but sublime - a great beer.

Glowing golden orange pour with a huge, explosive, pillowy  white head.  Typical Chimay style.  Some lace.  Vibrant nose...there is a subtle fruitiness.. cloves, raisins, yeast and hops.  Flavor is clovey, yeasty, lemon rind, and a  dry,  bitter finish.   This brew has a good malt and hop balance to it and a fresh and lively feel..very refreshing.   Carbonation is high... it has a good medium body and a simple, but attractive, flavor palate.
Very good tripel, but nothing noteworthy over and above La Fin Du Monde, which is a lot more reasonably priced, in my humble opinion.

This is a popular triple for a reason. Pours a great golden color in the glass. Tastes of banana, raisins, cloves. Zesty lemon and orange. Very yeasty, which plays along with the hop for a refreshing bitterness and spice. Surprisingly warm finish.
Maybe I got an old bottle, but this stuff reminded me of a slightly stronger Old Milwaukee. I was very disappointed

Bottle as Cing Cents. Poured a hazy golden hue with medium creamy white head. Aroma was complex with malt and citrus. Flavor was a moderate sweet with the same complex long finish. Creamy full body. Good brew.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2008 750 ml, correct temp. trappists glasses, and certainlly leaving the yeast at the bottom of the bottle.
Definantly a world classic beer.  A fine example of what yeast can do.  Absolutley spectacular color in the goblet, thick frothy head that will not budge unless the sweet nectar below it is sipped.  A complex plateau of what must be sterling hops and exotic citrus and asian spices. Very clean malt balance and crisp refreshing finish that pleads with the drinker to have another sip.  It is the devil, such a rare and special beer that goes down so easily and quickly.  You would never guess this beer to be 8%.  I cant tell you where they hide it, but those monks make a fine beer.  There really arent  too many beers around that a novice and an expert can both enjoy and love.
smell is awesome, flower, oranges. tastes like fruit, a pinch of alcohol and cumin. a really well done tripel with good thick mouthfeel and a lingering bitter and fruity finish, yummy!

Bottle. Rated this after a bottle of Chimay Blue (bad idea). Looks absolutely beautiful, slightly cloudy luminous light gold in colour with a huge rocky white head the sticks around and leaves plenty of lace. Aroma is medicinal and flowery. Taste starts with sweet malt, with a medicinal middle and a dry and slightly bitter finish. Mouth feel is exquisite; they have done a great job of balancing the viscosity from the high levels of alcohol with fine carbination. I should have tasted this before the Blue. Think I will re-rate the Blue now, I need to give it more credit for subtly and balance.
Magnum bottle, year 2000. Malted, alcoholic and a very long end. A very nice foam, stable and long. Bitter taste. Cloudy.

Bottle: Pale Orangey Coloring with Big White Creamy Head.  Fruity Aroma with Yeastiness Hovering About.  Carries Through to the Palate.. With Light Subtle Spices and a Comfortably Heavy Mouthfeel.  Very Good But a Beer You Have to Be in the Mood For.

Bottle. Great Belgian. Pours a cloudy orange/golden body with a nice thick white head in a Chimay glass. Lots of sediments. Yeasty aroma with some fruity, hoppy scents. Medium mouthfeel. Spicy flavor. Alcohol can be detected. Chewy. Smooth, warm finish.

In my opinion not one of the better Belgian tripels. Cardboard and grass nose. Notes of grain and wheat on the palate with some mild funkiness. Mild sour apple an pear flavors overpowered by the cardboard.

Bottle Pours a hazy light yellow/amber with a hugh foamy white head.  Hevy lacing. Lots of visible carbonation rising up.  Sweet light malts and belgian spice in the aroma.  Some notes of warm toast w/ honey.  Flavors are much the same but sharper and more bitter.  Lively carbonation.  Very light grain and slightly sweet malts, almost pilsnerish at first.  The immediate aftertaste is where the hops and bitterness kick in.  A marked transition.  Finish is quick and fairly dry.  The ABV is not very noticeable.
Bottle.  Light fruit flavored aroma.  Orange/tan hue with a long standing white bubbly head.  Light taste with a slight bite at the end.

This beer poured a cloudy orange color w/ slight head and lacing.  The aroma had a slight citrus note w/ light fermented fruit, apples, and grapes.  The flavor had pretty much the same, but it was thinner.  The mouthfeel was light and creamy.
Huge head from the bottle, which I expected from the style.  Its got a fruity aroma, but its taste fails to match up to the other Chimays I have had ( but not rated ).  Okay, but I expected more.

Pours a cloudy sediment filled apricot color with a creamy head and lace. Aroma is a balance of fruity and floral with some yeastiness. Flavor is initially fruity then a bit peppery and orange peel bitter with a smooth bitter finish. I would say the spiciness dominates the flavor but the finish is terrific. Light and fizzy in the mouth and has a pretty strong alcohol burn in the belly. Very good stuff and looks awesome in my official Chimay glass I got with it.
Draft at San Diego Brewing Co.  Rich golden color with a very nice head.  Aroma of citris with a decent flavor to match.  The only problem with this beer was the price I had to pay for it.

Still not bad.

Sometimes I really crave this beer... but it usually falls short in satisfying my palate. This beer pours a nice murky golden color with LOADS of sediment and a monsterous pillow for a head. Good overall mouthfeel. This brew has a nice light citrus flavor but it lacks in complexity. Still, its a good ale.
This is a good tripel. Not as spicy as the rouge it was much clearer in the glass. This beer offered up a stronger aroma of orange peel.
Very good example of a triple, too bad I had to go to Tennessee to get it.  Poured into a Chimay glass on a cold winter night  and it just made the winter blues melt away.

On tap this pours a hazy golden color with a medium long standing white head that leaves nice lacing behind. Spicy crisp aroma of corriander, clove, bread, and citrus fruits. Very well balanced with a lot of crisp/dry snap to it, citrus flavors throughout with some orange peel and spice in the finish. Great brew that is very floral on tap.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2008 Bottled. Hazy orange colour, huge foamy off-white head. Aroma is caramel, some wood, earth and mildly spicy. Flavour is yeast, hops, some wheat and also some alcohol. Alcohol isn’t burning bad though.

A fantastic beer in my humble opinion.  Huge hoppy aroma imediately from the bottle.  Beautiful pour which shows off its amber cloudy body and huge white head.  This disipated pretty rapidly, but the tast left behind was amazing.  Slight alcohol touch is the only negative thing about it.  Loads of hops with a very sweet malty depth.  Some strong yeast is present, as is a sweet spicy aroma.  A hopheads delight!

I found a few of these in a box Id forgotten about.  The cork read 12-93.  If that means this ones from 1993, it held up very well over time.  Pours a hazy orange with a small white head and lingering lacing.  Smells of cookie, caramel, hay, straw and citrus with hints of grass and alcohol.  Tastes sweet with a slightly bitter finish.  Very good.

This beer exhibits a wonderful head and lace that is typical among many quality Belgian brews. The nose is very big with a yeasty, spicy, and woodsy character. The palate is rather dry, light and airy. I must say this beer drinks somewhat like a brut Champagne. As for the palate, it is amazingly complex and well balanced. Finally, the finish is long bitter and utterly refreshing. This beer is obviously the most overlooked of the widely available Chimays, but I think it nudges out the red label by a hair.

Pretty beer with the typical clean trappist head.  This IS a trappist ale that I could enjoy without feeling guily that I was wasting something precious.  While it is by no means an everyday drink, it is very easy to drink, and the subtle fruitiness makes it quite pleasant.  After having the Blue, I do enjoy the Blanche more.

Pours a hazy orange/gold color with a good amount of foamy white head and a lot of carbonation.  Aroma is sweet, raisiny, with some hints of spices, yeast, and citrus.  Also faint notes of alcohol - rumish almost.  Flavor is bitter and raisiny sweetness with a finish of alcohol.  A lot of carbonation dancing on my tongue.  Overall, pretty good, but a little harsher than I expected after having previously tried the red.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2007 This pours a light, golden, unfiltered, amber with a lively white head.  The nose is of mahagony and a bit of white cheese with fruitiness.  The mouthfeel is very smooth with a wonderful lighlty citrus peel yeast flavor and a nice tingy hops finish.  The bitterness is somehow only medium, but the hop flavors seem to dominate the tastes.  The nose and tastes are very much floral and perhaps hint slighlty of unripe bananas.

Excellent beer, quite easy to find in france. Strong alcohol% for a white beer but not a problem, as the taste is complex and intense, with some flower, spice and banana. To be drank in the original and very nice Chimay glasse.
Not what I expected from a good trapist,  wonderful aroma noting of fig and plum and raisn hops, great complexity very carbonated. Not one to buy all the time but a good brew.
UPDATED: JUN 25, 2005  nose is fruity  with yeast and banana. quite nicely round in the mouth, very light bitterness in the finish, leaves a taste of banana.

Not overly impressed by this Chimay one. The aroma is absolutely wonderful, strong plums and raisin mixed with equal quantities of hops and malt. From there it goes downhill though, appearance is orangey with a gassy head. I didnt really taste much complexity or interest at all in this one, just an overly carbonated mouthful and pleasantly bitter hops with a sweet aftertaste. A perfectly nice beer but none of the complexities or cacophony of tastes that you come to expect from trappists.
Fizzy, cloudy pour.  Complex, hoppy aroma and the taste of hops and black licorice.  Highly flavored on top of the normal hops and malt, a very nice but intense brew.

Pours a Hazy copper, thicker head with some lacing.  Aroma is both hops and malts, the first Ive encountered both from this brewery in the bouquet.  Flavor is less complex than my other experiences with the style.  This one comes across as sweet, has the requisite full body and very strong malty flavor, as well as a nice bitterness, but the alcohol wears out its welcome in the flavor.  It covers up so much, that Im missing much of the spice and fruit that I expect in this style. I catch a little banana and clove right at the end, but thats all.   While it may in fact be a Tripple, its missing most of the best things about the style.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark orange color with a giant foamy head and  beautiful lacing.  Aroma is estery and honey-ish with notes of gingerbread.   Mouthfeel is carbonation, then some more carbonation.  There is still some complexity although I notice a reduction in that department since the mid 1990s.   Agressive bitterness is still a quaility as is the long and dry aftertaste of bitter orange.  Not the champ it once was, but still better than most.

Poured from the bottle by the barman at Galbraiths (and a great pour it was too). Amber colour with a big full head.  Sweet malty aroma, also wheaty.  Taste a winey sourness I often find with these types of beers (maybe tart is a better description).  Quite spicy as well.  Enjoyable, though I found I enjoyed these beers better from the tap when I was in Belgium.

Tasted 21/02/2005.  330ml bottle from Regional Wines and Spirits.  Batch LAK-565, BB 12/2006.
Pours a bright orange gold.  Appears effervescent with a huge ballooning off-white head that shrinks to a pillowy, pocketed, creamy appearance.  Appearance becomes murky as the yeast dregs roll in.  Lacing is thick and long lasting.
Nose is spicey and spritzy - you can feel the carbonation in your nostrils!  Some hints of breadiness.  
Flavour is peppery sweet, slightly winey and definitely yeasty; and is delivered in a light but soft mouthfeel that carries millions of tight tiny bubbles.
Palate, which is left warm from high alcohol, has hints of bitter orange, spices and wine.  Very different from my last abbey tripel, Tripel Karmeliet, this one is a lot harsher.

Finally get around to rating this one.  In the past I was unimpressed with drafts served at Monks.  This rating is for the small bottle (with dinner at Azure).  Benchmark tripel:  richer and fuller body than Golden Monkey and Fin du Monde; lighter on the spice; and malt, yeast, hop and spice flavors are all much mellower and blended than GM and FdM.

Hazy golden ale with discrete floaties and a thcik luscious white head.  Nose of coriander and yeas, with a touch of alcohol. Sweet yet in a restrained fashion, with hops domineering quite well over malt,  lingering coriander, bitter oranges, creamy in outh and complex. A  classic. Santé aux voyageurs des papilles!
330ml bottle. Pale golden with large white head. Vanilla, banana aroma. Quite carbonated. Bitter, orange flavours. Excellent, complex beer.

Beautiful pale gold color with excellent aroma.  The taste is full of fruit sweetness at first and then balances quickly into a great yeast/hop aftertaste. The feel of the hops lasts awhile but is pleasant.  Excellent head retention that does not dissapear.

Bottled. Cloudy amber/brown colour, big frothy head. Spicy, nutty, coriander and some cardboard aroma. Malty, nutty, slightly citric, yeasty and pretty bitter taste. Ends in a nut-bitter finish. This reminded me of Westmalle Tripel. Medium- to fullbodied, good mouthfeel, nice texture. This is quite a nice and interesting brew, but the weird spicy flavours, somehow prevenetd it from being completely enjoyable to me.
very nice and i think, underrated triple.  i also like this more than chimay red & blue. (but i also love those two)  a great beer.
The sweet spicy aromas accompany the thick head and cloudy ale.  Another of the superb brews fom the Trappistes.  I sampled the small genade shaped 330ml bottle.

I love the general aroma of Chimay beers.  This one has more character and complexity than the sweet and straightforward Rouge and is better balanced than the rather over the top Blue.  It is leaner cleaner and more interstingly complex than either and has a fabulous refreshing mouthful of hops!  This is the first beer I have rated here.  I’ve given it the maximum rating in every department because over many years of trying and comparing hundreds of beers, this is my absolute favourite and has been so for a long time...Duvel is similar in some ways and is second in my personal ratings, but does not have the almost miraculous WOW factor of the white-cap Chimay.

Pours out to a nice golden-orangeish color with a lasting creamy white head.  Smells a lot like the other Chimay brews, with hints of dark fruit (plums, raisins) leading the way.  Starts out only slightly fruity with a little bit of orangey flavors.  Spicy hops follow.  Finishes with clean, medium bitterness.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2017 Feb 2017
Possibly best showing for me. Bitter orange rind, abusers, candy fruit late. Serious beer and cant always accuse a triple of that trait.
Bottled: 2007
Tasted: January 2009 (13/20)
I havent had a great track record cellaring triples and this is no exception. Looks fantastic; massive billowing head, pure white, and a nice apricot coloured body. Chunky lacing too. Nose shows mild malt sweetness, some spice and a touch of aniseed. All very faint. Palate is dominated by fizz and light, but dirty, sweet malt character. Finishes surprisingly dry with a mild aniseed edge. Not much to advocate further cellaring, let alone hanging onto it for as long as I did.
Vintage: 2004
Consumed: Feb 2005
Good head, spongy, thick.  Cloudy burnt orange in the glass - nice. Subtle nose, some clove and spcie but not overt. Palate weight is a surprise given the nose; more spice, alcohol sweetness, some heat, big mouthfeel and drive.  Does get progressively lighter through the palate.  I felt it also had some ale characters hanging around the side which added to the complexity.
Looks beautiful, with a large pearly white head and deep golden colour. Very good aroma, which unfortunately isnt followed through in the flavour. My least favourite Chimay.

On tap Sophies Davis, CA. Quite delicious. Complex, yeasty, malty delicious; what else can you get from a fabulous Tripel? How about a smiley head, a brew as exciting to sniff as to roll off the tongue. Great stuff. And they only charge you six bucks for this Trappist brew served in the appropriate receptacle a Chimay Trappist. Perhaps a deal found only in a college town?

75c cl bottle w/ cork & wire. Served in Chimay goblet. 

Great appearance: hazy gold with big, stable head. Fresh, spicy aroma and flavor. Refreshing and yet full in taste. The typical Chimay yeast is present in both aroma and flavor. A very nice tripel.

I sampled the 0.75L corked and caged bottle typical of this variety, the uncorking of which for me is a much loved ritualistic event.  The bottle poured brilliantly gold, effervescent, slightly hazy and with a huge snowy white head.  But the head disappeared fairly readily, leaving some decent lacing and revealing a rich aroma of ripe banana, raisin and honeysuckle.  Initial palate is slightly sweet, fruity and characteristic of white grape raisin, orange rind and spice.  The finish is tart with light hop bitterness and hint of alcohol.  There is a pleasant and dry, but brief, aftertaste.  This beer is near perfect served at about 48-50F; very nice.

Hazy golden in color with a huge frizzy white head, this is a dandy tripel.  One of the more nicely hopped Belgians, this also carries a strong fruity aroma, dried fruits and orange peels.  Theres malt in the bottom of this, but this soft-bodied drink tastes of malts, spices, a yeasty fruitiness, some alcohol, and nice hop bitterness.  Finishes on a slightly tart, bitter, alcoholic note.  Nice.

A Rolls Royce of a tripel. Poured a cloudy golden colour with an appetising thick tan head. Lots of yeast in the light, fruity nose. Some strong orange peel characters. Medium-bodied. Some citrus in the middle, plus some darker, winey notes. Its surprisingly quenching in the mouth but with a lingering heavy hit of alcohol in the finish. Terrific aperitif I imagine.  (Bottle)

This is better than Chimay Blue, for sure, but does not compete with the Rouge.  A darker tasting brew, it looks lighter than the Rouge, with a nice caramel colored head.  Not as complex as Rouge, but more so than the plain, average-tasting Blue.  This is a nice brew, but I wouldnt drop the bucks on it again.
This tastes of a quality beer, and looks the same. It is cloudy, golden, and free, though expensive (I did not pay). The taste is pleasant and mellow and I prefer it to Chimay Bleu. Woohoo.

Im not a Belgian beer expert by any stretch, but if someone asked me to describe a Belgian beer - Id simply tell them to try one of these. Excellent in all respects. Great foamy white head, excellent floral and fruity aromas, and very good flavor. To me at least - this is "the" Belgian beer!
Pours a hazy golden with a huge white head. Has aroma of yeast. Tastes of fruit, yeast, and hops.

poured a deep golden color with a thick lasting head.  constant flow of carbonation bubbles.  great floral hoppy aroma!.. good flavor of hops and malts with an addition of yeast flavors. nice alcohol finish.

Chimay Glass night at McNellies (buy a chimay keep the goblet)
It was a beautiful site chimay goblets all around full of golden elixir topped with meringue like head. I made feeble attempts to explain its origins but alas it fell upon deaf and drunk ears for these Coors light drinkers had never drank an 8% beer. They tried to understand but they did not know how Belgian monkeys could brew such a fine beer .I tried to explain monks and the monistic life (abstinence) but they were not listening. I tried explaining the yeast and its importance and how it is responsible for the earthy aromas with hints of raisins and how the hops gives it crispness they were not buying any of it. Belgian monkeys sure can brew good beer they would say I would shake my head
in disgust.beer hell indeed

Muddy gold, lasting white head with lots of lace.  Aroma of fruit and hop flowers.  Good dose of hops.  Nice malty taste.  Raisins.  Fruity yeast.  Lasting hop bitterness.  Small carbonation bubbles that sting the tongue.

Bought a gift pack tonight with the red,white and blue Chimay along with the big chimay glass for $10.99.
The white poured a loghtorange/ amber with a thick heavy white head.
Nice aroma of hops and citrus.
Hops is the flavor with a light alcohol finish.
Much better than thr blue...at least for me.
From various bottles.Gold in colour,some head,lots of fruit,hops and pepper.Another one I used to like but cant get on with these days.
It was a nice treat to find this on tap at a pub in Northern California.  This is a very nice triple.  It has a lovely nose, a nice chewy mouth, and a smooth finish.

An ethereal nose of straw, yeast, and esther begins the Cinq Cents journey.  A hoary cloud of fluffy but sturdy foam caps a golden body, much like it does with the rouge.  The body is solid and lush, and the flavor is full, finishing in a tasteful combination of fruitiness, yeast, alcohol, and hoppy bitterness-- and in that order.  A fine brew.
Bottled.  Bright copper coloring with just a bit of a head.  Yeasty aromas.  Hoppy and refreashing but also has a bit of Heineken-ish skunkiness to it.  Carbonation is fantastic.

On tap at the freakin frog las vegas.  This stuff is heavenly, but I suppose thats just a matter of my opinion.  The aroma of this stuff is wonderful, must be served in proper glassware.  Apparently Rosemarys here in town has it too with other rare beers, but Ive yet to give that a try.  If you can find it on tap, go for it and go broke.  Of course, its one of my all time favorites..

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2005 Well, Happy New Year...  750ml served in a St Bernardus goblet. Clear golden pour with small creamy white head that disappears quickly.  Aroma is heavy on the hops with a little fruit.  Flavor is quite hoppy, tripel in character, but pronounced bitter finish along with that astringent Chimay yeast which I do not find appealing.  At least it has some character..  the Bleu I tried was markedly less flavorful and appealing. The Rouge is a little better.   Mouthfeel is quite smooth and full bodied, a little buttery. Only a hint of sweetness at the start and then quite dry through to the finish.  I can see where the hop heads would go for this, but its not what I want.  Not pleasant at all.  I guess the Allagash has spoiled me.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2004 One of the most unique beer on the market this one is my favorite of the Chimay beers. A little lighter than its Red and Blue brothers but all in all a more balanced beer. A wonderful beer to serve with just about any meal.
bottle, x-mas 04.  Cloudy golden brown/orange pour, nice big head.  Sweet yeasty nose,  fruity notes as well.  Bitter yeast, full mouthfeel,  good solid aftertaste.  Slight alcohol prescense.

Tap FRTH.  Faint estery aroma.  Moderate bitterness.  Full-bodied.  A touch alcoholic, actually rather alcoholic.  Quite estery and a touch phenolic, with some considerable bubblegum.  Long hoppy finish.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2005 Chimay, despite its mass availability, never ceases to please me with its brews.  One would think that such popularity would somehow diminish the quality of the product, but Chimay has not succumbed to such folly.   A nice, light citrus scent greets the drinker.  A subtle yeast, grapefruit, and lemon shake hands with the imbiber.  Great brew.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text:
Aroma:Sugar,weat,fruity
Apperarance:gold body with yeast.
Flavor:Fruity,weat,yeast.
Very good tripel.
Spic, floral aroma with yeast and floral hops. Opaque buff in color with a fluffy white head. Slightly sweet in flavor. Yeasty, fruity bread flavors with a little bitter finish. Very refreshing.

Clear color and much elegant one. Impenetrable and dense. Creamy foam of good persistence. Intense and strong aroma; wine cellar and mildew are the stand out scents. Optimal perhaps lightly too much alcoholic persistence even if.
I dont know when I have enjoyed a tripel more. Did not have all that musty aroma and flavor instead it was clean yet complex.
Very nice and fruity with a nice light copper body and a decent sized head, really nice and smooth to drink, but not as bitter as the rouge.
Another winner from Chimay, cloudy straw colour with a slightly bitter / citrussy taste and aroma. Not easy to come by ( here at least ) but WELL worth the hunt.
OH it hurts so good.  I usually drink the blue and I kinda forgot how good this was.  Just a fantastic tripel.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2005  Another great one from Chimay.  The taste is like a Hefeweissen and wine combined.  The aroma is very nice as well.  Excellent on tap.  I have not tried this in the bottle yet.  The bitterness in this beer is really terrific.  Bitter like an Indian Pale Ale, but with a different taste.  Really terrific.

Large frothy white head, fully lasting, good to fair lacing.  Cloudy light brown caramel body with thin particules.  Yeasty aroma with strong notes of orange, citrus fruit, banana à la weizen as well as coriander?.  Very light sweetness that dont last, citrusy and spicy tones in my mouth.  Traces of acidity and astringent feel, also hops flavors? toward the finish with some kind of bitterness (from curacao I guess).  Medium body, lively carbonation (thin bubble) and alcoholic feel as final.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2005 Draught, Meridian Room. Hard to find a negative to this one. Silky smooth on the tongue. Very pretty and the taste is fantastic. Whats not to like about a slightly citrus flavored, extremely drinkable Trappist Ale? Very much look forward to trying this one again.

White head on top of a dark gold body. The take is malty, with hints of fruits (citrus), which give it a slightly sweet flavour. Decent carbonation. A very good beer, but I wouldnt count it among the very best.

Had this on tap at Dr. Dremos served in a Chimay chalice. It appears dark golden yellow in color with a decent sized white form head. There are streams of little bubbles coming from the bottom that seem to keep a thin head in place. The aroma is a slight on of hops with citrus and a slight alcohol smell, not too strong of an aroma on this one. Very hoppy flavor with a fruity sweetness about it and a hint of some spiciness. There is also some alcohol warmth to it with a yeasty finish. Good mouthfeel with a good bit of carbonation. Fairly drinkable and complex, an good brew to have occasionally.
Bottle. Light gold with white head. Full   body but light for the strength well balanced by the hops.

Very good beer.  So far, the best Tripel Ive had.  But anything in the Chimay line will be top shelf.  This is a reasonbly light tasting beer as well as light in color.  The flavor is pleasantly fruity with just the slightest hint of a favorably bitter after taste.  Just enough to make you look forward to the next taste ot it.

This was my first Tripel and still the best Ive had. Its also my favorite of the Chimays. Pours a beautiful golden color with an incredible head. Better pour it slow. Nice spicy taste without being overdone. I love the bitter aftertaste that sneaks up on you with every sip.
golden brown and murky looking with an average begian aroma.very dry flavor with alot of carbonation.reminds me alot of orval actually.good stuff.

Beerbistro Winterfest and Vintage Tasting. Cloudy golden colour with a frothy white head. Spicy, coriander, orange, light lemon, and cherry aroma. Dry, citrus, light spice, and an alcohol and fruity finish. Light to medium body, lightly dry finish.

Yellow to golden colored with a thick vigorous head.  Two mintues later still an inch of head.  I usually do not like anything this lightly colored but you know with the head it is going to be special, and it is Chimay.  Beautiful smells of yeast, spice, apple and currants.  Like a milder Unibroue.  Very textured entry, frothy to chewy to thinner with alcohol.  A little spice, a little citrus jam or marmalade and currants with a yeasty, malty aftertaste.  Not as good as the Blue Lable, but still outstanding.
Golden. tall white head. Acidious aroma. yeast. hops. floral. Rather hoppy aroma. Some underlying sweetness. Floral. Spicy? Overall not as spicy and sweet as most trippels. Good.

Much more pleasent in my opinion than the Chimay Bleu. Actually went to a jazz club that sold this in the 750ML bottle. $6 Had a golden,orange colour from what I could see and a nice white cotton head. Ez. hoppy, somewhat creamy, dry finish. Had hints of something, but maybe that was just the crowded club smell. actually I was pretty toasted when I finished this, but I can say I enjoyed it.

Pleasant, sweet, doughy, yeasty aroma with mild herbal hop notes. Opaque orange-tan with lasting cover of white head. Very sweet up front with puckering, dry finish. Fairly strong carbonation detracts somewhat from overall enjoyment. Bottle enjoyed with beerhugger, CapFlu, DumDum, muzzlehatch, radiomb and Rastacouere.

750mL: Golden orange hue, long-lasting 1cm white head, light yeast deposit. Very dry aroma with far less events happening than moinette blonde. Light alcohol touch provides a rather heating character, very herbal, moderately hoppy, grassy. Decent honeyish malt base on the tongue though it fades into an extremely dry finish. This wants to be westmalle tripel a bit too much for its own good, but it doesnt even come close in the mouthfeel department where this one seems a bit overcarbonated, bubbly even and medium bodied at most. It certainly has an irony quality to it, or at least very mineralic, which I sometimes appreciate, but it didnt seem to fit with the alcohol in here. Finish is hoppy, salty. Decent take on the style.

Hazy gold with a huge fluffy white head. The head retention is ridiculous. I had a 4 inch head holding for 30 minutes. Aroma is yeast and spices. Flavor has some raisin, yeast, and watery lemon. A light beer with many subtle flavors. Nice malts and finishes with a hoppy aftertaste.

Somewhat light for a tripel but still really well brewed.  Hazy deep gold with a great off white head which lasts and leaves excellent lacing.  Lots of hot spicy aromas along with some esters like apple, along with a variety of phenolics like hay, clove and a touch of vanilla at the end.  Flavors are yeasty and malty with a spicy backbone.  Moderately smooth finish.

Like a glass full of honey, Chimay Blanche pours beautifully golden. An amazing white head that just lingers with gorgeous texture. This beer you can love just by looking at it. Flowery, tangy aromas. Rasins and dates  were most prominent for me. Medium body thats a tad more cloying than the Chimay Rouge. A bit of bitterness in taste, but predominantly you will experience the flowers and a touch of sweetness. This beer is well-balanced, delicious and attractive..

Big Bottle.  Poured a hazy gold, with a decent head that lingered.  Bready/yeasty aroma.  Flavors domated by yeast, and a sweet/spicy fruitiness. Alcohol revealed in the warm aftertaste, which is slightly bitter.  I like it but Bleu is still my favorite from Chimay.

Draught: Hazy golden yellow with a medium frothy white head.  Aroma has banana, wheat, strong malt presence, spicey yeasts, citrus, earth, and light fruits.  Taste has lots of yeast, malt, wheat sweetness towards the beginning with some bitter citrus, spices, and bread at the end.  Another solid one from Chimay.
Pours a cloudy gold with a large foamy white head.  Aromas of malt and wheat with a yeasty nose, some hop.  Flavor is yeasty, a bit malty and wheaty.  Palate is warm and a tad dry.

750 ml bottle. Pours a copper red type of color. Big fluffy head. Aroma is of spices, banana, and an alcohol smell. Flavor is a little bit sweet and fruity with lots of spice. Slight alcohol taste, but not alot.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2005 750ml bottle. Cloudy, amber with white head that dissipates. Very nice palate, almost sweet at first and then alcohol and hops flavor. A good beer, I prefer to the Allagash tripel. But the flavor is not quite as complex as the allagash, and nothing compared to tripel karmeliet. Id buy it again though.

Gold/amber color, that isnt cloudy, but isnt clear either. Aromas of yeast, spice, fruit, and some alcohol. Hoppy citrus flavor with some earth and spice. 
Starts a little sweet, and turns more bitter towards the end. Not as good as the blue, but better than I remember it being.

Bottle pours a pale golden, slightly hazy, large white rocky head, strong carbonation, with lattice like lacing. &nbsp Estery aroma, spices, with some notes of citrus & earth. &nbsp Forwardly musty, earthy, slightly sweet, with some light spices. &nbsp Good body, medium mouthfeel. &nbsp Finish turns from a slightly sweet to a slightly salty, subtle spices, and bready.
UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 Gold color with a large head.  Slightly skunky aroma and freshly cut grass.  A fairly wheaty flavor that finishes bitter and dry.  A pinch of Noble hop.
a good tripel, not great.  also noticed the funk in the nose.  taste was traditional banana with some clove and various other spices.  unremarkable overall.

The final of three Tripels. The best part of this for me was the aroma. I really like how funky this smelled, like a gueuze. There was also some bread and banana in the nose as it warmed some. As for the look, it was paler and less pretty compared to the others. The taste was passe, quite dull with sweetness and some pepper, perhaps hops. Nothing jumped out, though. Oh, and you could feel the alcohol, not a good thing in this case. Merely average...

Yellow, somewhat cloudy with a small layer of white foam. The smell is discreet and got hints of sour milk and lime.

The carbon dioxide is medium-strong. Taste is dry and bitter; there must be lots of hops in this brew. Then there is a sweet taste of lactose, followed by a quite simple sweet-bitter aftertaste.

It seems like I have been missing something important in this drink. It wasnt obviously defective, but it seemed much more simple than I would have expected from a Belgian import beer. Maybe the keg had been open for too long? I dont really know
Cloudy blonde, slight pink with a thick white head.  Spicy, slightly funky, fruity aroma.  Light dusty flavour with loads of yeast and spice.  Quite phenolic but very good.  Light bitterness.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2011  Nov, 2002: Mud, pepper, year old lemon juice, alcohol. Not good. [1.9]
 Sept, 2004: This seems to have more pepper than most. The ingredients list doesnt inspire confidence in this being a quality product. Hop extract and wheat starch? Rougher and more interesting than <a href=Beer-Ratings.asp?BeerID=400&FanOfID=4383>H Grand Cru, though less attractive and pleasant to drink. [2.7]
Sept, 2007 A peppery, smooth and strong beer with a chalky, dry finish. Hmm. Must compare this with Duvel one day. Sugar notes. Pleasant enough - warm - almost hot - alcohol. Not unpleasant, but not outstanding either. [3.0]
May 2011 Dry and bitter. Loose carbonation that repeats - not aggressive, just overly present. Woody, caramel and honey  notes - but bitterness predominates. Not a beer Im hugely enjoying. [2.4]

75cl cork dated 03/03  Explosive *pop* upon pulling the cork...amber colored, frothy white head, bubbly.  Banana, citric, sweet malty nose.  Big nose.  Malty, spicy(yeast) flavor leads to a dry, bitter finish.  Light bodied.  Fruity, light tripel that achieves good balance with some complexity while being quite easy to drink.  Alochol is hidden.  This is the best Chimay has to offer, IMO.
Wow, what a great taste from beginning to end.  It has a light bite buit is remarkably smooth. Raisin flavoring is noticeable and the alcohol certainly hits. Excellent.

Chimay has been one of my staple beers for a few years now - cheaper and easy to get in PA. 11.2 oz bottle. Poured a medium hazy amber color with a large tanish head. Fruity, citric and yeasty aromas and tastes with light spices. Peppery/spice finish. Fizzy body.

Good cloudy color, wonderfull head. I can smell the yeast from across the room, nice. Great full, malty mouthfeel. Creamy. Lots of yeast, fruit up front but also very defined by its bitterness. Very present alcohol, but not offensive. A triple that is not boring and dry,  I like it!

Bottle: Poured a cloudy light brown ale with a huge foamy off-white head with excellent retention. Aroma is mix between Belgian spices and strong malts and floral hops. Taste is quite delicious with again some spices showing up (some peppers?), strong malt with excellent body and all of this covered with floral hops. Less sweet then other tripel such as Westmalle but still very enjoyable overall.
33cl bottle. Great head. Aroma of pepper and resinous hops. Excellent bitter hop flavour with no evidence of spice or sweetness. Long dry bitter finish.
Sweet, honeyed, and tasted frothy though it didnt look it.  The kind of beer Id drink in a religious gathering or some sort of initiation, Id imagine.  Initiation into what, I dunno.

Hazy light gold color. Aroma of yeast and mild citrus.Flavor basically how it smelled to had a slightly bitter dry finish.
IMO Chimay has lost a fair amount of its appeal and is not the beer it was a few years ago.

750 mL bottle in a tulip glass. Pours an oversized forthy head, in which even the foam has an alcoholic taste, and a pleasant hop note to the smell. A golden hazy body. Once I get past the foam, I find a slight lactic tang among citrus notes and the mouthfeel of a Squirt soda. A delicate, balanced bitterness and the hint of orange peel at the end. Its just great for relaxing to in the recliner.
delicious abbey... not quite as sharp as the blue but just as delicious.  gets a few extra points for that.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2015 29 Aug 2004 - Soft citrus and grape  fruit hop aroma. Cloudy orange golden colour and white well retained head with an even veil of lacing.  Crisp clean sweet fruit that appeals to me. A bit to  bitter for me, pleasant lingering hop finish, with a nice fizzy disolve.  In the end this beer is more than the sum of its parts. Post note: Just after I rated this beer, as  I drank the rest, found that I didnt enjoy it as much as the beginning, I think it is the clingning bitterness as time goes on (rated down from 17 to 15).
UPDATED: JUL 30, 2015 Floral hop aroma. Cloudy amber colour with good head. Sweet fruit flavour with hint of hops. fizzy palate. Could down quite a few of these.
Really very nice. A great Tripel.  You cant really compare the main Chimays although Im tempted to.  The Blanche is excellent on its own.
Full, spicy and delicious.  Murky golden body, with a lasting white head.  Yeasty/spicy nose and flavor is much the same.  A wonderful triple.

Lacing and a full white head -- many different golden hues.  Aromas are overwhelmingly of hops, but there is also some fig and yeast.  The beer is full and complex on the palate, with a going-away, not-unpleasant kick of bitterness at the end.  A great beer, and a classic.
Sharp, hoppy and sour aroma. Pronounced long hop bitterness, fresh and some rock candy sweetness.
UPDATED: FEB 6, 2005 Flowery, yeasty aroma. Somewhat herbal. Amazing carbonation. Fruity, malty sweet flavors. Citrus and orange peel. Nice alcohol warmth. This is a wonderful beer.
Hazy gold...thick head that didnt last as long as Id like...smells hoppy and yeasty...tastes spicy and hoppy with a crisp dry finish...probably my least favorite "big" tripel...

Large white foamy head. Orange-light amber color. Aroma is hoppy, herbal with floral, yeasty and spicy notes. Flavor is moderately hoppy with herbal, spicy and light fruity tones, ending in a balanced hoppy and floral finish. Medium to full bodied.
Aroma has some citrusy hops and raisin bread in it.  Huge rocky head atop a cloudy brown body.  This beer is smooth and carbonated at the same time.  A bit sweet with some feint spices.  Prettygood.

Golden colored, slightly hazy, with a thick head.  Somewhat sweet and citrusy, and quite smooth and a bit bubbly.  A little bit of spices, and some hos at the end of a moderate dry finish.  Very nice.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2007 750ml Bottle: Poured gold with a big foamy head. Aroma was musty and herbaceous with some nice malt notes in the background. The flavour carries through with this but in a somehwat confused and dissonant. Very lively carbonation and full mouthfeel. This is a more expressive beer than the Rouge or the Bleu.Re-Rate: Less impressive this time around. Just not as expressive. 7/4/7/4/14=3.5

12 oz bottle-pours a nice hazy orange hue with a nice big pillowy white head.  Aromas are citrus like, but not in the hoppy sense-oranges, bananas and dusty yeast esters (my BBB63 quote for the day)  Flavors are fruity, yeasty and juicy-lots of citrus.  Great palate-smooth and round.  A great trippel

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2005 My favourite of the Chimays. Cloudy golden colour with a large white head. Nice lacing. Good mouthfeel and lots of carbonation. Lots of fruit and spice in the nose and taste. Slightly bitter finish. Dryer and crisper than the other Chimays. Great beer.

Biggg white head didnt last long.Real hazy light amber color.yeasty fruit flavor.I cant pick out the hops but this is a very good brew.The alcohol doesnt stand out.I keep sipping this to figure out exactly what the flavor is.Keep getting the fruity yeast flavor.Very good

Pours light gold and hazy with a big pillowy off white head. Duller than expected alcohol and herbal grassy nose with notes of yeast. Bread crusty and fairly boozey. Medicine like hop bitter. Mild spice and yeast. Some mineral and metallic flavours come through. Burnt sugar. Palate is stronger than the flavour. Picked up some mint near the end. Decent.

Golden with a large, rocky white head.
Aroma of hops is more pronounced than
either the blue or red. Nice and dry and hoppy flavor with just enough sweetness to balance it out.
Pours pale golden with orange and coriander in the taste and aroma.  Fantastic beer.  Great mouthfeel.

This one pours turbid pale golden, with a creamy head and lace.  Aroma of hops, yeats, champagne, fruit.  Tastes of hops, fruit, malt, with a slightly dry, fizzy, complex finish.  A good beer, but not a hall of famer for me.
UPDATED: JAN 25, 2005 Bottle. Golden color with a big white head. Fruity aroma and a spicy taste. Medium body.

This beer has a nice golden color with a fluffy creamy head.It has a intens aroma of fine hops with some sweetness and a touch of malts.It has a round taste with a bittersweet side an a nice afthertaste of nobel hops.

Pours a cloudy honey gold with a foamy white head.  Soothing Belgian yeasty aroma.  Slightly hoppy attack that quickly opens up into a burst of maltyness that quackly evaporates and leaves an alcohol sting behind.  This beer makes me happy.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2004 This is a re-rate... Hazy yellow color with medium head.  Spicy, floral nose.  Apricot, banana, orange, grapefruit, and grape flavors, with nice yeast fullness.  Not as sweet as Tripel Karmeliet, but flavors are more complex and not overwhelmed by honey.  Mildly bitter aftertaste that leaves me wanting more.

11.2 oz. bottle
Appearance; thickly opaque dark orange hue, with a full-flowering head of foam that dwindles and disappears almost immediately.
Aroma: sharp citrus, yeast, sour, must, ...thats it...
Taste: rather blase, little going on with the flavor, nothing to busy the palate.
Malt, yeast, thick citric, orangey feel, but little else, small, if any, hops, and fading flavor. Too sharp, too spicy, with little in the body and texture to balance that out. Feels drab, really, leaden, cardboard-y, actually. I dont re-visit this ale too often, so my memory is fuzzy whether this is supposed to taste so dreary.
Over halfway in, the fruitiness is broader, with more flavors swimming about, juicy, tropical fruits,pineapple, sweet, spicy, kicky...a far cry from the best tripels of Belgium. I may actually look into it, again, to investigate whether this sampling was inferior, and perhaps the brew was meant to taste much more amazingly. Until then...Chimays is an underwhelming tripel experience.

My serving of this was not all that great, if I can get this served in the propper way and under some better conditions then I will definately re rate this thing. Darker in colour with a big white long lasting head. The nose is mostly wheat and just a dab of malts which gives it a faint fruit presence. The tasete is bitter with some sourness to it. We had this at room temerature as well, dont think that this helped it too much.

Murky amber body with white head.  Aroma was interesting.  Banana bread.  Maybe gingerbread.  Certainly some spice and fruit tones.  Yeast.  Good creamy mouthfeel.  Flavor was mildly hoppy, fruity, some sweetness.  Not a preferred style of mine but not a bad drink.

pours a light brown with a volumous head that lasts. aroma is slightly skunky with a peach tint. flavor is enjoyable after the first taste. hop flavored raisin is the primary taste. finishes smooth the flavvors mellow out and leave a great impression.

Another good ale from Chimay.  This one seems to be the lightest in terms of flavor and complexity which makes it a little more drinkable in large amounts.  Nice thick, fluffy head that lasts.  Small touch of fruit with a nice full flavor.

Cloudy light brown color with huge long lasting head. Fruity aroma with some spicyness in there too. Flavor was totally different from aroma: strong carbonation biting in start and hops making flavor and after taste to be very bitter and lasting. Ending is very dry and some grassy flavors can be noticed too. Full bodied palate with some alcohol taste leaving warm feeling to mouth. Seems strange but I rated this White version to have points than more popular Blue one, but its not a mistake. This is my favourite Chimay.
Disappointing to me. Good looking but a bit bitter and dry aftertaste. I didn´t recognize the fruity part of the palet much.
Very bubbly, like champagne.  Looks beautiful in the right glass. Golden colored with a moderate amount of head. Similar to the other Chimays which means amazing.

on draft: pours golden tan with a bubbly white head that bubbles away quickly, lively in the glass with small bubbles like champagne. nose of grapes maybe some hops. tingly in the nares and mouth fruit with lots of body. seems light for a tripel but is easy to drink and quite good.

Cloudy golden amber pour with a huge white head.  Nice lacing as the head subsides. Fruit, pepper, and a bit of alcohol in the nose.  Nice ripened fruit forward with a heavy alcohol burn in the finish.
Sampled at Toronado. One of the best tripels Ive had so far.  Has a cloudy golden appearance. Lots of fruits and spices like all Belgian ales have and very smooth and sweet finish.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2008 Bottle:  Aroma is fruity, slight alcohol, and a little hoppy.  Pours a nice transparent gold with a large white head with great retention.  Very nice lacing.  Some very small sediment floating around.  Flavor is fruity with a slight bitter finish.  Leaves a short sweet aftertaste.  Some alcohol taste but nothing overbearing.  A very nice balance.  Excellent beer. (7-4-8-4-18)

Bottle (33cL): Re-rate...Really nice floral aroma with some moderate spiciness and faint apple.  It pours a hazy orange with lots of sediment and a moderate yellow-tinged white creamy head with very good retention.  The lacing really clings and coats the glass.  The flavor starts lightly fruity with apples, raisins, citrus, and yeast.  The finish is a combination of moderate spiciness, pepper, and moderate floral hops.  Medium bodied with lively, but soft, carbonation.  I was expecting my Chimay re-rates to all go down.  This was even better than I remembered and actually went up. (9-4-9-4-18)

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2005 My buddy Andys favorite of the Chimay roster while I place it a level under the Red and Blue.  A bit dryer, crisper and ends more succinctly than the others.  Very well could replace a white wine with dinner.
UPDATED: NOV 23, 2004 Lots of carbonation, thick white head. Citric aroma and flavor.

I do believe this is my first Chimay Blanche....Lively carbonation; thick, frothy, head dissipating quickly; metallic, yeasty, citrus aroma; nice, fruity, tangy, complex flavor, not too funky tasting; moderately-full bodied, creamy texture; outstanding, well balanced tripel.

I think this is my favorite chimay. Clear golden pour with a fine bubly head. Nose of hops in a big way, more hoppy then I expected. Hits the palate smooth with some fruit and malt flavors, and of course some hops.
user_location: New York, east village, New York, USA

text: Yellow color with good good off white head and some lacing.  There was a fruit smell and sweet first taste with a little kick at the end.

This beer was gone before I even had a chance to type my notes out. Anyway here is what I remember, hazy dull orange body with a good size off white head, aroma was fruity and yeasty, taste was lovely! Soft pepper, some malt, raisins and a little cloves. Good alcohol and a lovely mouthfeel.
Golden beer with a tall and foamy off-white head. Cheese, hay and yeast in the aroma. Taste is quite mild for a tripel. Hay, yeast, cheese and spices. Hides the alcohol well. A good tripel!

330mL Bottle, 04.06.04  Pours a darker, orangish amber color; head is typically ample for a tripel, lacing, and lasting.  Aromas are of ripe white fruits (pear, banana, grapefruit juice) and spice (corriander, clove).  It smells and tastes fresh and lithe.  A versatile beer, it can take the place of chardonay with a spicey or fishy dish.  In fact, some wine notes carry over from nose to flavor.  Hops are, as advertised, nicely intertwined with the yeasts, but this beer might just be too hoppy for its own good...its only downfall, IMO.  The beer is so fresh tasting, so grassy, peppery, floral, fruity; the finishing betterness adds to the fresh effect.  Its hard to imagine that this is a tripel, it is the antithesis of mellow - it is exciting!

Cloudy orange-amber. Some sediment. Lots of carbonation. Soft, foamy white head. Yeasty (bubble gum, banana), spicy (pepper), & fruity (orange) aroma. Lively, highly carbonated, slightly astringent feel. Complex flavour of yeast (banana, bubble gum), pepper, light malt, & fruit (orange, peach).  Firm, dry finish.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2005 Cloudy orange fizzy pour. Carbinotation made it interesting and classic Chimay.Tasty but worth sharing the bottle if without food. Bit of spice and pepper and (sour) yeast in taste. Bit bitter and alcohol feel. Aftertaste was dry.
UPDATED: SEP 2, 2004 This was really good, simular to the Bleu but better, peppery. Goes Down really easy.

Brassy gold in the glass. Dip your finger into the massive off-white head...you get a soft peak your fingertip, and a crater in the foam. Small amount of camoflage-like lacing. The nose evolves with time and temperature; at various points my glass yielded spicy and earthy notes aromas, yeast, pepper, nutmeg, dates and molasses, composting hay, and pizza crust. Initially slightly sweet taste (honey & water) is followed by flavors of spice, wood, and cowfield. There is also a lightly metallic character that actually enhances the flavor, and carries into the aftertaste. At first, the fluffy and cloudlike palate leads to a leafy bittersweet finish, but the flavor and mouthfeel get pretty wimpy as the carbonation dissipates.

straw colored with a great fluffy head--great retention and structure.

Nose is lively with esters of banana, pepper, clove and cinnamon.

Good mouthfeel.

Great beer!

Beautiful hazy deep golden brown colour. Giant foamy white head that releases plenty of fruity aroma. Very peppery and spicy with a lingering finish. Not overly aggresive alcohol but more noticeable than I expected for an 8% beer. Solid though.
Cerveza tostada de triple fermentacion. Esta buena. puede que sea la mejor de las tres o no, vete tu a saber

Bottle. Orangeish pour with one finger fluffy head.  Nose is super yeasty and hoppy and has hints  of bananna. There is alot of carbonation. Taste is yeasty (like fresh bread dough) with a touch of alocohol. There is some spice in there, and it adds a great flavor. There are some strong floral notes that mix really well with the spice. Overall taste is a great balance of black pepper, hops, malt, and yeast. Finish is sharp, spicy and slightly bitter. I am not a huge fan of Chimay, but this is the best of the three IMO. Not my most favorite beer by far, but a good beer. If you are like me and think that Chimay Red and Blue are too chewy, try this one. It is much more balanced and easy to drink than the other two. I would LOVE to try this on tap!
Pours cloudy yellow with a big foamy head. Citrussy/Yeasty aroma. Well carbonated. Reminds me of some good wheat beers I've drank. Excellent brew.
Great golden color.  Sweet yeast aroma.  The taste is tart with woody aftertaste.  I like it, but I like other Trappists and other Chimay ales better.

slightly cloudy, orange/gold color, nice white creamy head, lace, very nice spicy-peppery nose, fruit, malty sweet, some citrus and hops and yeast; flavor is complex, some nice spiciness-pepper blended with a fruity/malty sweetness, bitter finish, yeasty, bread and cookie, average hops, somewhat rich but smooth
UPDATED: NOV 24, 2004 Nice peach colour with big, but shortlived head.Aroma and flavor is fruity with hints of banana and clove. Nice palate.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2004 While not nearly as sweet as most in the style, this unusual tripel is very malty, woody, and somewhat bitter for the style, and this overshadows the mild sweetness and spiciness; The finish is actually quite bitter and hoppy; Carbonated mouthfeel is very expansive; The nose is neither sweet nor spicy, but instead is pretty malty with a slightly stinky cheese aroma; Orange-golden color and hazy; Explosive, bubbly, white head becomes rocky with very porous lacing ; The beer is very enjoyable, but just kind of odd for a tripel.

I really liked this beer. It would be great in hot weather. Has a sweetaroma with a slightly sweet matching palate. Finishes with a slightly bitter crisp bite. After taste is bitter that melts away leaving a refreshing sensation.

Pours a thick and fluffy cloud like head. Body is darker, a brownish colour. Floral aroma accompanied by some hints of spice and fruit. Taste is herbal/spicy with some fruity hints. A strange tasting beer, but a strange delight.
Cloudy yellow with a big head. REally enjoyable beer. Well carboanted. Sharp Flavor. Enjoyable. hoppy.
750 ml 09/03. Pours cloudy yellow with a big foamy head. Citrussy/Yeasty aroma. Well carbonated. Citrussy sharp flavor of yeast, orange peel and hops. Reminds me of a strong wit.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text:
UPDATED: AUG 13, 2004 Bottled 0.33l (BB 2006)
Hazy orange with long-lasting foamy head. Aroma is hops, citron and yeast. Typical Belgium malt texture. Smooth mouthfeel with nice hoppy finish. I prefer Chimay Blue. (6/3/6/3/13 3.1)
Re-rated, bottle (BB 2006)
Hazy orange with long-standing lace head. Aroma is malts, hops with citron. A bit Orval-like citric mouthfeel but not so spicey. Balanced, nice. (6/4/7/4/15 3.6)
Re-rated, bottled (BB 2006)
Hazy color, rocky head. Nice aroma, citric and malty. Bitter mouthfeel, well-balanced. (7/4/7/4/15 3.7)

The "Cinq Cents" was a 750ml bottle of a batch born in 10/2002 according to the cork. It poured with a tall, long-lasting white head with an aroma of pepper and flowers. Oh, the taste is just sublime... complex, floral, with interesting undertones... this is a great beer, and probably my favorite light-hued brew!

750ml corked and caged, date on cork 07/03. Poured a golden colour with a huge sticky head.Aromas of spice, pepper, fruits( apples mostly). The tastes are of big fruitiness, spices, and a nice hoppiness, previously described here as a dusty hop flavour that's pretty accurate by my account. The flavours really came out as this brew reached room temp. A really good triple.

Very big long lasting head. Nice coppery orange in the Chimay chalice. Lightly spiced aroma with yeast notes. Clean and smooth. LIght dust notes on the tongue. Interesting and lasting dusty hop finish. Can feel the alcohol in your nose. Excellent.

75cl Corked with 09/03 stamped on cork This bottle was well charged and created a loud pop when uncorked. Poured a clear golden color with an enormous white creamy head consisting of tiny bubbles. Aroma is spicy and yeasty with notes of citrus. Also has a funky bit of skunkiness to it that seems off to me.  The body is light and Chamagne like. Really crisp and carbonated. The flavor is a little too bitter for my liking and not as sweet and flavorful as some other Tripels I've had. Maybe this was not a great sample though.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Hazy gold color with a very small white head. Light fragrance of apple, pear, clove and white grapes.  Big flavor packs apple, bubble gum, clove spice, then turns hoppy with a citrus/lemon ending. Well fashioned beer, something I definitely expect from Chimay. Sampled on draught at L Enfant in Adams Morgan, Washington, DC.
Huge fluffy white that dissipates quite quickly with some lacing.  Aroma is sweet and fruity, mostly with some spice.  Taste is quite different, very tangy up front.  Finishes nicely dry and crisp

On tap.  Poured  a hazy orange with a huge head and great lace.  This one had a nice sour citrus flavor with a little tiny hint of alcohol.  Another very enjoyable beer that I can't get at home.  Stupid alcohol laws...

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2004 Nice frothy pour, with a generous and lasting head.  Great aroma of many spices including nutmeg.  Nothing to wow me in the taste, but mild hop bitterness makes it tangy.  Very crisp and dry in the finish.  This got substantially better as it lingered on the palate, leaving me wanting more.

My only criticism of Cinq Cents is that it is a little inconsistent. When it's right, it's one of the best beers I've had. Crisp, clean, and tasty. A little thinner than Westmalle (my favorite triple), but overall, a great beer. The fact that it's readily available (in my local grocery store!) makes it more appealing (IMO).

Malt smell w. a touch of spice, alcohol and that particular sweet smell of belgian ales (the sugar?).

Cloudy with a big old head, the head collapses to a dense cap.
Strong alcoholic bite initially which leads out through the malts to bitterness and boy howdy does this have a great bitterness. I wish it have the smooth palate in the manner of tripel karmeliet or even chimay blue. The palate is okay but I sort of think a tripel ought to be thicker on the tongue.

Has a big yeasty, cream colored head that bubbles out of the glass like cappuccino froth. Body is thick, deep, and golden. Has a fruity, aroma with big blasts of malt and yeast and subtle hints of hops and alcohol. This beer is loaded with flavor: yeast, fruits, hops, and alcohol battle for control of your senses throughout this beer. Overall, I think this is an awesome quaffing beer. Would be great at a party, served in goblets, with some bread and cheese.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2010 Beautiful aroma of oranges and spice.  Hazy orangey colour with excellent head retention.  Taste again is spicy and hoppy and clean.  There is a slight harshness after swallowing hence the lower score there.  A quality beer none the less and very drinkable.  Score 4.0Subsequent rating scored 3.8. Average becomes 3.9
A very good beer! A bit more crisp and a slight bit more hop than the other Chimay styles i have tried. Maybe my favorite Chimay that i have tried so far.
Yeast, light citrus, clove noise.  Orangish yellow in the glass with marvelous head retention.  Nice and warming, a hint of lemon zest, yeast and corriander(?)
fruity aroma and thick white head a bit of a turn off, lots of carbonation too noticable on palate. good bitter aftertaste that fades quickly.

While this is very good, it is my least favorite of the Chimays. Pours with a huge white head and has lots of carbonation. Very cloudy. Has lots of banana in the aroma and flavor. Kinz said it well that tobacco is very strong in the aroma and flavor. This is not complex and the alcohol definitely comes through and gives it some bite. A little piney and slightly citrusy in the finish. A little disapointing after having the other Chimays.

pours hazy(fell over in the ride home)copper amber with a large head that fades slowly. aromas of vanilla, orange, hops, and coriander. flavors of malt, oranges, coriander, hoppy bitterness, vanilla, and ending with an alcohol pepperiness. body is moderate with some creamyness from the carbonation. a bit musty. the blanche on tap is brighter and more refreshing. still a good beer.

On tap.  Deep gold, pretty white head, tiny bubbles.  Faint slightly cedary and tobacco aroma, with some orange.  Flavors are faintly of apricot, moving into an almost ashy hop finish.  Decent, bu the weakest of the Chimay line up, and there are many far better tripels out there as well.
Complex and delicious, with that charachteristic Chimay yeast strain aroma and taste... similar but IMHO slightly better than Duvel.
Could not detect any distinct aroma with this beer (might have been the smoke in the bar).  Cloudy golden color with good lacing.  Mix of fruit and bitter taste.  Good carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2008 [bottle] Very hazy golden color with good carbonation and a thick white head. Has a mixed nose. Some sweet mixed with hops and yeast. Very potent flavor of yeast and a little fruit undertone. Mouthfeel is a little harsh at the beginning but slowly gives way to a silky finish.

I brought home a growler of this from Sean Bolan's in Bel air,MD.Aroma is full of banana,yeast,clove,hop.The taste is lacking compared to the bottled version(but still very satisfiying).Smooth but not the same w/o that bottle conditiond champagne-like carbonation.More drinkable in it's flater draft version which is quite a treat four blocks from my door.The bottled version has more character(and is more preferred)
white head which dissipated fairly quickly and left slight foam traces on the outside of the glass. murky golden body.
Fruity floral aroma which was slightly skunky.  Pine and pineapple flavors with a slightly citrus twist.

Nice golden color with a very large head that sat like whipped cream after settling down a bit. Aroma consists of light fruit with hops and yeast. Not real complex flavor and doesn't mask the alcohol as well as others, but overall a nice smooth taste with a light bitter finish.
Sweet yeasty, fruity, aroma.  Nice full-bodied and rich.  A bit hot, the alcohol stands out a bit much on this one.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2004 toffee, honey and dark chocolate and nectary flowers [some australian natives come to mind] on the nose.
looks fantastic in the glass, with a rich amber colour and excellent head.
for me the dominant flavours were dark chocolate [without much of the bitterness associated with dark chocolate] and toffee, with subtle hints of dried fruit.
nice smooth body with fantastic bitterness that seemed to me to compliment the flavours beautifully.
Hazy gold color. Large white head that quickly diminishes. Fruity nose as the other Chimay beers. The alcohol lingers a little too long. The taste is musky.
UPDATED: DEC 18, 2006 On tap ... massive head.  Golden orange.  Yeasty aroma.  Cloves?  Wheaty grist.  Smooth and nice.  For a non-fan of Belgian beers, I liked this!
Strong Ale Fest '03. Light orange color with smallish head (sample sized). Light hops are preceeded by fruity taste you come to expect from Chimay.
Dark golden color with a large fluffy white head.  Spicy hops and yeast in the aroma.  Fruity taste, followed by spice and vanilla.  Just a small amount of carbonation.

Golden amber body is topped by a gorgeous white creamy head that clings to the sides of the glass in huge thick sheets. Fruity peppery aroma. The flavor packs a surprising astringent wallop. The fruity and peppery flavors are there but the astringency and alcohol flavors are a tad overwhelming. Body is very lively. Overall this beer looks awesome, smells great, but the flavor is a slight letdown but still not bad at all.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2015 Bottled (330ml). Colour is attractive deep gold underscored by a suggestion of orange. It has a moderate fluffy head, which quickly subsides. The aroma is dominated by yeast and Demerara sugar, with an undercurrent of wheat and malt. Spritzy on the tongue, but relatively light bodied. The flavour is dominated by lemons with some underlying sweetness, but the two aspects are not especially well integrated  imagine adding sugar to neat lemon juice. Well hopped, but the hops announce their presence a tad aggressively and without subtlety. There is sharpness on the finish that lingers and tends towards astringency. I certainly wouldnt say that the after-bitterness melts in the mouth as claimed. This beer is crisp and quaffable for a Trappist, but somewhat straightforward and uncomplicated. None of this is to say that I actively dislike the beer; I just cant really see what everyone raves about. As Tim Webb comments in his book, perhaps the monks are getting too commercial for the good of the product.

wow...what a beer.  received this beer in a smaller special glass right from the tap.  fine bubbly head not too cloudy.  first thing i noticed when drinking was the strength along with softer beer taste.  i did notice the raisiny, malty flavoring....very pleasing and i highly recommend this one.

Huge fluffy white head: Bread-like texture. Hazy golden. Looks beautiful in matching Chimay trappist glass. Smooth flavour, alcohol pushes through a little bit. Strong yeast presence, malty, and spicey.

Deep gold with mildly pungent herbal hop aromas with some citrus and cinnamon in there as well. Starts off with fruity notes, but the dominant theme is lavish floral hops. This is somewhat heavily hopped, but without excessive bitterness. The  aftertaste is bitter and lightly fruity. A rounded, very pleasant beer, drinkable in greater quantity than many trappist beers.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2004 Pours cloudy orange/gold with a large head and moderate lace.  A very hoppy aroma.  Also some spice and banana.  Flavor is heavy and a little sweet.  The finish is very hoppy and a little astringent.  The alcohol is aparent.  Strong carbonation.  A very good beer.
(330cl bottle in Chimay chalice) Hazy orange with small head. A whiff of banana in the aroma. Flavor is yeasty, somewhat sweet and fruity. Aftertaste only mildly bitter.

Bottle.  Sunset orange colour, with peppery alcohol aroma.  Patchy medium head.  Nettly, minty flavour, with a pinprick mouthfeel, and bags of aroma throughout.  Sparkling, bitter aftertaste, with some yeast notes. Easy and pleasant to drink for it's strength.

LAL 229 bottle code. 330 cl. Bottles. Hugely flavorful with gentle hops and buttery malt backbone. Wild dancing and subtle pallet of flavors; incredibly smooth and velvety finish. Golden Monkey has a long way to go.
(Bottle)  Pours a golden color with a large white head.  Has a ever so light citrus, cream, and hop taste.

Bottle pours a light amber color with a large head and significant lace.  The aroma is yeasty.  The flavor is fruity and sweet, sometimes musty, with a slightly bitter finish that lingers.  The palate is fine.  Overall, this is OK, but this is not my favorite Tripel.

Served in a Chimay chalice.  The beer is a hazy gold color that has a white sheen to it.  Not much head was in this beer when it was brought to me fresh from the tap.  It has a spicy aroma, but does not have any hotness to it.  There is a light musty flavor and aroma here, which I find characteristic of many Belgian beers.  A light white grape fruitiness rounds out the front and middle of this Trappist ale.  There is a bit of hot spiciness in the finish of this beer, sort of a pepper type finish.  This is pretty good, and is widely available.

Aroma of citrus and small amounts of hops. Cloudy orange with a great head and good lacing. Sweet malt with small amounts of citus and a decent hop & creamy aftertaste. More carbonation that the last two abbey tripels I just rated but doesn't harm this.
Pours a murky blonde color.  Light aroma is mostly wheaty & haylike; barnyardish.  Flavor is mostly banana and clove, with a slight tinge of pepper.

Blond, huge white head with some lace. Aromatic, fruity, sweet malty, flowery notes of pepper and some yeast in nose. Pretty full body, smooth and a bit sweet. Fruity, moderate bittered, acid and sweet, bit alcohol-like in aroma. A bit dry, bitter and long finish.
Pours a yellow/amber color with a lasting frothy head.  Yeasty and malt flavors of dough and oats.  A slight sweetness to the finish with a nice bitterness.
Beautiful amber color with large frothy head. A nice citris aroma accented the moderately bitter hoppy taste.

Tasted in Toronto from LCBO.  Tasted in Chimay trappist glass.  Colour is a rust orange colour, somewhat opaque with a large white stable frothy head. Aroma has slight hint of alcohol.  In the forefront, aromas of floral spice, apples, and raisins abound. Taste is more subdued and subtle than the aroma. Up front, the bitterness of hops is present, with a slightly 'creamy/velvety finish'. Little or no spice or fruit like flavour.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2004 (0,33l bottle) Very hazy, dark orange color with a creamy and lacy head. Slightly sour and acidic, yeasty, fruity and spicy, reasonably complex, almost "Orvaly" aroma. The flavor is dryish, witbier-peppery-spicy, citrusy and quite hoppy. Nicely balanced, medium-bodied, semi-dry palate, but way too carbonated from a trappist glass. From a Duvel glass (with the "crack" at the bottom), the excess carbon dioxide will quickly evaporate, and the palate is much better balanced! An excellent, quite dry tripel, although it could still be more refreshing.
Draft at Monks Cafe in Philly. Very good tripel. Was a little drier than I remember but still very good. Wasn't as sweet as some other tripled

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2005 100th RATING!!! / didnt care too much for the aroma, musty yeast. flavor and palate is what dominates: banana bread, cherries, smooth, and animated. flavor summed up as fruity peppers? a delight nonetheless, but nothing entirely too special. very good brew. (updated only to note that this is rating #100!!!)

Enjoyed this while watching the 1st half of the OSU/Michigan game.  Woot!!, what a great game.  Anyway, this brew pours a hazy clover honey amber.  The giant off white frothy head is mostly lasting with good lacing.  The subtle nose is licorice, roses, alcohol, strawberry/banana/cherry, and pepper.  The flavor is lighter than I expected for the gravity.  Great balance with the alcohol remaining concealed and elusive - just the way I like it.  Tangy middle and a long peppery finish.  The medium dry and fizzy palate finishes chalky.  This is definitely a beer that must be allowed to warm and breathe.  P.S. enjoyed this with a Mama Mimi's "Take N Bake" pizza.  For all those of you in central Ohio that haven't tried one - GET ON IT!!
Beautiful head, wonderful aroma, hoppy crisp start, with a variety of taste sensations on the palate.

well this is a great beer, nice aroma, great golden colour & head. The flavour is a bit simpler and perhaps a bit sweeter than other chimay offerings, but at the same time, it goes down fantastically smooth. Nice, but i still give the nod to chimay bleu.

33 ml. bottle.  Pours cloudy and peachy amber in color with a large white head that dissipated rather rapidly.  Aroma is citrus, spice, breadiness, malts and piney hops.  Flavor is sweet and yeasty with lots of spice - coriander and pepper - with a strong hop finish.  Nice round mouthfeel.  Nice, but I like the other Chimay offerings better.

Being a huge fan of this Abbey Igave tthis one a shot.  It was a pale colour,  very cloudy.  Creamy\ spicy taste that was very satisfying.  I'll agree with the previous raters comment on its apparent lack of complexity but still definitely a nice trippel

A local cigar bar just got this on tap served in the Chimay glass, so I had to try it even though the $12 was way steep for Chimay.

One of my favorite Tripels, it had a spicy aroma and a beautiful pale orange with a fluffy head. Yeasty flavor of fresh bread and figs, not as complex as the Blue but darn good.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2005 Bottled, stored for one year.
Orange, hazy with delicate white head.
Fruity aroma with notes of apricots, apple, rubber and spices.
Spicy flavor with notes of almonds and alcohol.

Dark golden colour, cloudy. Beige head that is thick and lasting. Hoppy aroma, dry hop bitter to it. Carbonated smooth palate. Sweet malts.Spicy and peppery Musty aroma. Slight must in flavour as well. Slight wheatiness. Slight alcohol. Everything is quite well balanced.
Cloudy amber color. Thick frothy head. Hoppy and yeast aroma. Complex flavor, with soem malt, spice, and fruit possibly? I enjoyed having this with some friends at the Beer Sellar in Nashville, TN.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2004 An hazy amber ale that waits for your lips under an appealing thick white head. The aroma is dominated by fruity and yeasty whiffs. Taste is very hoppy as well as spicy. A touch of bitterness shows up. Very enjoyable.
UPDATED: JUL 30, 2005 Draught at The Rover, Gothenburg. Golden, with a white creamy head. Aroma is fruity, rather amild and with some yeast. Has a sweet, herbal flavor. Better than the blue Chimay.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2007 Creamy, bright beige head over a deep bright amber liquid. Quite nice really!

Wintery, fruity aroma that had me thinking about vanilla icecream with almonds! Maybe Im losing it...

First impression is somewhat overpowering. Noticable alcohol and the beer feels big in the mouth at first and complex. A hint of sweetness can be found, but mostly its a pretty dry, spicy beer that leaves a nice bitter finish. A nice one!

Revisited 12th of August, 2007: Interesting how I still think some of my description is spot on but other things make me wonder. I thought this was a complex beer? Obviously I wasnt completely weened of Stella.

The aroma doesnt strike me as wintery, but I notice sweet and spicy orange. Perhaps thats coriander Im picking up?

In fact I think its more the flavour thats wintery. Theres a certain flatness in there that reminds me of a lot of Hefeweisses. Citrusy sting, perhaps grapefruit, along with alcohol and there might be a bit of pepper to the aftertaste along with... some greens that linger?

Anyway, it laces nicely, has strings of carbonation and is quite enjoyable. Im going to shave OA down from 15 to 14. Its nice but Im not quite as easily impressed four years on.
Hazy golden color, fluffy head, tastes of banana and clove.  Great Tripel.  Finishes dry and smooth.

A wonderfully attractive beer when poured into the proper Chimay Chalice..nice light amber haze colour, terrific white head..nice carbonation.
Beer smells quite 
"sharp" and fruity..mostly peaches and apricots perhaps? also some slight sourness.
This has a nice semi-dry taste to it..you can taste the alcohol..its pretty spicy.
Good feel on the tongue..carbonation just right.
A good drink  would have it again...though I liked New Belgiums Tripel better.

Holy cow. There's not too much wrong with this one; a wicked drop that I enjoyed swigging out of the bottle with pogo walking through Newtown. I guess there is a bit of mandarin and vegetable stock but cool and I love this beer. Kicks red's arse.

Decent head from the pour which is nice and frothy on top.  Huge carbonation.  Aroma is mainly yeast with a touch of citrus.  Color is a medium orange/amber and is slightly hazy.  Flavor is full but not that complex.  More yeast and citrus with some spices added.  The finish is the best part of this beer in my opinion.  Nice and smooth with a slight hops bitterness and a nice alcohol warming.  Very easy drinking, which could get you into trouble.  A good quality triple.

Cellared for about 8 months.  It has a nice golden tint with a thin layer of foam and excellent lacing.  The yeasty aroma is sweet and complex, with fruity esters a plenty.  It's well carbonated with a bitter touch on the end, but the flavor doesn't live up to the nose.  I could probably use one more year of aging to round off the edges.  Tasty none the less. A nice standard tripel.  The finish could be a bit more dry.
Large fluffy head. Aroma of straw and dough. Flavor of straw, dough, must, and a slight cirtus zest. Medium body but very light and refreshing in flavor with a peppery bite.

You'll want to dive into a pool of this stuff ... WARNING!  It's that good for a 'light' Belgian (if there is one?).  A pizza belgian if there ever was one.  Go for it ... and if you miss the turn, head for the New Belgian Brewing Co. sign.

Thick, dense, off-white head atop a hazy, amber body. This beer displays excellent head retention and produces the definition of lacing. Bubble gum sweetness in the aroma with a bit of corinader spiciness. The flavor is a very smooth maltiness, with coriander and decent hops in the finish. A bit of sweetness lingers on the aftertaste. The mouthfeel is superb, very rich and satisfying.
One of my favorited, though I caution you to never mix this with Aventinus in your belly.  Beautiful color and head.  Flavor and color are both wonderful.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2004 Nice dense white head. Little dark, golden colour. Aroma; little acidic, fruity (banana), yeast, bread. Taste; citrus, pepper, bitter. Complex. Re-rate: maybe its my palate but this isnt getting better!
Faint smell of hops; nice cloudy medium amber with a long-lasting tan head; distinctive taste of hops along with a smooth tripel feel; not the best of the tripels I've tried

Poured cloudy gold with big white head. Good head retention. Grainy spicey aroma with a hint of dark fruit present too. Lovely smooth full body. Nice simple wheaty flavour with a spicey clove-like aftertaste. Hint of citrus in taste too.
Light orange in color with a small fizzy head. Aroma is spice(pepper), fruit and yeast. Flavor is malty sweet with fruit and spice. Lighty bitter. Finish is slightly bitter. Well carbonated.

Golden/orange and hazy with a creamy big head. Clean aroma of spices, malt, apples and alcohol. Quite bittersweet in flavour. Malty flavour of oranges and and honey. Dry bitter finish with strong notes of grapefruit.
A nice amber pour slightly cloudy. Pleasing fruity aroma. Sour flavors with some spice. Small bitterness in the finish. Certainly a good tripel.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2004 Amber color. Plenty of sediment floating throughout. Very pungent. Smells of fruits. Dry bitter flavor, somewhat burnt. Very flavorful beer. Bites you in the sinuses to the back of the throat.
