Beer pours (in Chimay glass) a medium orange-golden liquid light penetrates with a generous amount of virgin-white head that collapses quickly but leaves plenty of great looking head.  Aroma is of sweet straw, citrus lemon and pineapple.  Flavor is a somewhat dry, toasty wood, barkline, sour and slight pine needle that gives way to a clean, but somewhat dry palate.  Sampled at 71 degrees Fahrenheit.

Golden color, good carbonation and lacing.  Lighter tasting than I expected, compared to Chimay Red and Blue.  Not enough flavor in my opinion, but a fine beer overall.  Has the Chimay flavor but certainly more hops than the others.  I'd go with the Blue if I had a choice.
Pale amber color, a ton of carbonation.  Spicy, pepper aroma, banana flavors.  The best Chimay with seafood, IMHO.

750 ml. brown bottle. Corked & caged. 2003 seen on the cork.
Highly carbonated, because the cork nearly shot out of the bottle as I opened it. Poured a cloudy orange color, with major chill haze.
Frothy white head never did subside. I had to spoon it out just so I could smell it. Peppery aroma right off the bat. Typical funky Belgian yeast smell to it as well. Kind of horsey actually. Not quite as bad as a lambic, but not far off, either. Not much in the hops department. Aroma or taste wise. Malt & lactic wheat tastes to this (apparently) popular Belgian. Thin mouthfeel, highly carbonated, almost too much so. Has a phenolic character to it as well. Not my favorite Belgian, but then again, not too awful bad.

75 cL bottle, goblet, 10/01 bottling, 57 degrees.  Gigantic, fizzy, frothy, white head lasts well and leaves great lacing.  Body is an amber-orange and is hazy from a dense collection of tiny and small particles.  Light toasted light bread and toasted grain malt aroma; medium flowery, sprucey, citric (lime) hop aroma; light cobweb yeast aroma; light white grapes, rome apples, clove and alcohol aromas.  The aroma is much lighter than I was expecting.  I am immediately stunned by how smooth this is for a hoppier beer and how well the dryness builds from start to aftertaste.  Impressive.  Moderately sweet, lightly bitter flavor becomes a lightly sweet, moderately bitter finish.  Absolutely no acidity.  The aftertaste grows more dry as the malt falls away from the hops.  Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation.  For me, this one is more about the mouthfeel than the taste.  The flavor is quite simple compared to the aroma.  The bottom line is: excellent looking and a great example of how a "lighter" beer can have great mouthfeel.

Big foamy pure white head that lingers with a bit of lacing. Aroma is yeasty and bubbly, slightly sweet, although pretty weak overall. Flavor is very belgian-like (I'm always at a loss to explain this better), yeasty, a touch of sweetness, very dry throughout, very carbonated. Mouthfeel is pretty nice, as thick as you would want a triple to be. Overall a great offering, and one of my favorite triples.

Hazy golden color with a snow white head. Yeasty aroma with some banana and hints of hops. Citrusy flavor underneath the yeast. Slightly bitter, which was unexpected but not disliked. Another good Chimay.

Dark copper orange color and a puffy white head.  Rich bready yeast aroma with soft malty presence.  Body is thick, sweet and complex, with everything from caramel malt to dark fruits and some spice.  Finishes crisp and dry.  Very smooth and balanced.
8/29/03:  bottle.   immense, slightly off-white head.  apricot body. huge nose of yeast, florals, bread, esters, lots of hops and even some champagne.  some piney-ness and more bitter than expected.

very pleasant beer, pours a hazy golden color.  Off white head, produces small fluffy bubbles with a good amount of carbonation.  I smell banana, and a complexity of other aromas that I cannot differentiate.  Very smooth and drinkable, a nice bitterness to finish.

Pours a honey color with a 2-3cm white head which stays around pretty well with nice lacing.  Beer is cloudy with notes of yeast.  Aroma is interesting--almost like a sweet banana bread.  Start is very smooth with hints of bananas, fruits, and perhaps some other spices.  The banana nature is not consistent with a hefeweizen.  Carbonation is good and palate is tolerable.

Pale gold body with a huge white head. Some lacing.
Yeast with a nice bit of floral hops in the aroma. There's some banana too. Slight hint of wheat that previews the bite ahead.
Yeast, banana/clove phenols, malty and a  slightly sour grape taste all jump out. Nice bitterness ends the taste before the alcohol burns. Very dominant alcohol finish that warms you up and sticks with you.
Surprisingly I find this beer to have a medium body. Dry finish. Hopefully a year or two in the bottle will meld the flavors together.

It was Valentines Day, the day for all lovers to show their true feelings. My wife was having her favorite wine with dinner. I was having dinner with my mistressa good beer. I chose a bottle of Chimay White for my evening, I had enjoyed the Chimay Red and wanted to try something different but something I was reasonably sure would be good.

After opening the bottle, which is pretty fun actually (uncorking a bottle of beer is something you dont do everyday in the states), I poured the nectar into my glass. It poured a cloudy light amber, bordering on orange. The head was ample, but descended in a short couple of minutes.

For a beer with an 8% alcohol content, I was surprised that the aroma was so subdued. I was also struck by a subtle citrus smell.

At first taste, I noticed a sweet, fruity flavor that was as subtle as the aroma. The aftertaste was short-lasting. There really is no overpowering flavor here, a combination of fruit, malt and a creamy spiciness that made for a very satisfying mouthfeel. 

This is a superb beer. I imagine it would be excellent either at the dinner table or the bar. It is one of the most satisfying ales I have ever had, because of its subtle combination of flavors and its smooth drinkability. A world class beer.

Didn't like this one as much as the Chimay Rouge ... was just as smooth but seemed less distinctive. Less character somehow. A little more of an alcoholic finish, to be expected, I suppose. Smooth, but not as smooth to me as the rouge. Still, a beautiful beer with a pleasant aroma. Great taste, just not as pleasing to me overall as the rouge.

Amber, gold colour.  Delicate, floral nose.  Alcoholic heat finish, with caramel notes.  I had this particular beer on tap at Monk's in Philadelphia - I'm  inclined to believe it would be better in a bottle, given Chimay's reputation.  I found it this time to have too much alcoholic heat - the Belgians are usually much better at hiding it.
Wonderful Chimay. The taste is sweet and lightly fruity although more herbal. Simple with a defined head. Also packs a punch (a hard pucnh if you arent careful)
Golden brown with a nice white head. Yeasty, spiced aroma. Light dry taste. Moderately spiced flavor, a godd bitter touch in the finish.

(Draught) Amber-clear; white, creamy but small head. Grape-like nose, white-wineish. Sweet taste with herbal qualities. Bitterish "Belgian" type hops. No more fruity flavours, which I seem to remember. Retronasal a harsh metallic, stannum-like tang. If it weren't for the palate ruined by the metallic taste, medium to quite full bodied. Reasonably refreshing. The beer is quite good, not great. The finish is just awful. I'm pretty sure their modern brewing methods have partially ruined a once great classic.

While the least impressive of this brand (I like red and blue a bit better) this is by no bad. In fact its quite good and gave me a good buzz. It is like Bass ale in its thickness and sweet sour flavor but much more consistent. Obvousliy this is higher in quality than Bass but there are similarites. I would drink this again and you know what I like it.

Aroma has light Belgian qualities, slight fruit hops and banana/clove. Clear yellow color, awesome lacing and a persistent white creamy head. Sweet and salty color, zesty and tangy. I had this one while fighting a bad hangover, so the strong ABV in this made me sick to my stomach, but was still tasty. Clean finish and bready on the palate. Overall a good Belgian whtat reminded me of Lucifer (the beer, not Satan).

A beautiful sight in the bour, golden and arimatic, with very vibrant carbonation, that is especially entertaining to watch it disperse the yeast throughout.  Creamy fizzy head, that lasts and lasts throughout the drink.  A faint echo of hops is present, with a floral fruity bouquet that is very refreshing.  Very pleasant on the palette, from the flavor and the aroma.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2004 A cloudy golden body.
A balanced aroma from some toffee and perfume.
Champagnelike palate.
The Cinq Cent has a cedar-tree-aroma and flavour; or like a pencil(?).

a orange to brown cloudy colour, and a massive long lasting creamy head. it has a fruity and spicey aroma. quite a smokey finish to the taste and has an alcohol taste as well. bitter and overall quite satisfying.

This golden beer has a rich creamy head with heavy lacing. The nose is sweet with bready malt and lightly herbal hops. The medium-bodied palate is creamy with lgiht malty character and a touch of citrusy hops as well as the slightest hint of wet paper. The finish is lightly malty with some afterthoughts of herbal hops.
A golden light amber with a large beige rocky head.  Crisp spring like line dried sheets aroma.  Alcohol is the dominate aroma though once this warms as is the taste. Average.

Golden color,medium sized foamy head that had a decent amount of staying power.Malty aroma with slightly sweet tone mild hops and a slight floral attitude.The flavor was mildly malty with a good fruity taste the alcohol has a little bite to it in the taste but it fades after awhile.The after taste is bitter with a slight fruit tone to it.Nice feel in the mouth Fairly high carbonation,kind of makes the flavors dance around on the toungue a bit.Not bad,I think i prefer some of the American versions a little more then this one but it certainly is a pretty good brew.

My least favorite of the Chimay colors, but it's still very good.  Mindboggingly huge head that eventually (after like 15 minutes) fades into a light layer lazily floating on the surface.  Yeasty and hoppy aroma that lends to the same in the taste along with hints of raisin.  it also has a pleasant aftertaste that melts quickly.

Lovely white head.  Aroma is slightly hoppy, citrus, a bit yeasty, apricot and pears, and a little pepper.  Nice golden, hazy color.  Taste is peaches, peppery, lovely dry finish.  My favorite Chimay.

On tap! First ever tapped here in Arizona. What a treat. Deep rich blond head. Aroma is distinctively malty, a little fruity. A wonderful balance of complex flavors shine through. It's highlighted in the end by a dry, zesty finish. Drinking this ,I'm only a few stories from heaven.

11oz. bottle. Substantial white head, Great lacing. Spicey nose with some alc. aromas too. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, nice. Fruity, yeasty with a slight peppery flavor also. Has a noticable acidity too. Alcohol is evident in the dry finish.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2004 Golden-orange body with considerable carbonation and a massive frothy white head. Fantastic quality of esters in the aroma: bubble gum, banana, and strawberry. Also orange citrus, yeast, baking soda, hay, and barnyard. Has the Chimay signature aroma that's hard to pinpoint verbally. Fruit peel bitterness, pepper, and flowers in the flavor. Tingly but smooth feel. The smoothest and most drinkable of the Chimay brews. It melts in your mouth. Complex for sure but not in the Chimay Bleu range.

Hazy amber hue with a nice head and good lacing, medium-bodied. Fresh fruity and pine aroma. Undertones of spice, grapes, hay, and cheese. Creamy yet lively mouthfeel leads to a very nice taste. Balance sweetness and acidic quality. Bitterness shows in the finish as does some alcohol. I'm still not quite convinced this is a true tripel, more akin to a dubbel in my book, and that's all that matters.

Unlike anything else!  Nice foam and good lacing.  Pours a nice cider color with some cloudiness and yeast sediment in the bottle.  Smell is not that appealing, but the taste is wonderful!  A sweet fruitiness with the taste of hops without being overly flowery.  A complex flavor.  An incredible balance!  And what a kick!
Was real excited about this Chimay seeing that i haven't met a Chimay i didn't like till now.was not impressed.Poured nice but the taste was too hoppy.

very mild and fruity aroma with a nice golden color that finished off cloudy.  
Fruity and malty at first, but finished with an astringent, but pleasent after taste.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2017 2017-04-07. Hazy orange amber body nice creamy frothy head and lace. 3++
Aroma of bready biscuity pale malt, light alcohol. 7+ Flavour is pleasant. Bready biscuity pale malt, decent amount of bitterness throughout, moderate alcohol amplifies the bitterness in the finish. Average bodied palate, good carbonation. 3+ Decent but just a touch more bitter and alcoholic than I am in the mood for today. 7/4/7/3/16 Bottle from the LCBO, Toronto 
2007-09-XX. Lightly hazy yellow body with a huge long lasting fluffy white head. Sweet doughy aroma, lightly malty, mild yeast. Simple flavour is yeasty, lightly alcoholic and fairly sweet up front with a dry finish. Sweet doughy-bready malt is quickly dried out by a finish that is lightly alcoholic, and mildly bitter and creates a pleasant balance. Not the most complex tripel you can find, but has sufficient richness to make it a pleasantly drinkable example.  Smooth medium palate (3+). Nice. 7/4/7/4/15 - 3.7 Bottle. 
2001-01-XX - Disappointing. Nice tripel, very smooth mouthfeel, but I enjoyed similar offerings from Unbroue more. Don De Dieu comes to mind... 6/4/6/5/15 - 3.6
Yellow color with a nice thick white head. Smooth taste with a nice mild bitter finish. Gets better when more than 12 degress celsius.

Light amber with a thick white head.  Yeasty and malty aroma; almost wheaty.  Also, alcoholic on the aroma.  Very carbonated, light bodied, malty finishing with a mild bitterness.  Surprisingly smooth.

Bright golden with a thick creamy head. Big sheets of lace. Mild aroma. Slightly stinky in such a way that stinky is not necessarily bad. Definite clove notes. Lots of carbonation but it's very soft and not at all sharp or biting. Full bodied. Finish is moderately bitter with some earthy hop notes and a sticky bit of lingering sweetness. In my opinion, the best Chimay. The others taste like sweet alcohol-water to me. This has real complexity and substance.
I expected more from Chimay.  Good carbonation quite fizzy, generous head dies quickly. I agree that this beer finishes with a metallic bitterness.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2006 Cloudy golden orange with a fluffy, disappearing head. Fruity aroma with some hops. Quite sweet, very fruity (banana) and some alcohol.
- Re-rated since it was one of my first ratings and excitement over good beer took over back then
Generous head  with attractive lacing.  Unfiltered golden appearance.  Pleasant yeasty aroma.  Nicely carbonated.  Fruits and spices in the taste, with a good bitter bite.  Very satisfying.

This beer is overrated.  Beers like Allagash and New Belgium Trippel flat our put this metallic tasting import on its ass.  Where are the raisins, yeast ala New Belgium.  This brew defintely suffers by comparison.  I profer that it is rather ironic that the top rated Belgian Trippels are all U.S. brews.  I concur completely.

As for the rating:  Brew pours massive floating head.  Appearance is golden amber.  So far so good.  Flavor is somewhat complex.  Metallic finish is a deal breaker.  Bring on the New Belgium.
there is only one chimay.  cloudly golden beer with a wonderful noise.  one of the few abbeys that i could sit and drink all day long.

Chimay white is a very beautiful brew. It pours a foggy sparkling pumpkin color. The aroma is reminiscent of hops and ripened fruit; it has a somewhat dry taste to it as well. 
A very grand beer, but still not as desirable as the blue.
light cloudy golden color with nice head. yeasty, wheat, flowery nose. Yeasty wheaty flowery, hoppy, slight hefe taste. Champange carbonation.

In a word, delicious. This delicate. creamy brew pours to a dark golden color, with good carbonation. The thick foamy white head dissipates quickly with minamal lacing. This beer is gently malty, with almost no hop flavor. This beer tastes like a rich desert, peaches or apricots drizzled with sugar and ladled with thick dollaps of cream and vanilla. In spite of the 8% ABV  the alcohol taste was minimal. It's hard to believe this beer is slightly stronger than the darker and fuller-flavored Chimay Rouge. A smooth, extremely drinkable Belgian Ale, this beer is my favorite Chimay.

Does it make a difference that I have had this from the genuine glass? You can see why they recomend this glass. Beautiful billowy head that settles well and leaves a great lacing all the way down. Subtle fruity nose, and a prominent hop bitterness on the back palate. Another excellent beer.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: Spicy and bitter. Fruity with a strong taste of alcohol. Nice head and colour

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2004  75 cl Bottle, 2002 Vintage 
Hazy orange. Woody, geueze-like aroma, i.e a little sourness. Flavour is smooth malty, rich woody(or is it cork?), a little chocolatey and finishes woody. This one might suffer from the cork, but what the heck.
UPDATED: FEB 24, 2005 Not my favourite of the Chimay  colors.  Very clear, and carbonated.  Spicy and peppery.  Large alchohol presence.  Duvel is more interesting to me if I am in this zone.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2006 Pale Golden. Pours with a wonderful champagne effervesence.
You MUST DRINK THIS at the right temperature (56-57ish) or the flavor will not come out and you will not get the true experience.  Just tried this in the small bottle. WOW! This is the best tripel Ive had to date(RERATE.  Ive tried alot more tripels, this is still good, but not as good as some of the best ones).  It didnt suffer from the overly yeasty/grainy flavor I see in so many belgians.  Had a great floral flavor at points and I even thought I tasted some citrus notes.  The alcohol was not reserved for the finish and was pleasantly present throughout and adds to a huge yeasty/raisiny complex body.  While I was drinking this, I kept thinking of an abbey pale and even an american pale.  It had a wonderfully even body which I did not find myself wanting more of at the end, which is usually the case with most beers.  This is one of the better beers Ive tried in fact and many brewers could learn a lesson from this.  Only things detracting from this beer is its need of a little extra kick of something in the main body, though I should reiterate, it does have a wonderful medium- full body. I have looked, and I do not taste any metallic bitterness on the finish.  Rerate, it dosent have nearly as much flavor as many smaller brewed belgians and is a bit astringent.  This one is much more on the drier side, could stand more malt/bubble gum.  Good sharp lemon/hops/citrus mix on the aroma.Draught tulip at redbones, January 2006Fairly aggressive yeastiness, plenty of perfumey alcohol esters and lots of dry, grainy biscuity malt.  Dry fruits on the end, but could use something to anchor it, ie. more malt and body.  Seemed a little too aerated and bubbly, with too much sharpness.  Not quite as much finesse or sheer flavor as some of the best in the class, but I need to get a 750mL bottle and sit down and give it a better review.
Clear amber color; generous head, as usual. Complex, warm aroma with malty and wooden notes. Taste is full-bodied, rich, creamy, spicy and distinctly bitter. Medium lasting, bitter finish.

The most delicious beer I've ever tasted.  Slightly sweet, slightly bitter, but with no barky or herbal taste in the bitterness of the aftertaste.  The sweetness is very light and smooth, which makes this beer exceptionally drinkable without any of the buildup of bitterness that you'd see in a different sweet style, like an oatmeal stout.
Bright gold pour with a nice coriander and hop aroma. Flavor was an excellent combination of malt and fruit. A very good belgian.
Hazy orange color, and a nice fluffy white head, simply gorgeous.  Some spices and maybe bananna in the aroma.  Taste was wonderful.  Spicey and peppery, and a bitter finish.  Excellent.

Bottled. Verbose white fluffy head. Golden colour with a few specs of yeast. Sweet aroma. Bitter taste. Baggs of alcohol coming of it. Which for me doesn't rate highly. I like my strong beers to be sly about it.
Smooth.  Nice balance between initial sweetness, acerbic assertion midway through, and a yeasty finish.  Peppery?? aftertaste.  Intriguing.
was the better of the Chimay brews, more complex, peppery, flavorful delight

Draft - I had this beer on draft and it was good, but I prefer it out of the bottle.  Great color with great white head.  Very smooth packed with citrus.  Though I have found the quality going down a bit in the bottles over the years, Chimay remains one of my favorites.
Orange looking out of the bottle. good head with a citrus aroma. Taste sweet but a little too much for me. Finish is a little hoppy.A good Trappist but I would pick Blue or Red over this.

Pours with a norange gold body topped by a thick rocky white head with good retention and a good amount of lace.  Flowery, orangey aroma with yeasty and spicy notes and a slight sourness.  Slightly sweet yet sour and salt flavor with flowery notes and orange accents.  The finish is short, bitter and flowery.  Medium bodied, dry and smooth.

This beer pours an orange color with a very citrus filled aroma and a medium head.  The taste is sweet and very strong of citrus.  This was a great drink and it was very smooth.  I would have this again if not for the high price.
Cloudy orange color with very sweet, citrus aroma. Taste is sweet and malty with a slightly bitter aftertaste.
Poured a cloudy orange with a large frothy head. yeasty aroma with with spice and citrus. taste was mostly citrus with hints of spices,with a somewhat sweet malty taste, good

Orange colour, cloudy appereance, huge, creamy head. yeasty aroma, with citrus hints. The flavour is yeasty, fruity (citrus, apple and orange peels) with a touch of sweetness (honey). The finish is hoppy. Good complexity, perfect balancement: another excellent trappist beer!
Yeasty almost homebrewed aroma.  Light amber.  Quite hoppy with a sweet, malty aftertaste.  I'd choose the Grande Reserve or Red over this Chimay.
This is a very good beer. Poured a bloudy orange with a nice white head.  Taste was very spritzy and fruity...very nice.

Golden orange color, hazy, with big, long lasting head. Some citrus aroma, wheat, yeast, maybe some moldy cheese hangin' out in there. Some pepper aroma and flavor, a little malt and grape flavors as well. Incredibly smooth. Dry, just a little bitter aftertaste. Complex, all around enjoyable, great in bottles and on tap. Favorite of the Chimay line.

Golden color, lots of white head that seems to just keeps coming.  Sweet citrus aroma and the smell of yeast.  Taste is very smooth and sweet.  Small aftertaste of alcohol, but nothing too impressive.

This is the big Chimay tripel. It pours a hazy yellow-straw color with a dense white head. You can see the carbonation in the murky brew and thick lace.

Aroma is of orange rind, lemon and Granny Smith apples, and a touch of cheese.

Carbonation quick to the palate, taste is rich with charred lemons and faint alcohol esters mixed with coriander. A great deal of dryness throughout with a crisp mouthfeel and a lingering bitter finish. Alcohol content is there, but the complexity of flavors works to obscure it. Good Belgian beer.
UPDATED: MAY 1, 2003 what a great beer! only available at one bar here in Iceland so this is not my everyday beer. What a aroma! and the taste, very complex, unique and this just melts in your mouth.

A nice pale colour, served in the authentic Chimay goblet. Small amount of a slightly off-white head. Subtle smell, definate yeastyness though. A good example of a nice medium bodied belgian beer, with complex flavours lingering in every corner. I've had it in bottles a few times, but I was completely unaware they sold this in the Keg (from Belgium). Tasted on Tap at MacGregor's in Rochester, New York.

gazing into the full bottle is like peering with a forlorn and flickering flashlight across the musty attic of a haunted house: the webs and mildews of suspended yeast are trepidating, a million little gooey orbs of doomed microbial colonies. oh yum. but a brisk pour in a clean glass restores that flimy ghostly murk to a daisy golden rebirth of linen foamy topped youthful alacrity-- like cracking open a curtained window to a sunny day.  simultaneously, the aroma leaps out with a nymphomanical proclivity for being caressed, panting promises of dripping crushed apples, a cord of hatchet split pine, with banana and powdered clove, almost enough to make you sneeze.  start of applesauce sweetness both confounds and coalesceses with dry pepper-studded hard bodied finish in an apparently contradictory and yet beautifully realized harmony. strange but interesting tongue-curling astringent finish.

yeasty orange like nose, cloudy brown hue with a large and frothy slowly dissipating head, some wood tones, traces of nuts, sherry like acidity, a very comlex beer but the flavours maybe not exactly to my liking
Just a gorgeous Tripel. Complex, delicious, beautiful. Chimay's are all they are cracked up to be, for sure. Complex, delicious, and they become more so as they warm.
A beautiful beer, in my opinion one of the best.  A wonderful subtle balance of flavours.

The first smell, i kinda stuick my nose in a little too far, and sniffed a little to hard, and i thought my nose was going to fall off, just the way i like it. Yeasty, champagne like, ciderish.
Taste is spicey, hops are well presents, nicelty carbonated.
I quite liked this beer, i'll have it again, and again, and again.
Very light brown with a large head. Smells like manure, cow and pig farm with a little citrus added. Taste sweet with light wheat flavor.
Draft: Straw color. Cloudy. Nice head. Definite hop flavor and aroma. Banana esters. Needs more time. Too fresh.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2003 Bottled: Is golden coloured. Hazy with pretty head. Lots of spices in the nose. Has lots of alcahol in the flavour but is well spiced and sweetish. Has a light bitterness in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2005 These days this is probably my favorite Chimay. A very nicely done Tripel. A murky and dirty yellow appearance. Lots of apricots and peaches in the nose. A somewhat sour and dry taste with some oranges, pears, and peaches showing in the flavor. A spicy and somewhat sour aftertaste. It hides the alcohol quite well. Good one!

This is a very nice beer, it took me a while to figure it out. 
It has large head lasting long time, some fruits and spices, a little sour with a some bitterness in the aftertaste, nice but i prefer the blue :)

Body is golden with a slight haze.  Particles were also present.  Head is large and in charge and laces with great patience.  Aroma was mild with floral notes.  Taste was slightly fruity, spicey and quite hoppy.  Finish was bitter.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 First impression wow! It almost foamed out of the glass even though it was cold. 1/3 beer 2/3 foam! It was very lively and carbonated. Wow, it even has a good head in the bottle after I poured it! There were a lot of fine bubbles that continuously rose up the side of the glass. Very long lasting head continuously reinforced by the carbonation. This brew has a very light amber color with some particles floating around in it. It also has a very mild aroma that is hard to notice. It reminded me of nothing in particular. The carbonation rolled off my tongue yet the taste was mostly of that carbonation with a mild fore and after taste. I liked the taste though. This is a beer I could get drunk on. Lets see if it has the stomach upsetting qualities that some of the other Chimayan ales have had. Time will tell. GF gave it a 4.1 rating. She said she could drink it all night long. That's a pretty good rating from her!
Cloudy medium gold, lots of foam. Nose is floral, spicy  and active. Flavor is nicely subdued and classy, with just the right amounts of fruit, spice and bitter finish. An outstanding creation.
A light golden color with a 2 finger rocky head. A nice sour floral aroma. Smooth palate. A sour citrus flavor with bitterness and spices.
On tap: nice yeasty flavor, fair amount of carbonation.  The color is golden, slightly hazy.  Very tasty.  A little fruity, clove taste.

(33cl bottle) As part of a LCBO gift pack with red and blue, the white Chimay pours a frothy, almond cappuccino head and a cloudy orange body. Beautiful visually. Faint aroma of fruit, oak and spice. Full-bodied flavour, perhaps more spicey than the other two Chimays but same mellow, bitter finish.

Fruity, bits of orange peel, woody, horse blanket. Kind of weak. Orange amber and hazy with little off-white lacing head. Champagne-like fizziness. Heavy watery body. Astringent. OK sweetness and nutty, bitter after. Peppery and fruity. Some yeast, grass, earthy. Interesting taste and a slightly odd bitterness. Dry.  Had it on tap, but maybe not a good one.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2003 Wow, I feel like I hit the jack pot tonite.  This is an aged bottle.  Yeasty, alcoholish aroma, and a malty, yeasty flavor.  Unbelievably good.  Somewhat sweet on the finish.  I worried about the $5.20 I paid for this bottle, it was worth every penny of it and the good news is there is one more of the aged bottles hidden in the store!

A nice head, but an unusual sent apon pouring, an almost sour smell has a slightly offputting effect but the taste is smooth and not as bitter as expected, a mellow peachy flavour lingers on the tounge then melts wonderfully. An magnificent brew.

Active upon opening. Thin white head and an odor like fresh cut grass or hay. This follows into the taste and carries a lightly toasted quality to boot. Slight bitterness lingers at the back of the tounge, nice, not outstanding, but very enjoyable.

In spite of its OG (20 Plato) this Trappist has a surprisingly light body with a distinct malty flavour and a hint of Junipher in the finish. Try to keep the bottle for, at least, two years before opening.

It is extremely similar to Chimay Red without the abundance of flavors and yet it is equally as impressive. Even though they are all perfect beers I believe the Chimay taste ladder begins with Red on top followed by Blue and then White.
I really like this kind of beer. It has a lot to offer. Complete head that last, golden-colored. Lot of sweetness, strength, and herbs.

What did I learn? Never be a cheap fuc#*ing bastard when it comes to tasty beers that you never see on tap! I tasted some of my friend's blanche on tap but didn't buy my own glass of it. And I've been thinking about it ever since. It was incredible compared to the bottled version. Wonderful fruity aroma with a light citrusness and a bit of alcohol. Sweet and fruity with a light spicy aftertaste and some bitterness. Fizzy and highly carbonated with a light body. Some alcohol in the aftertaste. Much better on tap.

Slightly cloudy appearance.  Head initially quite large, then subsides into thin foam.  Quite fruity with clove spice very apparent.  Slightly bitter finish, but rather dry.  Yeasty notes.  A nice beer for 300, but definitely the Allagash deserves its higher rating.

Awesome, especially having the red, white & blue side by side. This is the fruitiest and leaves an awesome sweet, dark fruity, then bitter aftertaste.  Thanks to Jaymobrown for bringing the Chimays over!

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2008 While the color is a nice strawberry blond (heavy on the berry), the head fades quickly a a thin, off white layer floating atop the beer.  Nose is lovely.  Often the nose of a beer improves as it warms and the nose here was immediately pronounced, sweet and enticing.  Flavor, especially when compared with the nose, is unexpectedly dry, perhaps a bit too heavy on the carbonation, and lightly bitter.  After such a sweet nose, this is very surprising.  Palate features an extended, mild bitterness.
Nice color with a medium size head. Fruity aroma and taste, with complex spicy tones, Chimay blue and red heaps better.

Chimay makes gorgeous beers to gaze upon - runways models in a glass with elegant and sunstantial lace and enviable coloring.  There are some sweeter, candy leaning tones that disturb me on occassion, but I like the rest of thios beer a lot - very spciy and fun and full of confounding fruits and darker spices, hops breesing steadily in.
This is a pretty good beer. Nice color and big white head. Stong aroma of yeast. Fruity and spicey flavor. This is a good beer, but it's not my favorite Chimay.
Overall I thought this was a pretty good tripel.  More hop flavor and bitterness than other beers in the style.  Pleasant spiciness and fruitiness in the aroma.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2003 Beautiful to look at, a light brandy color with a nice thick small bubbled head. Aroma smells of hops and that unusual Chimay aroma that must be a product of their yeast.  Hoppy more so than the other beers of Chimay slight taste of wine the hops are a stand out, again making this beer much different than Chimays other beers

This beer poured a dark gold color and formed a bubbly white head that left trace lace when it subsided. An aroma of malt, citrus and lightly of caramel. The flavor was of malt and caramel and the finish was quite dry. Not my favorite of the Chimays, but still a very good beer.

Another classic from this wonderful label.  Too hoppy for my taste but you simply have to admire the pure "class" of these beers.  That unique Chimay taste with way more hops than the either the Red or the Blue.  This one I really like cold.  Very nice to have around but not my personal favourite.
UPDATED: MAR 17, 2004 Pours a golden apricot color with tiny bubbles and a thick white head. Aroma is spicy and yeasty. Flavor is complex and spicy and the palate is champange like. Nice Tripel.

The appearance is perfect, a thick white head crowning a translucent golden liquid. The smell is tantalizing. The taste however is the best part. It tastes sweet, but in a way that does not assault the senses. There is a hoppy, fruity taste followed by a welcomed hint of bitterness. The palate is full, more than I expected in such a light beer.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2012 White frothy head sitting atop a slightly opaque golden color. Smells heavy of yeast and malt.  Taste is very smooth and nice on your tongue.  Yeast taste is strong, with light hints of sweet fruit.
Huge white frothy head.  HInts of yeast & a nice toasty maltiness.  Very gentle, clean & crisp.  Plenty of subdued hops.  Great yeast presence among the light fruits and sweetness.
very dry, but it had a nice bitter bite to it.

I had this draft, so I assume that it may be younger than the bottled versions described by other raters.  Clear, not cloudy as I expected.  Great lace after the small white head dissipated.  Taste of cloves, pepper, wheat, and alcohol, a little fruitiness (banana maybe), and then a lightly bitter finish.
A phenom of a trippel. Pours with a grand head and beautifully cloudy body. Flavor is very refreshing especially for a beer of this strength. Very drinkable and very very ejoyable

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2016 2016-11-24, LAK-237, bb 2005, 14 years old, 6-3-7-2-13=31Cloudy amber color, it looks like the carbonation is missing, and the head is very small. The aroma is like a dessert, a pudding rich of raisins, also dates, light vanilla, and just a hint of oxidisation; meaty. With such low carbonation the mouthfeel is quite oily; the body is not thick, but the total absence of bitterness highlights the little residual sweetness; it hs a quite evident fruity malt flavor, raisins, plums; the oxidisation is really minimal; the flavors decrease rapidly towards the final.Not exactly a good beer, but it held up quite well to its age.2010-08-11, draught at Ris Ras, Århus, 8-5-8-2-16=39Cloudy light amber color; small sized creamy head. Malty aroma. Strong body, round; good malt flavor, a bit biscuity, somehow yeasty and spicy too; very good flavor, but the bitterness is a bit too much.2008-04-04, draught at Ris Ras, Århus, 7-4-8-4-16=39Just hazy golden color, creamy head. Soft aroma of malt, and light biscuits, maybe a bit perfumy. It has a good malt flavor, dry, with a good body strength, with a very good Belgian yeast job. Well bitter. Very good.2003-01-14, bottle, vintage 1997, 5ys old, 8-5-8-4-16=41Beautiful amber color, thick head.Very nice aroma, more delicate than Chimay Red; caramel and old hops.Good body structure and good balance; it has aged well, just some oak cask flavor, and a light liquorice hint.Final stronger and more interesting than Chimay Red.
Very cloudy, nice colour and head. Sweetish and discreet. Lacks of character.
I thought this was almost as good as the blue.  The slight bitterness wasnt much of a factor in the overall quality.  Still a fine brew. Excellent in its own way. ;)
Very nice restraint and bitterness after sampling a lot of sweet Belgians.

Clean, light and effervescent mouthfeel; almost champagne-like in a way. Gentle spices come through as the beer warms. Malts are soft and dough-like. Finishes somewhat dry, bitter, and a little oily. Enjoyable beer, but it doesnt seem to have as much character as the blue or red.

Pale gold color with a thick and foamy head.  Not as good as the other Chimay offerings, but still pretty decent.  There is a bite that gets you with this beer, and the bitterness seems almost out of place.

My least favorite Chimay! Im glad I opted for the smaller bottle of this one. Pours a light gold color with a thick white head. Nice effervescence and minimal lacing. Aroma was actually skunked a little which surprised me. Some spices were also evident but it was ruined by the skunk factor. The flavor was a peppery and yeasty and light. I will try this again sometime and hopefully have a better experience, but at $4 for the small bottle it wont be any time soon.
I was most surprised by the strong peppery flavors - very enjoyable, as was the dryness.  Nice golden color with bubbly head and good lacing.
UPDATED: JUL 14, 2004 Big sour fruit and raisin nose.  Peppery, hoppy flavors.  Very yeasty.  Full mouthfeel, slightly oily, finely carbonated.  Tasty, but not worth the cash.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2004 I actually prefer this brew to all of the other Belgian Strong Ales I have sampled to date (including Westvleteren 12, Trois Pistoles, and Chimay Rouge) - more warming than I expected with a nice dose of sediment lingering at the bottom of the bottle.  Very hoppy nose, not nearly as fruity as Trois Pistoles, nice reddish orange pour with medium light orange head.  Beer has a great mouthfeel up front with a well defined balance between the high alcohol content and carbonation - alcohol is more cleverly disguised than in other Belgian Ales of this magnitude.  Very bready, yeasty flavor with a strong finish.
UPDATED: JAN 7, 2003 Orange color, medium head. Bready/yeasty aroma. Peppery, strong carbonation, somewhat acidic

Smells like a fresh loaf of bread. This was very unpleasant for me for whatever reason. Im discerning a trend with these white, spicey beasts; they just dont sit well with me. I didnt enjoy this like the red and blue but was over powered by a peppery spice and an almost bland watery finish. Granted the next belgian-phile would love this, but for me it was near naueseating. big points though for the AMAZING bready, yeasty aroma and palate/complexity.
A nice warming beer.  Best at cellar temperature.  Good delicate flavors nicely matched with a good alcohol zing.  No discernable aroma.  Good color.  The Red is best, but this one aint bad.
its good but i rather have the blue and the red instead. but if i couldnt have those to i wouldnt mind this
Good pale colour with a nice head. Spicy triple taste, with a fresh palate.

RE-RATE:  Had this on tap at Monks.  Still quite good.  Has a little extra silkiness to on tap.  Original: An excellent beer.  Ive been so keen on trying others that I havent had this since RateBeer started.  Full bodied enough, but just a little light as compared to some other of this type.  As for tripels, I prefer the Allagash or Duvel.

Very pleasurable to drink.  Very smooth as expected from Chimay, although its astringency gives it a little sting.  Something about the mouthfeel bothers me a bit, possibly a little greasy? (diacetyl?) Anyway, it is a good brew.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2009 Lighter red than than the rouge. Typicaly big head for Chimay. Still yeasty but hint of rasins. bitter tatse. 11/12/2002
6 3 6 3 14
rerate Has been a while since I rated this beer, glad to see my rating havent chnaged much.
Cloudy golden colour with firm white head, yeasty bread mouthfeel with hint of spice.
Hazy gold with huge white head.Medium sweet flavor with puckery astringent finish. Peppery and yeasty
Not as good as Chimay Bleu but thats only because its not dark and yeasty enough. Very drinkable, though.

More "drinkable" than Chimay Bleu, but probably less distinct. Dark fruits and alcohol dominate the flavor. Not nearly as yeasty-tasting as Bleu. This is probably a good, easily accessible intro to Belgians.
Another wonderful Belgian Tripel Ale... Nicely hoppy....

Spicy, yeasty, alcohol, and hop aroma to start; Golden hazy color, could be a little more clear for a tripel.  Mouthfeel is a little astringent and slightly heavy for a tripel, but whos to question the Trappist Monks about their beer?  Very nice beer, but not one of my favorites from Chimay, although Ive only had 2 of them.  Ive yet to try the Blue Label.

Chimay Blue is my favorite but this is still one damn fine ale. The Monks that thought about making these ales and cheese are great.  If it wasnt for the lack of women Id love to be a monk at this Abbey.  But then again they throw me out.
not my favorite chimay..but defintely not a bad choice. more of a fruity taste with a slight aftertaste. still great..

I detect a baked apple taste, with some yeast thrown in to boot.  Also, there was a certain mustiness about it that I felt detracted from the beer.  There wasnt much of an aroma, and its appearance was hurt by its weak head and murky body.

Note - I had the beer in its 11.2Oz Triple incarnation.
I found the flavour of this beer quite tangy from the smaller bottle but from the Cinq Cents bottle it came across quite alot smoother.  It has a nice hit of alcohol in its aftertaste

My least favourite of the three Chimays, but great nonetheless.  Probably the most consistent of the bunch, which has its own merits I suppose, and a really strong finish.  ...  On another tasting four months later - this time from the larger cinq cents bottle - I got a lot more from it.  Very smooth with tons of great flavour - a touch of pleasing alcohol leading into a fruity, hoppy swig, like liqueured cherries or something.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2003 This is good stuff!  My favorite Chimay.  Huge musty, yeasty flavor/aroma, backed up by a great hoppiness.  Smooth in the mouth, followed up by a satisfying bitterness.  Addendum -- I had this beer on tap.  I do not recall it being quite as nice from the bottle, but ymmv.

Very special.  One of the best beers Ive had.  Hoppy, yeasty, and earthy.  Everything is balanced.  The aroma is refreshing and uplifting.  The taste is refined, and more complex than that in the rouge.  Perfect head.  The only negative is that it isnt ultracomplex like some stronger Belgians.  My favorite Chimay.

Deep hazy, golden color with a tall head that disipates to a 1/4 inch of thick foam.  Aroma of a sour cream raisin pie.  the smooth mellifuous liquid crosses the lips and the flavors bounce about merrily.  Yeasty, with flavors of cherries and spiced apples.  Less assertive than the aroma and initial sips.  Warming alcohol with a fairly strong bitterness in the finish.  To me this a is a cross between a triple and a strong, and smewhat missing both.

Has a cloudy orange color and hoppy smell.  Taste is of hops with a accompanied bitterness and finishes with crisp bitterness.  Overall this is the third Chimay beer that I have had and I am not impressed.  I just am not into their flavor.  At least I got a cool glass with the three-pack...

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2008 Thin slightly creamy head with an old honey color.  Gardenia, dough, straw, and coriander nose.  Lush medium firm mouthfeel with flowery bitterness, honey, spices, ginger, and caramel.  Light bready finish with a firm grassy bitterness.  Very round and nice.
Big fruity nose, citrusy and grapefruit-like. Hazy orange color and a huge spongy head. Yeasty, lemony and spicey. Astringent finish. Medium body. Complex and sophisticated.

Dull, cloudy orange-tan with a large fluffy, creamy, goin nowhere head. There are orange peel and coriander notes making this reminiscent of a wit (but probably coming from the yeast). In the flavor there is subdued spiciness and a small, thin bitter aftertaste. Light and airy feel and a bit creamy.
UPDATED: JAN 15, 2003 Good stuff.  Nice thick but short head.  Cloudy body, nice belgian lacing, spicy, aromatic taste with a sweet, carbonated finish.  cleanisng aftertaste.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2003 Appearance: Image of Sahara desert just before dawn, thick pillow, dancing yeast on CO2 bubbles. Aroma; Alcohol is proudly standing in the front line , shy salt and pepper is hiding before well known Belgian yeast , Baltic sea ice .
Taste: Der Kommandant reported that proud alcohol become more refined blended nicely with team of Chimay .Blended nicely, gut for long sipping trip. For Trappist long enough for those lonely nights, monk and Chimay...

pours hazy golden with a huge pillowy white head.  yeasty, sweet and spicy(black pepper, coriander) aroma.  malt has a honey-ish sweetness to it with more spice in the background.  an excellent triple.
Didnt like this as much as the bleu.   However it was petty good.  Besides the yeast and hops, I could taste peaches, grapes, apples, orange peal, and honey all blended together.

My first impression is of the intense carbonation and enormous head this beer has. Definitely the hoppiest of the Chimay brews. I dont like this quite as much as I do the Premiere or the Reserve, probably due to the less intensive maltiness I love so much in Belgian ales. As well complimented as the bitterness is, I think the esters and fruit are a bit lost in the flavor. This doesnt quite sit on the palate like a nice fluffy Belgian should (in my opinion that is). Apart from all this tongue-lashing, this is still a very good beer. Theres a lot happening with the fruit and alchohol, and I love that lace
IMO better than the reserve. And I loved the reserve. This beer is just about perfect. Dark copper color, full-bodied, and fruity.
Grapefruity, orange-y nose. Orange body with a medium head. Also very grapefruity flavor, nice medium bitter aftertaste.

Tried this one from tap.It was served in a mini 25CL Chimay glass.Didnt have the nice head it usually does.Herbal hoppy aroma.Balanced crisp herbal sweet, slightly fruity flavor then dry with a medium bitter finish.This is my favorite Chimay.

Re-Rate 11/22/02: A pellucid amber color on the pour, the head is large-scale, the lace filmy fine sheets that cling to the Chimay Chalice. Nose is malt, hints of citrus and lightly sweet, and quite pleasant. Start is malt, somewhat sweet, the top squinny, the finish is medial in carbonation, the hops pronounced, the aftertaste bone dry. Of the three Chimays, this is my least favorite, great in its own right, just not my personal favorite, but well worth a sample if you have not.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2003 Bottled in 7/01 sampled on 8/2/02: brilliantly opaque orange..Gigantice head of big bold bubbles..Bubbles endlessly shot up from the bottom of the glass...spicy, slight citrus, and a tad eggy in aroma...mellow wheaty notes surround a pretty firm spiciness and a blizzard of orange & lemon zest..  I like this better than the blue...haven't had the red yet...yet..Nevermind..had the red tonight..The white is the best chimay IMO...Re-Rate 8/30/03 Draught:   Everything it was before and more..with super twang grapefruit playdough..Re-Rate 11/23/02:  beauty damn beauty..yeasty almost medicinal horsehay nostril cleaner..bananas..citrus and yeast..mellow & smooth..Rock da disqotek!

This was a 15mo old bottle. Pours a nice medium golden color with a big white head. Has a nice hoppy, yeasty aroma typical of a Belgian strong ale. The flavor is a perfect blend between hops, malts, and spices with a perfect level of carbonation. I think I like this one better than the Grande Reserve. A very nice ale and well worth the price.

7/01:750ml:Medium strentghed cork removal.Deep,hazy,golden with a bubbly,fizzy white head.Pefectly creamy and retition.Fruity,hoppy,yeasty aroma are terribly inviting,to me.The softest,velvety palate,was incredible.Made this extremely drinkable.Flavor are round and balanced and compliment the aroma well.Lightly sweet and malty with a big fruity,slightly dry,finish.Cork bottles seem more consistent.I will stick with them from now on.

Although this ale has a higher ABV than the Chimay Rouge, it is a much less complex and therefore a more drinkable ale.  Very little malt, more hops, fruit flavors of peach/raisons and some spice.  Very drinkable.

Huge head out of the bottle, although I think that was a function of the stem ware I poured it into.  Deep golden color with a nice spicey nose.  Lots of clove/coriander spice flavor with apple and orange tastes to balance it out.  Bitter orange peel in the finish.  I remember liking this beer more, but still a great beer.
UPDATED: MAR 24, 2003 Cloudy goldeness with nice aroma.  Citrus flavors and slight bitter after taste.  Strong beer, worth  looking into.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text:
a firm, creamy, long-lasting head. Strong aroma of hops and citrus. Also hops and citrus in the dry taste, combined with a slight tartness. Long hopbitter finish. A real, complex, trappist ale, maltier and easier to drink than Orval and Westmalle tripel.
Re-rate from tap, Café de Nieuwe Roos Ootmarsum: Ive boosted the rating from 3.8 to 4.3. Sweeter than the bottled version, almost honeyish, but with the raw hoppiness and the long lingering hoppy finish. Maybe the bottled version is a bit more complex, but the tap version has a much more appealing taste.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2009 Had this on draught - new here. What a complete delight. I was drinking free rounds and so had the pleasure of really tasting this. (the next morning was another story) Would love to do a comparison with small bottle, 750ml and draught. Found this to have maintained all the fine qualities of the bottle with all the subtle characteristics there - raisins, slight bitterness and alcohol warmth there ever so lightly. Delicious!

Much preferred the Red to this but still an excellent ale - the Blue is next.  Clean, slighlty fruity aroma, nice cloudy nectar-like appearance.  Gets better as it warms - more subtle flavors such as raisins come through. Strong to the finish. Good way to wind up the weekend with a steak dinner.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2003 This is a very good triple. Fruity aroma. And no doubt: This is Chimay with the characteristic yeast-flavour. I love it! 
Draught at The Danish Beerfestival 2003: Even better than bottled!

This time I got a much more complex aroma including; fresh (apple and grapefruit) and dried fruit (raisins), grainy malty spice, and a weird soapy charcoal as well as the barnyard yeast. Flavours mirrored aromas  closely. Alcohol becomes more evident as it warms. Nice hint of grapefruit in the finish and aftertaste. Points are exactIy the same as the previous rating, and I still prefer both the red and the blue over this one.First rated 4/11/2002: 3.8 Hazey gold colour, fine off white head. Complex lotsa-character aroma, more of barn yard, wet hay and malt, lighter on hops, fruit and yeast. I found it less complex in flavour than either the Blue, Orval or the Westmalles. Full reasonably balanced bitter-sweet start, malty body with excellent finish.
I had a couple of goblets from draft.  Definitely a strong ale, that did not have as much aroma as I expected.  I do agree this beer "melts in your mouth" and also began to "melt my senses".

RE-RATE Its hard for me to get excited about this beer anymore; the other Chimays are so much more complex while this one tastes more like an average tripple.  Hazy-light golden color.  Spicy beginning that fades but still retains some of its character toward the finish.  Strong mouthfeel, but still my least favorite of the Chimays. Original rating 1/1/2002 9-5-9-4-17 An excellent brew.  I cant really decide if I like this or Chimay Blue better.  Well-balanced hoppiness, fruity flavors are evident.
Very nice beer, smooth and complex flavor with a subtle hoppyness.
yum...this was a great triple, chimay is so good Im going to get more of bleu though.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2004 RateBeer Summer 2003, 1994 vintage:  Apple aroma, fizzy, tastes slightly old and oxidized.  Perhaps 9 years is a bit much for this beer (7/4/5/3/11).  Re-rate:  Spicy nose with light fruits, medium body, peppery ending.  Rating unchanged. First rating:  75CL bottle from 06/00 drank on 1/27/02: Yeasty taste, with fruit tones.  I prefer the Red and Blue over this.

Foggy golden bronze color. Fluffy, pillowy, dish soap head floated on top till bitter end. Adhesive lace. Herby hops, alcohol, and yeasty aroma, with subtle fruit accents. Dry palate. Lingering hoppy finish. The flavors meld as this one warms.
A revelation. Reminded me of Witte Hoegaarden, but while Hoegaardens White reminds you of hot summer evenings, this is a beer for all the year round.
Delicious.  Well balanced.  Flat out delicious.

Wow, what an aroma on this one!!! Tooty fruity was this thing good!!! Very appealing golden brownish colour with quite a lot of head may i add. Good strong taste grabs the tongue, but not as strong as to make you cringe. A good aftertaste is left after a nice chimay white...very impressive indeed.
750 bottle.  Beautiful hazy golden color with a thick head that floats on top.  As it warmed the fruit and floral notes came out, especially banana.  Some spice, didnt notice much alcohol.
UPDATED: JAN 11, 2003 Nasty colour, Typical trappist-taste and a pleasant palate

750 bottle: wonderful cloudy orange -for want of a better adjective- color. fully fluffed bubbley head. sour aroma. sour but spicey flavor. 

certainly interesting, but hardly rave worthy, imho. i wasnt bowled over by the red either, as i recall.....

Bottle - 09/21/02.  A light spicy, fruity, cider, champagne, dry, yeasty, golden blonde ale that tickles the mouth with its joyfulness.  This beer will always hold a special place in my heart.  On my last night in Hong Kong and the end of a 40 day tour through Asia I smoked a Cuban cigar and had a bottle of Chimay Blanche on the Kowloon side of the bay during the mid-autumn festival late in the evening watching the lights of city and the festive atmosphere of the crowd.  I celebrated the end of a big exam a of couple months earlier with a Chimay Rouge, so it was only fitting to end this trip with a Chimay and a Cuban.  Both seemed destined to meet at this place and this time.  Thanks to Irvin for sharing in the adventure.
deep copper/light amber color with quite a bit of sediment. good creamy head. aroma is dominated by some sourness. reminds me a bit of a lambic. flavor is sweet and slightly metallic.

2001 edition, I believe. Very peppery, fruity, spicy dry and hoppy aroma. Fresh, assertively bitter flavor. Deep gold color, nice head retention. Extremely aromatic, it seems coarse though, like it would benefit from aging -  mellowing for another year or so. Still very good for fans of strong, dry beers - compare to Corsendonk abbey pale.

Nice gold/bronze hue with creamy, rocky head--patchy lace...Aroma is dry, yeasty, vaguely fruity in a dry, cidery way...Flavor features a good blend of mild sweetness, hop bitters, and a yeasty spiciness that lingers through the warm finish...Carbonation is lively but well-judged, and body is medium-full, which gives a nice anchorage to its otherwise buoyant character...I always get the 750ml bottles so that the brew has a chance to work on me a little bit...the second glass is invariably better than the first!

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2004 Light golden copper color, with a large fluffy white head. Heavy clove and banana aroma. Light clove, banana, spice and sweet malt flavors with a nice hoppy bite. Medium carbonation with a fairly dry finish.

Just have to up the numbers on this one a bit, I forgot how much of a  sour apple presence this one has.
8/17/02: This is my favorite Chimay ale. Deep golden.  A little spice, citrus and raisin notes.  Smooth mouthfeel and balance is superb for this tripel. Excellent Trappist ale!

Light gold color, large head. Medium bodied, malt y and hoppy. Some malt sweetness and fruitiness. Good balance. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is crisp and clean. Aftertaste is slightly bitter. Beer is 8% alcohol by volume, no alcohol bite.
Strong taste of alcohol in this one. No real complexity, but a dry aftertaste. A hint of something bitter stroke my mind (orange-shells maybe?). I like it because of the strength in the brew.

Rerate:  Not much has changed in my opinion of htis one.  However, the last rating was a bit imprecise.  The big thing I noticed was the bit of fruit, or really, what I meant by that.  Apples, green, Granny Smith Apples.  A bit of white grape, and maybe even pear.  Still quite enjoyable.  Still refreshing.  7/16/2002:  Crisp aroma.  Spicy with a bit of fruit. Nice dry finish.

An orange beer with a beutiful head. It has the aroma of orange and fruit and the tastes of the same. It is very well balanced between the sweetness and the bitter lingering. A great beer that I enjoy on a regular basis.

Very hoppy and very carbonate.  It had a lot more acidic taste in the beer than I would have thought. Slightly more bitter than I was expecting, but that little edge was intriguing.  A nice beer, but not as nice as I was expected.

Great fruity aroma that doesnt come on to strong. The color is a murky golden yellow with some sediment visible. II noticed a hint of banana in the flavor along with other fruits. Not nearly as bitter as I had expected. Overall a good brew, and I recommend it to all.

This is the BEST beer in the World! I have traveled the World in search of it and have brought it to 5 star restaurants with me and served in a chiller. A beer so good you will want it after a night on the floor of the bathroom and still appreciate the taste

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2003 This was a great beer, but not as good as the Chimay Bleu. Spice and fruit aroma abound. Cloudy brown in color. Tastes of apples but seems sort of dry, especially during the aftertaste. Great beer, nonetheless. Highly recommended.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2004 Very bubbly...like champagne actually. There is a not-too-strong aroma and taste of sweet clove and a refined woody flavor. Pretty hazy yellow/golden color with a massive creamy white head that lasts forever. Not my favorite of the trio, but still a highly crafted and completely enjoyable beer.

Dark golden unfiltered color. Nice solid head. A very nice aroma. Complex is an understatement! It is fresh, bitter and still fruity sweet! Hints of hop and yeast. Long lingering aftertaste. One of my favorite tripple!
The Chimay I would reccommend to someone new to the style. Lots of flavor, looks good and goes down easy.   Quite different than the Blue, but still very good.
colossus head and hypnotic orange glow, slightly creamy then real bitter, maybe I should become a monk...

Beautiful golden colour with a huge white and long lasting head. Wonderful and complex aroma: fruits, hops, spices (muscat). Flavour is fruity (orange) and the carbonation high. Very long, hoppy, and bitter finish - maybe even a bit too bitter for me.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2004 Golden in color, great lacy head, more of a hoppy nose, a bit of bitterness in the aftertaste, very smooth, very rich, had the pleasure of partaking in this very excellent brew ON DRAFT at Monks Cafe in Philly
The best of the best, the Paramount of all beers. Perfect palate & finish, dont be fooled by the light color. wonderful fruity aroma. I love this beer
Chimay remains the Champagne of beers.  I found the white to be lighter and more lemony than the Bleu and Red.  Still a fantastic beer that can be enjoyed at any time.
I prefer the red (Rouge) Chimay, but there aint a loser in the bunch.  I wish Westy was as easy to get though...

UPDATED: APR 12, 2004 In my opinion this is the 'worst' Chimay. Offcourse it's still an excellent beer. Good spicy taste 
#Rerate (april 12, 2004) Aged. Apple and yeast in aroma. Malty, sweet and full. Lacks fruitiness compared to the chimay speciale. The Speciale is certainly better for aging purposes.
Now this is a good beer.  Excellent flavor.  Expensive, but worth it every once in a while.

Very lovely yeasty flavor with some spicy and fruity undertones.  The flavor leaves a bit too quickly though and I wish it were a bit more complex.  I think Chimay has a certain mystique because it comes in a wine-sized bottle, its made by monks and its not cheap.  This isnt really my thing, but its still pretty good.

Nothing wrong with this brew at all... the hints of spice and citrus are quite wonderful, and the appearance is just gorgeous... a reddish orange on top that submits to a more golden orange towards the bottom... bubbling at all points during my drinking experience. Citrus and spice are all I can really say about this brew with a great hoppy finish... great beer
Not bad, but I prefer either the red or blue Chimay to this.
A fruity nose, Large head, Colour is a golden haze. Chimay yeast flavour which is fruity & spicy.

On draught-Liars Club, San Diego.  Beautiful presentation.  Opaque orange with lovely and firm white head.  the aroma is wonderfully inviting.  Spicy aroma.  the palate is very lively, keeps it from getting thick on the tongue, also keeps the flavors exciting.  Excellent taste.  Alcohol is there but it is well matched, and disguised, by the spices and slight fruitiness that also come through.  I need to drink more of this beer, just not on tap, it is a little too pricey for me in the bars.
Good, as all Chimay beers are. Big dense head, citrus/fruity nose, hazy gold/light brown colour. Good fruity and yeasty flavour but I think I prefer the Red.

fresh,fruity and yeasty
great as an apperitife
Still think that the red and blue is better
A Dark golden color with a big foamy eggshell white head. A great combination of aromatic hops (Tettanger?)and fruity tastes. Very tasty!
Definately better than the red.Nice hops, balanced well with the malt. Grapefruit(?) aroma.Lively palate.Definately worth another try.
Has a peaty, barny, fruity aroma; taste citric/hoppy, yeasty, almost salty with good malt in the background; dry, piney finish. Very nice.

Theres a lot going on here.  I really enjoyed it, but before I can say much else Id have to try it again.  Had it out of a Chimay Goblet, which enhanced my drinking experience.  Easy to drink with a nice texture.  Very nice to look at, with a constant slow swirl in the surface foam.   The big problem here was a very malty acidic burp several hours later.
[Cinq Cents] Very nice appearance. Much wheat and fruitiness in the nose. Dry, fruity and hoppy flavour. Reminds me of Leffe Blonde. This is not one of the best trappists Ive had.

a typical triple belgian strong ale. the alcohol is very prominent (some would say it tastes of methylated spirits). It has small notes of wheat especially in the aroma. The head is very smart. Not my favourite Chimay though.
Another well done Ale. Still prefer the red. But Im special in that way.
The middle Chimay, just the right amount of alcohol with a complex fruit taste.
Well, for a Belgian Tripel, this was a little disapointing.  The flavor was flat and it did not have the sharp spice that I have come to expect in a good tripel.
take the red and crank it up a notch

750ml bottle dated 03/00. Hazy peach. Tons of sediment. Fat and frothy white head. Turbulent carbonation. Healthy aroma doused with yeast, spicy notes and sugary hints. Wisps of sour acidity. Surprisingly mellow, despite the carbonation. Slightly airy but tolerable. Spicy and zesty with a nice hop charge. Lingering yeast aftertaste. Medium body. Musty and damp with traces of sweetness. The spiciness is playful and tempers the yeast flavor a bit, at times. Mushiness creeps in as it sits, as does pin pricks of alcohol. Fairly balanced between sweetness and acidity.  Typically large Chimay yeast pour adds sharp yeast overtones, countering the spicy nature. Thickens the body and adds a cottony nature. Finishes spicy, hoppy yet mushy and bland. A fan of Chimay I am not, and never will be.

A great beer. Part of a 3-pak with a free Chimay glass for $6.99, what a bargain. I would have bought all of them if they had more than one. Beautiful hops, great orange/brown color, creamy white head. Not as good as the Blue but definitely something I could drink a lot of.
A good beer. A little bitter, coriander, a little alcohol taste.
Appearence is really excellent - a 5 in fact. Oh so smooth with lovely fruity, yeasty flavours. Could have done with a bit more spiciness but its great all the same.

Prickly, robust piny aroma with an alcohol body in this taupe-orange brew. Smooth body sends piquant signal to nose, but the flavor is more warm and rounded in mouthfeel than having distinct decipherable components although wheat and evergreen needles seem detectable. Alcohol is present, but well masked. This beer finishes with a peppery pinyness.
Thick creamy head, fruity aroma, strong alcohol taste.

Great looking beer. Bright orange/gold color with lovely lace. Fluffy white head. Aromas of pepper and coriander with a touch of alcohol. Hop bitterness that envelops the palate. Flavors of orange and pepper. Finish is a tad harsh but still quite enjoyable.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2006 Chalky flour cream...Very yeasty clouds obscure the sweet oranges in the distance...Alcohol bitterness meets the hops in the back...Between a tripel and a witbier...Lemon, pepper, floral hops and cinnamon also play very quietly...
This ale has a large creamy white head.  A complex beer with definate strong spicy?pepper flavor.  Well balanced and complex.  I prefer the red and blue Chimays, but this is well above average.

This beer rocks. The hazy color of apricot nectar (my wifes assessment). As with most Belgian ales, the nose hints of a skunk about 300 yards away...downwind. Also, a very fruity aroma.  A very crisp, clean, spicy flavor with a dry, effervesant finish. Yum.

Bonus.
Drunk this baby a number of times.. never realised that we hadnt rated this lover.
Orangey, honey, smokey Tequila pepperpinch (eh wtf?). 
Like the 750ml bottles.... 

Nice. But dont drink through your nose. Well you have to get up close to get the full aroma.....

The Palate, she doesnt linger too long and when shes gone she leaves her shoes at the door.

Dont care..gonna drink it again and will re-rate it again. again.

Pale in color, thick white head of foam. Nose is surprising for style, a perfumy citrus, notes of orange with an underlying maltiness. Palate is soft and lightly carbonated, showing soft oak tones throughout (could be due to 6 months laying on its side). Green apple intro lends an enticing crispness, turning astringent in the latter half and souring in the finish. Mildly refreshing fruity tones in the latter half.
Nice orange body with requisite abundant head & Belgian Lace. Flavour was full on but like trying to chomp through a grapefruit.

Darker than a normal blonde ale and the head lasts for ever.  The aroma and flavour are more akin to an English ale with citric undertones.  Thoroughly drinkable, one of the best Belgium ales you will drink.

This got better as I got to the bottom (having already had a Chimay Rouge before it, is there any wonder?) but there were some elements that prevent this from reaching the stratospheric levels that ten years ago I might have expected of Chimay.  Head is not as rich as the Rouge and the alcoholic essence is a wee bit overpowering here.  The palate, too, is slightly askew--too much carbonation.  I liked the hint of floral/fruit in the flavor, as well as the yeastiness in the aroma.  No doubt, enjoyable--my rating is being extra critical--there are no fundamental flaws with this beer, just nagging doubts about its composition.

Nice citrus flavors with a dap of yeast on the backend. Pretty carbonated which takes away from my drinking experience. Chimay is solid, just wish is was more affordable and this style is a bit on the light side for my personal tastes.
I prefer the Bleu as well.  This one was OK, but I think the astringent flavor was a bit much.
I prefer the bleu, but this is also a good one...

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2004 Cinnamon, nutmeg, coriander and citrus. Mildly excessive sugariness is forgivable when the trade off is that silken palate. A wonderful sipping beer. Drinking from the corked 750ml bottle is a must, the little ones do it an injustice.
Big head atop a golden unfiltered body.  Sweet, fruity, peppery aroma.  The flavor, however, is, in addition to all these, slightly astringent.  Alcohol flavor noticeable, but not unpleasant.
Good.  Strong.  Less complex than expected, though.  Mostly just strong.
Unreal. Not as good as the bleu though.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2011 Rerate, 750 ml corked bottle, as Chimay Cinq Cents, Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 8%. Some sediment in the bottle. Hazy golden colour, huge white head. Nice fruity, floral, yeasty and spicy aroma. The flavour is also fruity, yeasty and spicy (distinctly peppery, also nutmeg) with a hoppy bite in the finish. Very moreish. Im upping it a point. Original rating: Peppery and spicy indeed, this is a beer out of the ordinary. The White is surely not a beer I regret sampling, but Id prefer Chimay Blue by a mile.
Starts with peppery aromas and a spicy palate.  This foamy beer continues with caramel notes and ends with more spices.  Has a nice warming finish.  Good ole Chimay!

Wow! Isnt this kind of Belgian wit-ish? I see in others reviews lots of orange, coriander references, and I agree, and those are usually qualities in a good wit, right? I loved this one. As different from the Bleu as can be, yet a gem in its own right.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Beautiful head that stays around. I particularly liked the combination of hop bitterness and fruityness. Excellent trappist ale, but still comes short to Bleu.
Dense white ghead that leaves a filigree trail. A head that lasts till the finish. Aroma of fresh fruit and soft palate of light citrus. Bloody marvo!!

UPDATED: APR 8, 2012 Bottle. Head is initially large, frothy, white, mostly lasting. Body is hazy dark yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers), lightly to moderately yeasty (mold, basement), with notes of Juicy Fruit gum, coriander, and pepper/alcohol. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter, unclean. Medium body, syrupy texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Somewhat attractive nose, but rather clunky and dirty in the mouth.
Light brown, foamy beer. There is some liquorice and pepper in this very dry and bitter beer.  The aftertaste is very bitter. The alcohol is also too dominant for my taste.
Great Beer!  It seemed to have overtones of orange and maybe a hint of nutmeg.  Very good flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2003 I could really dig this beer. It reminds me of a four 0 cause of the size, so i put it in a bag and enjoyed. Its kinda like what ya drink after a ghetto wedding. Whats with all the names, does this beer think its prince or what? I say it should go with the cinq cents cause it sounds cool and also becuase the blanche thing gives me visions of the golden girls. As far as the beer itself, it was really good, one of the best. It tasted a lil bit weird at first, but very good.  Lots of cool flavors in this, but my belgian palate was not what it is now, so i want some more.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2004 big, yeasty, phenolic, peppery, harshly bitter, alcoholic, slightly caramelly, estery with sweaty green banana. really rough, nasty highalpha bitterness and phenols ruin this. it tastes like an american IPA with an infection. but i still give it points for lots of flavour.

I really like this beer, and id go as far as to say its probably my favoured Chimay, soft floral aroma. Deep orange colour with a pillowy head at first fading to a thin head which sticks all the way down to the bottom. Dry, bitter orange peel flavour aswell as added spice and pepperiness and a medium to full body, smooth aswell with abitter aftertaste. excellent beer, lots of flavour.
Nice white head, almost fizzy.  Orange colour.  A hoppy, fruity aroma.  Strong but very drinkable.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2004 Small bottle
Fruity (apricot) and spicy aroma.
Orange chestnut, hard to avoid yeast clumps, big creamy head.
Fruitbread base, raisins, citric freshness, a bit marzipan. 
Relatively light body, somewhat foamy mouthfeel.
Sugary aftertaste. 
It is a really nice trippel - fresh and with a light body, but I dont know, something was missing - mayby it was the small bottle
Hoppy,fruity,quite strong.

A huge outpouring of a frothy, white head, which sticks around for the duration, a golden-yellow color, a nice, pronounced aroma, this resembles the Westmalle Tripel, although in my view, not nearly as complex, not as sweet, there’s more of a lasting bitterness here, not as evolving a flavor, but this is a rich, slightly fruity, ultra-strong pale ale.  As with the Chimay Bleu, I found a sour dullness in the flavor.  The look, the texture, the balance is all there, but the flavor ultimately disappoints.

A nice golden colour with loads of fizz.  The head remains for an age, without being too big.  It also offers a nice and clean, fruity smell.  Not sweet like I expected, but fruity and hoppy.  Im not too keen on drinking through head but ill forgive that on this one.  Nice and refreshing, and not too complicated.
I drunk him 4-5 times and every time i discover new things. Not as good as Chimay Bleu, but a good trappist.
Somewhat hazy, golden/orange color. Threw up a good head that would not die. Nose is fruity hoppy. Finishes the same . Think Ill add this to the favorites list.

Finally tried the white. Could it be my favorite of the Chimays? Fun interpretation of the Tripel style, with that pleasant musty monastic essence. Drier than the others, but would go equally well with a hunk obleu as an aperitif. Splendid.

Incredible apearence!  Nice golden yellow colour with a beatiful, creamy, tall, white head with plenty of lacing.  Quite good banana/fruit aroma and a nice well balanced flavour to match.  The flavour is not quite as fruity or malty as I expected, yet still damn good.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2005 My favorite from Chimay, It does not have the overbearing malty sweetness that some Belgian Abby/Trappists have. Some have called it a pale ale on steriods, or maybe a Belgian interpretation of an IPA?
What a beautiful beer! the clean, white head compliments the golden/orange color perfectly and the crisp hoppy taste makes this beer that much more enjoyable.

Aroma very orangey, fruity and spicy, also laden with malt.  Beer is sort of a medium golden amber color, a little darker than I was expecting, actually.  Very generous head.  Flavor starts off with some sweet malt tripel-type flavors, but quickly some spicy flavors and even a bit of hops are thrown into the mix.  Mouthfeel is a bit on the dry side, body is medium.  Finish has a touch of sweetness, but overall is very citrusy, peppery and spicy.  Quite a different Tripel than my mind had formed a gastric picture of, but certainly tasty.  Nice lacing, too.  Pretty good!  Lacking a certain degree of complexity that I was sort of hoping for, however, likely bred by the excellence of the ubiquitous Blue and Red.

Sampled after an Orval. Nose is similar to Orval, but inferior. Tastes much sweeter, with far more prevalent alcohol flavor, as might be expected. It has just a tiny hint of the spicy zing that makes the Blue so distinctive. I dont find it all that peppery - more fruity - but maybe the beer I had before it had something to do with that.

The last of the Chimays. I feel so accomplished having gotten a hold of all of these. This triumvirate has been hyped up to me for quite some time. Truly they are great beers, but really not my style. The white reminds me of something else that I have had before, but I am not quite sure what it is. The head was extremely large, frothy and white, and it went down smooth. Although, I still feel that the red beats this one hands down.
This Chimay was a bit bitter for me...pretty harsh.  Need to try another bottle.  May have gotten a bad one.
I really dont think chimay could make a bad beer if they tried.  Slightly sweet citrus flavor which hides the alcohol.  Another winner.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2003 Re-rate.  Another truely great Chimay beer.  Served in a Chimay glass.  Fantastic appearance, orange in colour with a big creamy white head, simply stunning.  Orange and yeasty malt aroma.  Lightly malted taste with orange and perfumy, junipery dryness.  All Chimay beers are just superb.  However this is not their finest work, Blue is.
This has a great muskety aroma with citrus hints. The palate has tons of flavour with yeasty notes. This is truly a great beer.
Very tempting aroma, looks like a golden cloud. Rich, full flavour. Plenty of mouthfeel(dances on the tongue) A true Trappist Ale, great to the last sip!
Very good, I agree with other people that the red and the blue are better.
An overall very nice beer. A strong creamy head, pure white with a light spicey fruity aroma which follows through on the palate. Balanced by a finishing bittersweet hop/malt component.

Re-rate, A cloudy dark golden,almost orange color. Persistent head that did not die. Nose is fantastic,subtle banana,yeast,fruity undertones,sour apples(almost like a sour lambic quality) and more. Medium bodied,soft and lively mouthfeel. Bready,yeast,peppery notes,very light banana and honey flavors. Nice hop and bitter twang at the end. The balance between sweet and sour is awesome. This is good chit:)
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2007 Fruity aftertaste, rich amber color.  One of my favorites (when I can get it).
Re rate.  This beer used to have a secure spot in my top 20, but has fallen from grace. Too sweet, just doesnt have that je ne sais quoi of the great Belgians.
Quite bitter but very drinkable anyway.

Nice aroma and head, pale amber color.  The aroma reminds me of fruit, mainly pineapple, and is nice but also quite thin compared to the red and blue.
